wordpressContent.en-GB: [Follow my blog with Bloglovin](http://www.bloglovin.com/blog/14308057/?claim=zjrf4gtjazv) And so it begins. It started with a wedding. As I travelled up to Gloucestershire earlier this year I began planning how I was going to begin this blog. There seemed no better way to start it off with a post about a couple’s new beginning. ![IMG_0910](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4InpVPEBHGGiQA6CG8SsKy/439b1fadb10265a22c4f9c76c2317b82/img-0910.jpg) Charlie and I were on a three-hour train journey through the beautiful fields of Gloucestershire for Sami and Sophie’s wedding. It was the first we had been to that we could really appreciate (meaning we were old enough to get fully involved!) and remember all the finer details. From the moment Sophie made her elegant walk down the aisle and Sami said ‘Oh!’ to the moment they glided around the dance floor in their first dance, the day was beautiful.   The ceremony was lovely and everyone enjoyed belting out the old hymns. The flowers throughout the church were really pretty and had been created by Sophie's mum adding that homemade touch. After the canepes in the garden and a yummy buffet meal it was time to dance. Sami and Sophie had made a great choice with a swing band- everyone was up dancing and spinning around the room. ![IMG_0954](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/47ivyWaY1WOuq028OeOACK/bdb00e0704bc50b4e9389df298044f03/img-0954.jpg) Weddings are interesting events; you gain an insight into the person and their family. The day is full of smiles and happiness. The moments you share with the two families are moments that stay forever. [![IMG_0951](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/15qseyuM4ayYg4eqqiQEYU/5146e0e6d6998416449a1220c1692948/img-0951.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/15qseyuM4ayYg4eqqiQEYU/5146e0e6d6998416449a1220c1692948/img-0951.jpg) [Follow my blog with Bloglovin](http://www.bloglovin.com/blog/14308057/?claim=zjrf4gtjazv)

seoDescription.en-GB: And so it begins.... my first blog post.

wordpressContent.en-GB: With wedding planning underway the summer has been none stop. The best part so far has been the excuse to make trips up to Suffolk almost every weekend. Let me introduce why Suffolk is so important to me... ![IMG_0091](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5NEOwz5cfC844egWUWYAmu/cb913cceff7810f94400945f4604b010/img-0091.jpg)As the A12 opens up to never-ending fields and we arrive in Thorpeness, I always get a sense of excitement. Tucked neatly down a secretive track is the Cottage we stay in. There is always someone coming or going here, neighbours knocking on the door for dinner and unexpected boat trips. Suffolk is, to me, one of the most magical places. You don’t plan what to do here but you know you will always be doing one thing or another. [![IMG_0260](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4WdHwev7cAAuCIMIWcoEAW/165ef8bfc0db88df679c420be7f3c817/img-0260.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4WdHwev7cAAuCIMIWcoEAW/165ef8bfc0db88df679c420be7f3c817/img-0260.jpg) I've been going to the Cottage since I was 14/15 when I used to camp out in the field surrounded by all my closest friends. We would ride bikes, swim in the sea and build giant bonfires. The trips I made up here were completely different to how I spent my time at home. I remember Woo and I would spontaneously dress up and make the strangest cocktails out of whatever we could find. Carnival during August was always a main event up here. We would go and watch the floats during the day then sit on the beach at night watching the fireworks. Suffolk provides the best kind of escape from London and is just the thing to revive your creativeness. We’ve shared this place with all sorts of friends who have each found their own way to enjoy it. From Gee playing his guitar in the middle of a field to Jay drafting scripts - it seems only natural to host our big day up here. After exploring numerous wedding venues across Essex and Suffolk we've finally found our ‘one’. It’s just 15 minutes from the Cottage and has the sort of quirky, country house feel to it that I just love around here. If you ever get the chance to visit the Thorpeness / Aldeburgh area make sure you do. ![IMG_0108](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2esBdzJqd6SeMOWiuWAmcY/52597dad0aec8a6bdda4c26b0da01235/img-0108.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: An introduction to Suffolk and why I love sending time there

wordpressContent.en-GB: Charlie and I had arranged to meet up with our friend Jub Jub, who we hadn't seen for ages. With most of our friends still based in Essex we usually meet up with them around Liverpool street. I always struggle to think of new places to go which aren't too far from the station. I didn't realise there was a [La Tasca](http://latasca.com) so close. The dark, underground atmosphere seemed like a great place to hear all of his crazy stories which ranged from cheerleading to spending time on construction sites. ![La Tasca](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7uajXRoWas6cQG8wS8go8O/9d9a2d5b74dd5e4abb0645fac2ffb8b9/img-1521.jpg) I don't think I can remember having ever been to La Tasca so my first trip there was really pleasant. La Tasca seems like the standard [Prezzo](http://www.prezzorestaurants.co.uk)/ [Zizzis](http://www.zizzi.co.uk) chain but I quite liked that it brings a Spanish twist to the Italian dominated food market. I took advantage of O2 priority and used my 25% off code which made the meal super cheap - especially so near to the city. We decided to share everything and had with olives and bread for starter followed by seafood paella. My only fault was that we asked for chorizo in the paella but never got it, other than that it was a really delicious meal. Next time I go I think I'd try out some of the tapas dishes - I skimmed the menu and I could have eaten everything on there! My favourite type of meals are when you get a little bit of a lot of dishes. [![La Tasca](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/bXcIqTegHQAImmWmgkymk/49b1faa25cfde7d72906f7329383cff7/img-1525.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/bXcIqTegHQAImmWmgkymk/49b1faa25cfde7d72906f7329383cff7/img-1525.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My first time goig for dinner at La Tasca - the perfect place for catching up with old friends

wordpressContent.en-GB: For the past four years we've hosted the Wood Party. It's becoming a bit of a tradition and stems from when we used to spend so much time in Suffolk when we were all younger. It's a great chance to get all sorts of friends together for one big night together. We all arrive in a private woodland in the absolute middle of nowhere and set up for a magical evening. We decorate the clearing with tents, hammocks, a fire and fairy lights. Each year the amount of people grows and each year it gets better. Volleyball, face painting, vodka haribo (it's a thing?), strobe lighting, dancing, acrobatics, BBQs, bonfires and DJs have all featured at the party one time or another. ![10570365_10152671547738767_4987122103683071032_n](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/nVvclxLdbEQcK2seG2w6i/9b2741f7f37d94e6216bd4d307d082d8/wood-party.jpg) ![IMG_3507](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6OGvIe8Mo0CWyIwcQui4MK/cef6d13df0967fdc7c0628c395da68e8/img-3507.jpg) As the sun begins to set and the music gets cranked up the dancing begins. The different sets of friend spread between Charlie, Woo and I all mesh together and have a great time. Sure the woods may seem like a bit of a creepy place to spend the night, and be the perfect setting for a horror film but each year we come away, slightly worst for wear, with a smile on our face and a great story to tell. Don't worry your invite for next year is in the post! ![P1000041](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/cvwlGHvOmcukEsSqYY2wq/009aefd3be7c45e764ba32575b93b3b0/p1000041.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: The annual wood party and how we make it into the event of the year

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I remember being on the school swimming team waiting at the side for my race. I would always do front crawl, sometimes the other strokes but mainly front crawl. I'd LOVE that rush you get as you dive in for a race, the power you feel as you propel yourself through the water and that adrenaline always had me hyped up afterwards. I learnt to dive and tumble turn pretty late on but luckily my stroke and breathing techniques made sure I kept up with the team. I loved racing and that 30 seconds of screaming someones name in encouragement and they smash through the water.

Swimming makes me feel great - so why don't I go swimming more often? It's a question I've asked myself for a while now and I think it all comes down to laziness. I'd love to swim but unless I have someone to encourage to swim or someone to encourage me it simply doesn't happen. I end up bringing in my kit and leaving it under my desk at work, or finding some excuse why I can't take an hour out of my day for a dip.

Having a wedding in about eight months is the perfect excuse, everyone talks about getting fit for a wedding but you won't catch me in a gym in a million years! I've found some swimming buddies and last night was my first swim in (roughly) three years. It felt amazing! I may have pulled some muscles in my arm by being a bit too over enthusiastic but it was worth it. Swimming lengths gives me an excuse to shut down my brain and stop thinking about everything - especially my wedding to do list! I found an [app by Speedo](http://www.speedo.co.uk/speedo-fit-app) where you can set yourself length goals so I'll be trying that out and seeing how far I can go in one session. All I need now is some practice and I'll be a fish in no time....

seoDescription.en-GB: Getting back into swimming ahead of my wedding, remembering school swimming galas and rediscovering my love for a speedy swim.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
To celebrate my dads birthday last week we went to [Masons](http://masonsrestaurant.co.uk/) restaurant. I've been there once before (possibly for my birthday) and remembered it was great food so I was really looking forward to it.

The banter was on a high as my brother and his friend kept cracking jokes through the meal. I'd forgotten what 16 year old boy talk was like!

I had heard that most of the staff were in collage and that definitively showed. Our waiter obviously had some experience but still seemed quite rude to us at times. The food more than made up for the service though; I wanted to try nearly everything on the menu.

[![IMG_1549](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7K7yvMZz1uM00GUKCEMCCg/caf69c378ea42bc7cf1876bf77723f8d/img-1549.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7K7yvMZz1uM00GUKCEMCCg/caf69c378ea42bc7cf1876bf77723f8d/img-1549.jpg)To start I had the Masons salad which is a mixture of rocket, sun dried tomatoes, pine nuts and blue cheese this was followed by fillet steak partnered with a strange but delicious looking potato cake and the sweetest onions I've ever tasted. The steak was amazing, normally when I ask for it blue it arrives fairly cooked but this was perfect. The evening was topped off with mango and passionfruit sorbet.

[![IMG_1556](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/37Yc2kBLoIoIq2cwg06OWk/e4ba51d3ca774230d351fd7778619105/img-1556.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/37Yc2kBLoIoIq2cwg06OWk/e4ba51d3ca774230d351fd7778619105/img-1556.jpg)

Full and more than satisfied we made our way home. If your ever in Brentwood for dinner try out Masons - the food is delicious.

seoDescription.en-GB: Dinner at Masons in Brentwood for my dads birthday

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I![IMG_1573](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5b1LcA3oA00EQekG6aEKo2/21ced0d0334eccc7fff118ed736d234a/img-1573.jpg)'d never thought about going on a spa day until my dad got mum and I a voucher for Christmas. I'm not the sort of girl who likes to get a facial or a pedicure; I just can't sit still for long enough!

After almost a year of trying to organise a day we finally booked it for the day before mums birthday. Off we went to [Clarice House](http://www.claricehouse.co.uk/) in Colchester. This is based in an old country home packed full of individual therapy rooms and a multitude of beauticians. They also have a pool with steam sauna and something called a eucalyptus room which you can use throughout the day.

We tried out plenty of treatments starting with a full body massage followed by a swim then a leg treatment, facial, lunch and finally a manicure and pedicure. We managed to pack a lot into the day.

My favourite treatment was probably the massage as the beautician doing it worked really hard on my back. The facial was also lovely except for the fact I fell asleep during my head massage - opps!

![IMG_1575](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4HjkE41GLCeeWC4G6GIYO2/611a051015207c73a7dd44357127e0db/img-1575.jpg)Lunch was all pre booked and served up very speedily in the dining room. I had some kind of mozzarella and chilli to start followed by chicken in a sage and onion sauce and maybe a cheeky glass of wine!

![IMG_1577](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4JnnUgwybKUUMyu6QaQW66/83b184e4282d23a03ca332999c21e406/img-1577.jpg)

The day was great, although somehow tiring! Time for bed I think.

seoDescription.en-GB: A spa day at Clarice house in Colchester

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Our last family holiday was over four years ago when we all went to Turks and Caicos for Christmas, so it's no surprise that I was fairly excited for our trip.

After a slight hiccup in Antigua (they found a hole in the plane) we arrived at our hotel, [Paradisus Palma Real](http://www.melia.com/en/hotels/dominican-republic/punta-cana/paradisus-palma-real-golf-and-spa-resort/index.html). First impressions were fantastic - the reception was giant with columns all around and backlit fountains. This was going to be a great holiday. [![IMG_4492](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2t1N6ekSKUC0goQMqOUMgI/f8e65d61ca97abcc284acd717c710cfa/img-4492.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2t1N6ekSKUC0goQMqOUMgI/f8e65d61ca97abcc284acd717c710cfa/img-4492.jpg)

Through the next two weeks we discovered all about Dominican culture and spent vast amounts of time doing a whole lot of nothing. There is far too much to include in one blog post so I'll give you some highlights over the next few posts.

_The food_

With seven different restaurants to choose from we were spoilt for choice. A few of the places called for men to be in trousers and shirts which was a nice excuse to get a bit dressed up. My favourite places were Aqua or Vento (both did amazing steak). Typical food in the Dominican Republic is rice and chicken so of course there was plenty of this on offer. I personally took advantage of the amount of steak on the menus and the all inclusive sushi. My last lunch may have bean steak and sushi! [![IMG_4551](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6kEOCtaDZKsm2q6U6oqUia/a5cbc64f2bcc1673356b13fccd9a298d/img-4551.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6kEOCtaDZKsm2q6U6oqUia/a5cbc64f2bcc1673356b13fccd9a298d/img-4551.jpg)

If you're considering going to the Dominican Republic then go! It's a great island and everyone is really friendly. There is plenty of excursions to do but be aware that everyone will want a recommendation on Trip Advisor! The Dominican Republic is a great island to visit if you get the chance. Just be sure to fully research any excursions as there are plenty on offer. I'd definitely recommend the [Outback tour](http://vikibell.com/the-outback-tour/ "The Outback Tour"). You can read more about the [Bavaro Splash](http://vikibell.com/bavaro-splash/) trip we took and [the shows](http://vikibell.com/the-shows/) we saw.

Until next time.... [![IMG_4526](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ikcjm2lJukIcWkA40UmKu/890fd61f24b1d7a1912d181d8e2f0eb2/img-4526.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ikcjm2lJukIcWkA40UmKu/890fd61f24b1d7a1912d181d8e2f0eb2/img-4526.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Dominican Republic

wordpressContent.en-GB:
We were up bright and early ready for our [Outback tour.](http://www.outbackadventuresdr.com/) I had no idea what to expect but dad said if it was anything like one he'd been on before it would be great.

Angel picked us up in some like of truck with open sides and off we went to pick up others from hotels. The majority of tourists to the Dominican Republic are American so it was no surprise we were the only Brits on the bus. We all got chatting about our countries and we faced the 20 Brit questions (how often do you drink tea? Do you know the Queen?) One even said I sound like the Queen and Charlie looks like Will! ![IMG_4699](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/64A4GBXWvuWQ6QyIYK0ak8/f39e4c823fde83378ce011c00d6462a0/img-4699.jpg)

Our fist stop was a local school. Here the government pays for the school building and the teacher but anything else like teaching supplies you have to buy yourself. This is where the outback tour comes in, it pays the school a little money in order to see the class room. This then buys books and stationary the kids need.

[![IMG_4698](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6CjTGbsAgMmK4GkI6keUAe/247e943d5c28610a85e81a42b174a0ab/img-4698.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6CjTGbsAgMmK4GkI6keUAe/247e943d5c28610a85e81a42b174a0ab/img-4698.jpg)

After the school we headed up the mountain to the outback huts. We were given a tour of the local vegetation showing is aloe Vera, basil, vanilla, coco and coffee beans amongst others. We also saw a cigar shack where the boy was rolling them with various flavourings. Did you know the tobacco factories pay for the middle bit of the leaf which is left out from a tobacco cigar. Why? Because it has 60% of the tobacco!

[![IMG_4743](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2gM8A601uIA2eIgC6IESeY/026c9db7d32b0c40e387fbc33d191d73/img-4743.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2gM8A601uIA2eIgC6IESeY/026c9db7d32b0c40e387fbc33d191d73/img-4743.jpg)

After a Local lunch of Dominican fried chicken and rice we saw and alligator, iguana, crocodile, flamingos and some local shops where we bought some mamajauana. We then headed down the mountain towards a local home. [![IMG_4756](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6qaxMIOhGw04g6CmgcMea8/7015ad16466df364368c2ea328a50140/img-4756.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6qaxMIOhGw04g6CmgcMea8/7015ad16466df364368c2ea328a50140/img-4756.jpg)

This was really brightly coloured and consisted of two shacks. One had two bedrooms a lounge and a work room; the other had a kitchen and the finest kitten if ever seen! There was where we were given a demonstration of how coffee is made (yum!) as well as vanilla, sugar cane and various ways of using the coco plant including chocolate of course.

[![IMG_4760](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/vRXKQWP8qc0SMWSumCAGW/a22073ac2d70034e4b6c285e6ae97a83/img-4760.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/vRXKQWP8qc0SMWSumCAGW/a22073ac2d70034e4b6c285e6ae97a83/img-4760.jpg)Then it was off to the beach. As tourism boomed on the island all the beaches have remained public. The only problem is that you can't get to them as the resorts take up all the space in front. We were heading to the last accessible beach in punta Cana which just so happened to be great for body boarding. I flung off my stuff and headed down to the waves to be crushed and whirled around - I seriously felt like I was 8 again! ![IMG_4801](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2oKjvufkze2CESIomAy8cM/d8c48333ad4e9320c6f400ea1ddd63f2/img-4801.jpg)

The day was topped off with a few too many rum and lemonades and a lot of stories to tell.

seoDescription.en-GB: The outback tour we took in the Dominican Republic

wordpressContent.en-GB: For our second excursion we'd chosen something water based. [Bavaro Splash](http://oceanadventures-puntacana.com/bavaro-splash.html) was the perfect combination of my desire to snorkel and Matthews need to drive a speed boat. On Thursday after lunch we were collected and taken for a safety briefing. After this we found ourselves on a boat headed for the offshore reef. Our group was first to snuba. I hadn't heard of snuba before but it was soon explained that it's a form of diving that combines both snorkelling and scuba diving by supplying your oxygen through a long tube to a breathing device. At first I wasn't sure about how the pressure would feel but we only went down around 5 metres so it was fine. The guide, Wilkins, took my camera and took plenty of photos of us all on the chairs, feeding fish and holding a sea urchin. [![P1030578](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3SL7MOFBNmUqYQkcSO0AyM/ef235c99d5054931a1b358354d022ccd/p1030578.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3SL7MOFBNmUqYQkcSO0AyM/ef235c99d5054931a1b358354d022ccd/p1030578.jpg) After snuba we stayed in the sea to do some snorkelling. This part wasn't as fun but there were plenty of fish swimming around. One even treated me like a whale and was swimming alongside me for ages - not sure I like being compared to a whale! It was really nice to explore the reef and see the different fish swimming around. We had some bread with us to feed them too, although one bite my finger! [![P1030624](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ygrC0axYMmKI8cSQ8oCok/27bc3ec24c24451337409b42cf53f4cc/p1030624.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ygrC0axYMmKI8cSQ8oCok/27bc3ec24c24451337409b42cf53f4cc/p1030624.jpg) Our final activity of the day was speed boating. We each paired up and got given a boat along with instructions of what not to do. I went first and was smashing our boat into the biggest waves and flinging us around the coast line. Of course I may have forgotten that we weren't supposed to "zig zag" it across waves and was a little violent with the driving, but it was all good  Matthew's turn was up and, after an initial stall, he managed to get to grips with the driving. He really had a great time! This was an excellent activity to end on as the sun was setting and the island looked beautiful. After we got back to shore we decided to walk back along the beach to our hotel. It was a really lovely afternoon trip. [![P1030706](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2uWGt5GpzC6Kicm0geywO2/e508794e8a158017e3343397f8a825ee/p1030706.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2uWGt5GpzC6Kicm0geywO2/e508794e8a158017e3343397f8a825ee/p1030706.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A sea trip we took in the Dominican Republic - Bavaro Splash

wordpressContent.en-GB: Evening entertainment at hotels is always a bit hit or miss. Of course you can never expect a west end quality performance but you can have some fun watching the reps bounce around doing routines they know inside and out. At the Paradisus it was no different; each evening the reps would put on a show, either on the stage or around the courtyard. Our favourite shows were by far the Jazz and electro ones. The Jazz night had a lady singing accompanied with a band. She sung all the hits from Nancy Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald and Frank Sinatra. The reps all did a dance routine for some of them and of course the singer acted very tipsy for _One more for the road_ - although I don't think some people understood as they seemed to leave in disgust! [![IMG_4377](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4zObCEDzQIEUE4sace4ouc/77aa476fb4d2b36f9bde3d9e862e9674/img-4377.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4zObCEDzQIEUE4sace4ouc/77aa476fb4d2b36f9bde3d9e862e9674/img-4377.jpg) When we arrived at the electro night we were very confused. Angel (one of the reps) was painting around another of the reps on a giant board but was all neon and looked great with the glow of the light. The band suddenly struck up and a saxophone player begun walking around the crowd playing. This was followed by a bartender showing us various tricks as he made cocktails. Now it was our turn. The reps all came round and picked people to go up and copy one of them who was twirking in order to win a cocktail. After Charlie volunteered me, I found myself in the centre of the audience making some sort of attempt to dance. Thankfully I was good enough to get a cocktail! Then they carried on playing electro swing hits whilst people were up dancing. We're seeing a [Parov Stelar](http://vikibell.com/parov-stelar/) in a few weeks so if this hasn't got us excited I don't know what will![![IMG_4453](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5FuGoPnwaWYMeyiWkwW6UY/8fc08b3a0d111c426cc2c8b025b66276/img-4453.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5FuGoPnwaWYMeyiWkwW6UY/8fc08b3a0d111c426cc2c8b025b66276/img-4453.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: The shows we saw in the evening in Dominican Republic

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Everyone's creative in one way or another. Some are just more so than others.

Creativity is fed by experience and doing new and exciting things. If you constantly say no to trying out new stuff, you'll find yourself ageing into a very boring story. I've been reading a book called [Stuffocation](http://stuffocation.org/the-book/) by James Wallman and these thoughts keep cropping up.

Stuffocation is pretty much what it says on the tin; a book about how we, as a society, have too much stuff. It's made me begin to question the things I have lying around in my flat. Why do I need fifteen or so candle holders and 5 different salt and pepper shakers? Are we not better to spend our time and money doing new things rather than accruing more stuff?

Think about what you talk about and the stories you tell- is that new dress really going to give you an experience you tell your grandkids about? Or would you be better to spend it on trying a new class, or a dinner at the newest pop-up? No one tells stories about the nights they went home to bed - so do something exciting this week!

Sometimes spontaneity can be rewarding.

[![18865910](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2YpFCzeYsMac4McW6Q2wyg/628ad07390d3c0bb5ad4bfea38386708/18865910.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2YpFCzeYsMac4McW6Q2wyg/628ad07390d3c0bb5ad4bfea38386708/18865910.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Everyone's creative in one way or another. Some are just more so than others. Creativity is fed by experience and doing new and exciting things.

wordpressContent.en-GB: I haven't been to a gig for years, well, the last one was the Hamburg Ramones (tribute) in the summer but I don't think that counts as it was just a small thing. I used to go to them quite a lot when I was younger, either seeing screaming rock bands or booking tickets for festivals. Nowadays I just don't seem to think about looking to see who's playing. I only found out that the Parov Stelar Band was coming to Brixton by chance at work. I'd just got into electro swing so once I heard I had no excuse not to book it. [![IMG_1790](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ZBpWeVDkcMKCMwkMAgc4g/f88566e0f73ec752fbf8abcab936dc35/img-1790.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ZBpWeVDkcMKCMwkMAgc4g/f88566e0f73ec752fbf8abcab936dc35/img-1790.jpg) After a cheeky pub dinner we headed into the Brixton O2 arena. Unfortunately we missed the support band The Rochelle (cloak room queues!) but Parov Stelar more than made up for it. You can't beat that buzz that spreads through the room as the band begins to take the stage. We were up dancing and bouncing around the crowd to the music. It was incredible. They played all of my favourite songs including Catgroove, Josephine, Clap your hands, and All night. The encore was a crazy mix of Golden Boy, Libella Swing and Matilda. There was even a moment when, before the tune dropped, the entire Brixton Academy stood still waiting to jump. ![IMG_1806](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7pXneh6EvY8s88yQqGSMEO/33d85f4b027738e51ae01264d55fa3e4/img-1806.jpg) The night ended far too soon for my liking and we were all on a high. I'd forgotten what it was like to stand in front of a band that can't wipe a smile off your face. The whole experience seems like a dream now but one I'd love to repeat. I don't know anyone who I've played Parov Stelar to that doesn't like it. The type of music seems perfect for my wedding; I'd love to have a similar band - I think it's time to start searching!

seoDescription.en-GB: Watching Parov Stelar at the Brixton Academy

wordpressContent.en-GB:
For the past three years Charlie's been taking part in Movember. Each year he tends to take a different style mo. He's doing it all for fun but at the end of the month I'm always quite shocked with how much he manages to raise without shouting about it too much. This year he and his team got £300. [Movember](http://uk.movember.com/) raises awareness and money for testicular cancer. This is all helped by a final push with their gala parties. We went along to one two years ago and didn't really know what to expect. At that time I was working in John Lewis so rushed to get there after my shift. I met Charlie, Rob & Silvia and we all dressed as cowboys. The aim was to dress to suit your mo and wow, some people really went for it! I couldn't believe how good some of the outfits and Mos were. We met a gynaecologist who was a movember rep that had been growing his moustache and it was **giant**! ![469084_10152475888995001_1371573114_o](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3oEQbGgyM0eGo8gqk8qE6Q/518dd6ff34b59c5393d434c88bd0f798/469084-10152475888995001-1371573114-o.jpg)

_With the Gynaecologist and two doctors!_

The venue was at Billingsgate market and as we walked in, a brass band snaked across the room before leading us through curtains up to the stage. There were giant disco balls, dancers and the feeling that anything could happen on that night. [![469009_10152475889760001_1296013493_o](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/30ITzIOJYQ0scgC2GQAKKo/bb42493d7e544bfe96392ec6f0739352/469009-10152475889760001-1296013493-o.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/30ITzIOJYQ0scgC2GQAKKo/bb42493d7e544bfe96392ec6f0739352/469009-10152475889760001-1296013493-o.jpg)   It's no surprise that when this year came around we were really excited to get tickets. Although the venue wasn't as fun (this time in a sports hall in Bethnal Green), the Movember team had gone all out - and so did we. Taking tips from our first year, Charlie and I dressed up as Tonto and Lady Harrington (ish) from The Lone Ranger. Charlie even went as far as putting a dead partridge on his head - sorry in advance!

[![P1030857](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2WkXPDS2dW84MysogEAgkG/764241a58001cf53f788e03cd329f918/p1030857.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2WkXPDS2dW84MysogEAgkG/764241a58001cf53f788e03cd329f918/p1030857.jpg)

During the gala there are various prizes up for grabs such as lamest Mo, Mo of Movember, best Mo bro and Mo sister, best team and best Mo sister. It's no surprise that we were nominated for best Mo bro and Mo sister and got through to the final. Sadly our winning streak ended there after a somewhat embarrassing dance off. Oh well, the rest of the night was amazing and lots of people said they wanted us to win!

[![P1030860](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4VwWR1J8W4G6ceQwaCuW2W/25bb7846d5bf9ad4bd3504a456bf7ad9/p1030860.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4VwWR1J8W4G6ceQwaCuW2W/25bb7846d5bf9ad4bd3504a456bf7ad9/p1030860.jpg)

_We don't look too happy with our nominations! _

Even though I've only been twice, each Movember gala is one of the highlights of my November. It's such a different night to others in the year and is the perfect excuse to pull together a fancy dress outfit and go all out (honestly, anything goes). Until next year Movember!

seoDescription.en-GB: The Movember charity gala and our fancy dress for it.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
We wanted to cook a proper roast dinner today and I fancied something a little different so I reached for our [Leon](http://www.amazon.co.uk/Leon-Naturally-Fast-Henry-Dimbleby/dp/1840915560/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1417376729&sr=1-2&keywords=leon+cookbook) cookbook. I think Charlie's grandparents bought this for him for christmas one year but it's really handy to have. Whenever I'm bored of the normal things I make I reach for this. It has pretty standard food but each one is slightly more exciting. We've made quite a few bits out of the book so far. There's a recipe with 100 cloves of garlic that I really want to try out. ![IMG_5292](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ahoT2zb4eQiomsmKcy0e8/2f9a70f2ceabadeec5e83179a15ea91f/img-5292.jpg) This time though, we had made green beans to go with smoked gammon and roast potatoes - it was perfect. They would also go really well with chicken breast or even as a meal by themselves. **Green beans with tapenade, tomatoes and garlic**

*   Cut the ends off the green beans and slice them slightly (just to make it look interesting)
*   Boil them in salted water until they're tender and drain
*   Sprinkle a little olive oil and 2 teaspoons of tapenade and lay on a plate
*   Fry off some roughly chopped garlic and leave to one side (for the top layer)
*   Chop tomatoes and fry them in olive oil (I also threw in some pine nuts at this point but this isn't on the recipe)
*   Season with salt and pepper and 2 teaspoons of tapenade
*   Scatter this on top of the green beans
*   Finish by throwing the garlic on top

  [![IMG_5288](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1tw7410SlSCUayUuwY2CEw/842a7aeba37ca5c92b5484b8d8d469cb/img-5288.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1tw7410SlSCUayUuwY2CEw/842a7aeba37ca5c92b5484b8d8d469cb/img-5288.jpg) Yummy! We didn't know what tapenade was and there didn't seem to be any in the shops so I made some myself. It was really easy and surprisingly tasty. We now have a whole jar of it in the fridge for next time too! [![IMG_5300](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6lMq65LzGM8AaOs06ak8so/0c2e9b1f55e25bf14ee80219c8a7fd95/img-5300.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6lMq65LzGM8AaOs06ak8so/0c2e9b1f55e25bf14ee80219c8a7fd95/img-5300.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My green bean recipe - making your greens into more of a focus in a meal.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Excitement begins to build up throughout December time as the lights get turned on, trees get decorated and the Christmas jumpers appear. I love Christmas time. It's a great excuse to switch off your everyday life and spend time with your family.We have a set routine on Christmas morning: wake up, have breakfast, line up in age order and enter the lounge for present time! I love surprises so the moment when I get to give people their presents and see their reactions is always fun. Since going to a talk on [Suffocation](http://vikibell.com/creativity/ "Creativity") last year I've been asking myself more and more the reason behind the gifts.

I've noticed that there is increasingly less reason to buy a physical object for someone. No longer do you need a walkman, CDs, DVDs, camera, notepad or map - you have a phone. Yet every year for Christmas people find themselves trailing around the shops looking for gifts to package up. This is where gift guides can sometimes be useful. But are they doing more harm than good? When I've been really stuck I've glanced across at gift guides and felt like they are just an easy way out. I found myself trying to fit the person to the gift rather than the other way around. Each person is different and the stereotypical 18-25 year old male gift won't suit both my brother and Fiancé. This year I've decided to think of it differently so I thought I'd share my present planning techniques...

*   What do they like to **do** - is there anything that relates?
    *   Hobbies - do they need new equipment?
    *   Clubs - a new book for book club?
    *   Drinking - a cocktail book?
*   What **age** are they at - will they begin doing something new?
    *   University - something nice for their new room?
    *   Driving - a guide to driving? New mix tape?
    *   New job - a desk ornament?
    *   New children - photo frames?
*   Have they **been anywhere** interesting lately?
    *   Maybe you could get them a T-shirt from a gig they went to?
    *   Print photos from a holiday?
*   Have they not been anywhere interesting lately?
    *   Treat them to **something different** to their every day life?
        *   Spa
        *   Comedy night
        *   A tasting
        *   A new class
*   What do you enjoy **doing** together?
    *   Try something new together?
*   **Where** do they work?
    *   Do they need something special to help them with their job?
    *   Could you get them something funny to do with it?
*   What makes them **laugh**?
    *   If you can't think of something to get them can you at least **make them laugh** on Christmas day?
        *   This is where silly hats come in!
*   Is there anything you can add to the day?
    *   Maybe some wine for your Christmas lunch?
*   What can you make?
    *   People always appreciate the **thought and effort** that goes into something you create
        *   You don't have to be an artist to create something beautiful it's all in the story behind it

Finally, **positive memories** are always amazing to get as a gift. Be that a photo of that time or a chance to relive it through something similar it will always be appreciated. This is my take on buying gifts. It gives me a good insight into the person and what I imagine they will like. Hope it helps with your Christmas shopping too! [![IMG_9098](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1THaaiG7Mwm2os4ci4CemS/9c827c8f17a91b286fe49d0fc8dcb0e3/img-9098.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1THaaiG7Mwm2os4ci4CemS/9c827c8f17a91b286fe49d0fc8dcb0e3/img-9098.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My guide to gifts and the questions you should be asking yourself when planning a present.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Sometimes a change of scenery can be the perfect escape. This is one of the reasons I love going up to Suffolk. I've introduced Suffolk in a previous [post](http://vikibell.com/suffolk/ "Suffolk") but be prepared to hear more about it...

[![IMG_5360](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/38aGXTN19SC4iE28QEQy4m/0c017079bc0b99f26112593c342ac85c/img-5360.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/38aGXTN19SC4iE28QEQy4m/0c017079bc0b99f26112593c342ac85c/img-5360.jpg)

We'd booked to meet a wedding caterer on Saturday morning near Bury St Edmunds so we were up early and on the road from Southend. We really got on well with the caterers and had nothing but praise for them. I'm really hoping that we've found the right person for us but lets wait until the tasting to decide for sure. As the frost started to lift and the day begun, we headed straight for the Cottage to light the fires and plan our day. I always find going away for a weekend difficult as I try to make the most out of every moment and seem to forget that I'm there to relax! So it's no surprise that we ended up walking into Aldeburgh, which took an hour, and walking back via dinner in The Dolphin.

[![Suffolk](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/SK0Jyw9VcW4GQ6MaSkOeM/708d175e4cb4c9a565592edbc6d3f0f1/img-5354.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/SK0Jyw9VcW4GQ6MaSkOeM/708d175e4cb4c9a565592edbc6d3f0f1/img-5354.jpg)

[![Suffolk](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6mbz7qhhxSuqymAwE0MKm0/c14986b57965da0eb14e9e4dddaff0a9/img-5372.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/SK0Jyw9VcW4GQ6MaSkOeM/708d175e4cb4c9a565592edbc6d3f0f1/img-5354.jpg)

Whilst in Aldeburgh we did a bit of Christmas shopping and had a cheeky drink at The Cross Keys. There's nothing like sitting by a warm fire having a drink during the winter. Of course I chose Aspalls as it's local, the same reason Charlie had an Adnams.

![Suffolk](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/Rinvr6APgQsUyeuoaGmEk/7d729ce46722444379c4eed4193b4a08/img-5388.jpg)

As we walked to the Dolphin for dinner we were amazed by the reflection of the moon on the sea. Of course I whipped out my camera and tried to capture it but the photos don't really show how bright it was. The shadows we cast were as defined as the ones we get with sunlight - it was crazy how bright it was. I think I'm too used to the light pollution of London! [![Suffolk](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3gUvHweMTKy0GyCsswY6CW/7a0f6e53eddf45bacc66851a839d86a9/img-5401.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3gUvHweMTKy0GyCsswY6CW/7a0f6e53eddf45bacc66851a839d86a9/img-5401.jpg) [![Suffolk](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2HJuqm38VGUmaSeGSSGewm/10ae72bd8e00e9877a44bc118e4e75e1/img-5413.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2HJuqm38VGUmaSeGSSGewm/10ae72bd8e00e9877a44bc118e4e75e1/img-5413.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A weekend in Suffolk and why I love going there so much.

wordpressContent.en-GB: There's something almost magical about Camden Market on the run up to Christmas. I always find myself visiting at this time of year searching around for some unusual gifts.  I'd planned out my Christmas presents, using my [gift guide](http://vikibell.com/my-guide-to-gifts/ "My guide to gifts") of course, and set off bright an early. Unfortunately I was forgetting that Camden doesn't really wake up until lunch time. This gave me a chance to have a look round as the stalls were getting set up. I don't think I'd been to a market whilst it was setting up before but it was really interesting to see the routines the stall owners had. They all knew each other and were chatting and laughing together. Some were even singing and dancing along to the radio. Overall I got the feeling that they loved what they were doing and were really looking forward to the day. I wrote this post in the corner of Ruby Duck, a small coffee place in the heart of one of the markets. A bunch of people came in and I could hear all their excitement over their gift ideas. One lady had bought a present and was obviously over joyed with it. As I've mentioned before, I don't see much point of a gift unless your excited to give it. Countless times this Christmas I've had easy options for gifts suggested to me such as CDs or clothing but I've opted out for more of a challenge. What I've bought it still top secret but lets just say that I've thought outside the box and I'm really excited to give everyone their gifts. I'd really recommend visiting Camden Market during a week day. The crowds can get a bit much of a weekend, especially during school holidays. There's all sorts to discover around the stalls but I personally love the choice of jewellery on offer. There's a great stand that sells crystals and stones from around the world in the top of the Market Hall called [Jewellery of the Earth](http://www.camdenlockmarket.com/shops/stalls/jewellery-of-the-earth/) - the stall owner is really lovely too and full of great advice.   [![coffee](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7arCru5aRqCEgU4YgUyicY/3c70cfcb44847e506625777f3320d368/coffee.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7arCru5aRqCEgU4YgUyicY/3c70cfcb44847e506625777f3320d368/coffee.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Christmas present hunting around Camden market and why it's such a great place to explore

wordpressContent.en-GB: ![panarama](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4NE52vZwDYK8ksyGIUmaOU/ec764fd9782b1691c2f703563198afaa/panarama.jpg) Family walks are always a thing over Christmas, wether thats because you're over stuffed with turkey and other goodies or due to the vast amount of alcohol consumed during the run up to Christmas. Whatever your reason it's a good excuse to get outside and see the frost on the ground and feel the chill in the air. Usually I go on a big Boxing day walk with Charlie's family and friends. We all head towards Hadleigh castle and and go in a big loop back across the sea wall. Of course there's a pause in the middle for mulled wine and minced pies! After skipping the walk this year (we were sleeping!) I was keen to get outside. ![IMG_2240](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4awLGa626QUweqIimsMuWA/8746e59290277262fd394e21ea765489/img-2240.jpg) My dad is training to do a [big walk](https://bellyswalk.wordpress.com/) in the Sahara at March so has been forcing himself on three/four/five hour walks over the holidays and this was my chance to go with him. I pieced together some sort of walking kit from my brother's jacket, mum's shoes, dad's scarf and Charlie's hat - very prepared I know, and we set off at the crack of dawn. You can see our route below - I only downloaded the app a quarter of the way into the walk! There should actually be a line joining up the route making it about 11/12 miles. [![IMG_2298](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2bpnf7I12Yqgg6MyywkSMq/8960d1641a479c0ad48c768228123735/img-2298.png)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2bpnf7I12Yqgg6MyywkSMq/8960d1641a479c0ad48c768228123735/img-2298.png) The best thing about walking in the morning is that you get to see the sun come up and everything seems to come to life. We didn't see any other people until nearly the end of the walk which was when we were in a more popular forest. [![IMG_2213](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1t4pBVhThiGW440c6mGYSc/0a41b2eee62e73449e645e56c2aaca38/img-2213.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1t4pBVhThiGW440c6mGYSc/0a41b2eee62e73449e645e56c2aaca38/img-2213.jpg) I think I was most excited to see goats - I didn't know there was goats just roaming around a field in Brentwood! There was also some sheep, a horse and plenty of squirrels to be seen too. [![IMG_2229](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/HFOr5DXHGKqkwoauM2kAW/47a51f2cd7234bf504a14cfe244ff4f3/img-2229.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/HFOr5DXHGKqkwoauM2kAW/47a51f2cd7234bf504a14cfe244ff4f3/img-2229.jpg) This is the top of Jury Hill which has amazing views. Apparently you can see the Shard from it sometimes. I could just about make out the M25 and A127 through the mist but the view was great. I took the photos on my phone as I didn't want to carry my SLR - I had to be quick though else the Nike running app would tell me off for pausing! [![IMG_2275](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2Do0bkoKvimoYm6UUEOQSS/7c6ef94269a276f6cd404704e31cd13f/img-2275.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2Do0bkoKvimoYm6UUEOQSS/7c6ef94269a276f6cd404704e31cd13f/img-2275.jpg) I real enjoyed the walk and want to make sure I spare some time in the new year to go on others. My last walk was an 8 eight round trip to the pub for lunch, in Dunwich, last January! Have you been on a walk this Christmas?

seoDescription.en-GB: A Post-Christmas walk around Essex and seeing the countryside

wordpressContent.en-GB: Now Christmas and New Year has passed I plan to get cracking on the wedding planning. There's plenty to do before July and the more I do now the longer I have to sit back and enjoy the run up to the day. What's caught my interest is the traditions and how they have changed over the years, the main one obviously being the lack of people getting married in a church. For my own reasons I've chosen to skip the church part and have opted for a civil ceremony in a beautiful country home - [Glemham Hall](http://www.glemhamhall.co.uk/). The grounds and the house itself are beautiful, it's a typical old country home thats got character and history behind it. The reason the house means so much to Charlie and I is that it's something we always recall when we are driving up to the Cottage. It's the place that means we're almost there and the last landmark I remember when we drive home. Of course since we've booked it every time we drive past we wave like a pair of lunatics! I've set this weekend aside for designing the invitations. Seeing as both Charlie and I have an art/ design background I don't see why we shouldn't be doing these ourselves. Not only does it give the personalised touch but it means we can have them exactly how we want them. Well, just as soon as we work out how we want them! I started off with a quick Google around invitations and then a read up of a few wedding blogs. [Rock My Wedding](http://www.rockmywedding.co.uk/) had a great [article](http://www.rockmywedding.co.uk/is-traditional-wedding-stationery-outdated/) about the use of stationery and whether it's become outdated. Seeing as Charlie and I are planning to setup a website as a blog/ place to get information about the wedding, I thought this was particularly interesting. As we move forward in our digital age where do we draw the line at being paperless? When I was at uni I loved getting post. Nan and Grandad would send me a postcard from each country they went to (you can image how many I got if they were on a cruise!) and my little cousins would send me drawings. With an event as big and important as a wedding you would expect a paper invite through the post - right? Well according to Rock My Wedding there's a fair amount of people who are now sending out their invitations via email in infographic style images. As we move away from paper I can see this trend taking off, not only is it cheaper, it's easier to collate all the RSVPs and keep a digital record of the invitees' data for any future events. Saying this, I don't see it being an option for us, I just can't move away from how excited I get when I get an invitation through the post and I want to allow my guests to have this too. An email invitation just doesn't compare, you haven't spent the time to get it printed, folded, written the address, stamped the envelope, post it etc. and when you get 100s of emails a day what's special about another one inviting you to something? [![IMG_2345.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1v6vfcDvsEAMWwOO8yIcgK/0571da1a307b22a7cd8d3243baf76e5f/img-2345jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1v6vfcDvsEAMWwOO8yIcgK/0571da1a307b22a7cd8d3243baf76e5f/img-2345jpg.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Wedding planning and how the traditions have changed over the years, the main one obviously being the lack of people getting married in a church.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
So this post maybe unleashing my inner geek to some of you but it doesn't even scratch the surface of what's going on tech wise.

Black mirror fans may have seen the episode where the characters had chips in their eyes and could record everything they see. There was also the episode recently with a clone in another reality. Well, all of this could be closer than we think. A few years ago Charlie mentioned that we may one day all be plugged into machines living in fictional world. We would have no need to move as we'd get all our nutrients from the machines - sort of like The Matrix. Of course this pretty much terrified me, what if we were living this now only we didn't know? What if I'd chosen to play out this game of life which feels like ages and when I die I'm given options of other games to play, maybe I'd like to be a dragon or a prince? Charlie also mentioned that the futurologists were predicting that in our lifetime we would have infinity life so we shall have to wait and see if that part comes true.

We've been so scared of living in a big brother world that most people are now in denial. After going to a talk this week around technology, I realise that it's a lot further on than most people know. We can predict what's happening but there is so much data around right now that we can find out pretty much anything. Think about it - you have your phone with you 24/7, that phone has GPS, knows all your information though Facebook, Twitter etc and that phone can tell advertisers where you will be using predictions of your monthly/ weekly routines. It will know that I get the Victoria line to work as I get internet on the underground but this knowledge will eventually allow my phone to message me to show me delays, flash sales/ discounts nearby, and people around me during my route. Think about it in terms of the O2 priority app that tells you deals that day near you, whats to stop that then messaging you to let you know your favourite burrito shop is handing out free burritos? The data gathered by using that app allows O2 to gain a profile of you around your eating/ shopping/ entertainment habits so can market to you better, perhaps with personalised phone contracts and deals.

We've got Philips hue lightbulbs in our flat and have named each one by which room it's it. Things like [IFTTT](https://ifttt.com/) (if this then that) can allow us to make theses bulbs smarter and connected to other products. We already have an app which means we can control them remotely - so I could turn them on as I leave work so the house is light when I get back. But we could easily use IFTTT to make them smarter and start picking up our habits so they would know to turn the lights on as we got near home for example. It could easily tie in with our phone GPS to see where each of us are and make sure our house looks like it's occupied at all times. It could even connect to a smart lock like [Lockatron](https://lockitron.com/) so that you could allow a visitor into the house and turn on the lights for them all remotely.

The smarter these devices get the more opportunity there is for brands to market themselves. There's no reason why the data our lights pick up couldn't link to our ovens so they could preheat of us or suggest meals we could make by learning the usual times we like to eat and how long we have to prepare them by this time. They could become security devices and change around whilst we are away, flash when someone is at the door or we get a call, or change colour to reflect our moods by judging us on our social posts.

![IMG_1748](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ey72OUWhOMeiAk8CoGqm0/6637a5eb71f653b99d7e93593c5f27d5/img-1748.jpg)

There are plenty of interesting projects out thee cropping up all the time. Places like Kickstarter and Indigogo have a whole array of interesting projects. We got these the other week from [Mipow](http://www.playbulb.com/en/playbulb-candle-bluetooth-smart-led-flameless-candle.html) and they're LED candles. All you need to do is tap them on the table or blow them out to turn them on and off. Just a quirky little gimmick to liven up dinnertime!

As with most things in life the opportunities for tech are endless you just need to know what there is out there and how to use it.

seoDescription.en-GB: Releasing my inner geek and writing about tech, where it's leading us and how it impacts our home now.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I went swimming after work earlier this week. It was my first swim of 2015 and it's inspired me to get back into a swimming routine. It seemed to be the perfect thing to get rid of my January blues except for the fact I couldn't stop. After completing my usual routine I kept on swimming until I realised I'd done 120 lengths, my eyes were bloodshot from having no goggles and my legs were like jelly! As I swam I thought about the unspoken rules of the swimming pool, I've listed them below for you keen fish out there...

*   Don't just stand and chat at the bottom of the lanes, either move to a more open section or get swimming
*   If you're resting at the end of the pool, make sure you keep out the way of swimmers
*   Switch lanes if your going to go slower. No one likes to be stuck behind someone when they have a routine to do
*   If you are in the right lane but doing a slower stroke, let the person going fast go ahead of you at the end of your length
*   Don't overtake unless you have the space - I watched two swimmers bash into each other because one was trying to overtake a slower swimmer
*   Don't zig zag down the lane, stick to your side and swim straight
*   Don't make eye contact with lifeguards. It's either looks like your drowning or trying to chat them up (or both)
*   Speaking of which don't make eye contact with anyone in the changing room ESPECIALLY when 80% of them are wondering around naked
*   If you do insist on getting completely starkers in the changing rooms try to keep it to a minimum or in one place
*   Butterfly - no you can't do it and no matter how hard you try you look like a drowning seal. Not even worth attempting
*   And finally don't pee in the pool!

[![P1060065](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5zwR6XlmU0me2UwQ24eyIe/e62e24b435ba858f604aecdadd18d0a4/p1060065.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5zwR6XlmU0me2UwQ24eyIe/e62e24b435ba858f604aecdadd18d0a4/p1060065.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: What should or shouldn't you be doing in a swimming pool

wordpressContent.en-GB: Being ginger is always a little difficult unless you fully embrace it. Think about it - how many true gingers do you see each day? I bet most people can think of one redhead they know straight away, their token ginger friend. When I was at school I used to get vaguely bullied for being ginger - nothing too harsh just negative comments about my hair colour making me feel like I was ugly. It was only when I got older and turned into the slightly crazier version of me that I fully embraced it. This was about the time I was walking around with black streaks through my hair and styling it similarly to Russell Brand; someone even tried to insult me by calling me his name once. ![ginger](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ZIZX81mZqwcmQSoMG2WSc/edb712beb9d619ed32c9eeb00f36a4fc/ssl21520jpg.jpg) Since that day I've had plenty of colours through my hair: pink, orange, purple, blue, blonde and black, but I've always refused to fully dye it and loose my 'orange glow'. Unfortunately though this in inevitable, as I get older my hair gets darker so now I have to face comments telling me I'm not ginger anymore. Brands even skim over the redheads. I spotted an email recently from Wahanda which was encouraging you to dye your hair brown or blonde. What about ginger? I know we're only a small percent of the population but thousands of people dye their hair red - why wouldn't you include that in your newsletter? ![ginger](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/12J0CIS1JsIwsgAoQiUWCe/7fb2c3d0447a10c4d62b956b12dc57ab/sam-1194jpg.jpg) I think it can be a struggle for kids growing up with red hair, they always stand out and always look different which is prime material for bullying. I personally love the look of ginger hair, whether that's ginger, auburn, red or whatever shade you have. It's something different that you should be proud of. And so here's a photo of 15 year old me, around the stage I started appreciating my hair, ignoring all the ginger hatred. ![Ginger](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3WsAqUf9sIYaICqQYCYOKO/52be3aaf1a3ac9f5ce0e28920b9b0977/ssl21442jpg.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: I love being ginger but it wasn't always the case.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Who doesn't love Rocky Road? It's packed full of sugar and the perfect thing to nibble on. I made it a few times last year and noticed that I'd managed to stock up on all the ingredients before Christmas but never made any. On a dull Sunday it seemed like the perfect thing to do. I tend to make up the amounts of ingredients as I go so feel free to add in more or less of something. The recipe was originally given to me by India. ![IMG_2472.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6j9Hc6snEQ8IW2UkIMyEAG/566032e32de5f33e1d8ef78272b7366a/img-2472jpg.jpg)

*   Take 2 big bars of milk chocolate and melt over simmering water with a lump of butter and 3 spoonfuls of honey - you can also add extra sugar if you fancy but that really isn't necessary!
*   You can substitute the chocolate bars for any others you have in the house like mars bars, toffee crisp etc. but be careful as the consistency of the melted chocolate will change. I've used easter eggs and chocolates from a tin of celebrations before so experiment!
*   While the chocolate is melting smash up some digestives
*   Use about half a large pack of marshmallows and add half of them into the chocolate once it melts, mix in the rest of them with the biscuits. This will make some of them more gooey than others
*   Once you've done this pour the melted chocolate over the biscuits and mix it all together
*   Put a sheet of baking paper over a dish (this helps cleaning later) and pour the mixture over. You want it to be about 10cm thick so make sure it doesn't spread out too much
*   For the melted marshmallows on top just add some more from the pack and pop this on a low heat in the over for about 10 minutes
*   After this time use a palette knife to smudge them on top
*   Then take the whole mixture and let it cool on the side over night OR pop it in the fridge for a few hours
*   Cut it into little portions and enjoy the sugar rush!

![IMG_2475.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1VoQlEwVtmY26qOYkmEuEk/b9ff1bc015ca74cb79f71e5b4d1cd827/img-2475jpg.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Who doesn't love Rocky Road? It's packed full of sugar and the perfect thing to nibble on. Here's a bit of a different recipe.

wordpressContent.en-GB: On Thursday we went out for dinner Côte Brasserie in Camden. We chose this place as we wanted to have a slightly nicer meal than usual. Oh we were wrong! Before I describe our dinner I need to point out that as soon as we sat down I got my first visual migraine so the evening was slightly tainted. ![IMG_2525.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2xrDy1hEFeaamMSQAyamsq/bdf59f3e9a0cdb6ececa60d53d03a0fd/img-2525jpg.jpg) We were given bread and olives as we ordered which was lovely. We usually ask for balsamic vinegar with it but it was so fresh we didn't want to take away the taste. The mussels we chose to start with were by far the highlight of the meal. It was either the fact that we hadn't had them for ages or their freshness but they were really tasty. ![IMG_2533.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4O0j95vixqQKYagUWSo8yq/1005860f894efcb3a6d86a8778e1c14b/img-2533jpg.jpg) The main course was a bit of a let down as we'd expected it to be amazing after the previous food. We'd ordered steak with bernaise sauce and chicken in a mushroom sauce. The plan was, as usual, to split both and share the sides. The chicken was well cooked but both pieces of meat just tasted very standard and cheap. The meal would have been okay if I'd been better company! I'd had migraines before but never anything visual. I could see all these lines across my vision but had no headache at all. By the time the main course came I was finding it really difficult to remember the easiest words. I kept trying to mime them out - it's safe to say I'm pretty bad at charades. We must have looked hilarious to everyone else in the restaurant. By the time we left I'd got my sight back but from then until afternoon the next day everything's quite a blur. Not something I want to repeat in a hurry!   Maybe we'll attempt to go out for dinner again soon...

seoDescription.en-GB: A spontaneous dinner out at the Côte Brasserie in Camden

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Everyone has those moments in life when their happiness take a dip. As I dragged my feet, wandering across the platform in Victoria Station I realised that I haven't quite been as happy as I should be recently and that they only person who will fix that is going to be me. There isn't some sort of happiness fairy that breezes along and sprinkles a little fairy dust on you - unfortunately. What’s important is that you focus on the smaller things that make you smile – after all promotions, engagements and big life moments don’t come along that often. Think about all the small things in your day or life that are going well, the easy wins. Focus on these and the happiness will begin to grow. As I begun thinking about the smaller wins and moments that bring a smile to my face, I started writing them down and felt a lot better about everything. This is far from finished but it's a good way to take a look at everything positive in your life. These are the things which make me happy...

*   Memories
*   Food
*   Happy people
*   Getting a seat on the tube
*   Kittens and cats
*   Sunshine
*   Reading a good book
*   Being creative in some way
*   Painting
*   Drawing
*   Cooking
*   Photography
*   People laughing
*   Waking up in a good mood
*   Being ridiculously silly because, well, because
*   Those days or nights when you don’t plan anything and they just evolve
*   Surprises
*   Brainstorming new ideas for something pointless
*   Building the fires in Suffolk
*   Suffolk – generally
*   When you get to the platform and the tube pulls in
*   Seeing old friends
*   Making new friends
*   Fancy dress
*   Colourful stuff

  [![Happiness](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5MfjFaUuRi6kQumciWu68c/5a80b02e788e7bc30cdaee2b7be847cf/happiness.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5MfjFaUuRi6kQumciWu68c/5a80b02e788e7bc30cdaee2b7be847cf/happiness.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: What happiness means to me

title.en-GB: Ukulele playing at the Queen of Hoxton

wordpressContent.en-GB: There isn't too much to say in this post. It pretty much does what it says on the tin. You turn up at the Queen of Hoxton to be greeted by the sound of ukuleles being strummed by various degrees of skill. Grab one out the box and try your hand at being a musical maestro. It's safe to say I won't be taking the stage anytime soon. I decided that sticking to a C or sometimes D note was best whilst trying to stay in time. Enough people were good so at least we managed to hear what the song should sound like. [![IMG_2829.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/72KX4P25DUecuYCs4OOYQu/9cbac57009f28139426aa92ea29d724c/img-2829jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/72KX4P25DUecuYCs4OOYQu/9cbac57009f28139426aa92ea29d724c/img-2829jpg.jpg)   There's something really special about the Queen of Hoxton. Last year we went along to this giant tipi on the roof and a big open fire where they made various burgers like wild boar. After we ate paper and pens were handed out. Puzzled, we took some and waited for our instructions. It turned out we were to play that game, you know that game, the one where you turn the paper draw something and pass it along to the next person that draw something else. Anyway we all spent the evening drawing very peculiar looking monsters. [![IMG_9458](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2qFkCLQta8KU2uqKkouka8/4448b6a5f020f898aa6fb3e50f49ed38/img-9458.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2qFkCLQta8KU2uqKkouka8/4448b6a5f020f898aa6fb3e50f49ed38/img-9458.jpg) At the moment you can take up Ukulele lessons at the [Queen of Hoxton](http://queenofhoxton.com/) each Monday - but best to double check on their Twitter first as I'm not too sure how long it goes on for!

seoDescription.en-GB: My first time playing a Ukulele at the Queen of Hoxton

wordpressContent.en-GB: To bet the winter blues I headed off to Tenerife for a quick getaway with India (Charlie's sister and my soon to be sister-in-law). The sun was shining and the pool called to us. [![IMG_6072](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4LmmCIhJ0kWaOS2WeoYCmc/bd756bf5d4a9c24c76e6aea2b0c5741c/img-6072.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4LmmCIhJ0kWaOS2WeoYCmc/bd756bf5d4a9c24c76e6aea2b0c5741c/img-6072.jpg) With me planning a wedding and her in her final year of uni we were under strict instructions to relax and relax we did. We had lazy days by the pool and beach along with a massage and elaborate dinners. Of course we may have treated ourselves to a cocktail or two! [![11035473_10155287565215621_3679693147599596914_n](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4kU6DPZU3SGO8YYI4QgySy/531df28859b95c14aac32abb2eb77c49/11035473-10155287565215621-3679693147599596914-n.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4kU6DPZU3SGO8YYI4QgySy/531df28859b95c14aac32abb2eb77c49/11035473-10155287565215621-3679693147599596914-n.jpg) Thirty years ago my grandparents made the wise decision to buy an apartment here. Tenerife wasn't the tourist destination it is today. In fact our complex was next to a banana plantation, now it's in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Las Americas and Costa Adeje! Tenerife has always been special to me, I came here at less than a year old. It's where I learnt to swim, my first beach holiday and where I made my first holiday friends. The apartment is the perfect (and cheap!) holiday for anyone looking to get away from the dull skies of England and top up on their vitamin D. ![996110_10155287561825621_2967861965285434618_n](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4mXeqtu4ms2CQUMOGiSY62/7043c7c20662aad65862a9465d201310/996110-10155287561825621-2967861965285434618-n.jpg) I've got so many stories of my time here as a kid, as I've probably bored India of during our week! These has been added to through my four trips here since being a 'grownup'. I've been here with Charlie, friends and now India. If you're considering coming to Tenerife for a holiday one of my recommendations would be the trip up to Mount Tiede - I went on my first visit with Charlie and it's amazing to see the island mapped out below you and hear the history through some fantastic guides. [![DSCF9891](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5BMVR4zWr64OOeK4YoyQKw/50e32ae5acc623b54e3aec42217bf106/dscf9891.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5BMVR4zWr64OOeK4YoyQKw/50e32ae5acc623b54e3aec42217bf106/dscf9891.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A cheeky week away in Tenerife.

wordpressContent.en-GB: As if organising a wedding isn't stressful enough Charlie and I decided that we're going to buy a house. As of the 18th July our new life will begin, we will be married together and live in a place we actually own. We've been house hunting for a while and I actually quite enjoy looking and seeing everything that's available. I like exploring the new areas we can live and wondering where our local pub of food shop will be. We knew we wanted to be based around North London and were really lucky when we found the place we've bought. Just a stones throw away from Caledonian Road tube station it's perfect. Here's us and Charlie's mum having a great time in the new bathroom! [![IMG_2566](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6qO22gUajuQcEuO6u0OGUo/54bf0c6e4d60d7f2941d10e2b44b18b8/img-2566.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6qO22gUajuQcEuO6u0OGUo/54bf0c6e4d60d7f2941d10e2b44b18b8/img-2566.jpg) Of course being the two creative people we are we were never going to buy anywhere easy. This place definitely needs a lick of paint and touch of love. Hello Pinterest! I've been plugging in all sorts into our [new home board](https://uk.pinterest.com/vikiibell/future-home/) and it'll be really interesting to see how this inspires us to decorate. I've been reading up on the best ways to layout a room and found this Feng Shui [infographic](http://www.sheknows.com/home-and-gardening/articles/1050539/how-to-feng-shui-your-home-infographic) really helpful. I'm not too sure I want a yellow kitchen but a bold statement entrance area sounds amazing. [![aceec255d5cf840a65031a2bc71eaf2d](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5dOJ0rZvewg8YygqWo0UOq/8c300d264134c008cefd59a0e09bdb24/aceec255d5cf840a65031a2bc71eaf2d.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5dOJ0rZvewg8YygqWo0UOq/8c300d264134c008cefd59a0e09bdb24/aceec255d5cf840a65031a2bc71eaf2d.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: We spent ages looking for our new house to buy and finally have found one both within our price range, area and that we can make into somewhere we love.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
When I finished uni I told myself that I wanted to live in London. I wanted it to be the place I called my home. Every so often I need to pause and remind myself that I've done that, I live in London and I need to make the most of it! It may just be me having an _I love London_ moment but have you taken the time recently to look at your surroundings and really appreciate the beauty and history of it all?
![IMG_3760.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2vWDQtmiCwSGO4I6oMYAge/c8f058bf7ee186b424eb84e2a45951f0/img-3760jpg.jpg)
Last night I decided to walk an extra station before getting the tube home. Once I started I couldn't stop and ended up walking the hour and a half to home. My walk took me from Victoria through Green Park, across Mayfair and through Camden.
It was a sunny evening and I just kept day dreaming and listening out to the various sounds I could hear. I love the little snippets of history that you hear about these places from passing strangers. One was saying about the previous owners of a building and what it had been used for years ago; another mentioned an accident that happened with a window pane. I'd love to know more facts about the areas I live in and be able to tell others how a building has changed hands over the years or what happened on certain streets.
Everywhere looked glorious through the low shining sun and I kept pausing to take photos. I love that I can take the time out to have a walk across London, it's so much nicer than getting on a sweaty packed tube! Im going to aim to walk home more often during the summer. It doesn't take long out of your day and you feel really good afterwards. It certainly feels a lot better than coming straight back to watch Netflix! 
 [![IMG_3764.JPG](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1UG3dCQcvyGU8Usq88gSgs/b22fac397d6ba1888efce66051ede2b3/img-3764jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1UG3dCQcvyGU8Usq88gSgs/b22fac397d6ba1888efce66051ede2b3/img-3764jpg.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Walking home from Victoria to North London and all the sights you can see.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
After hearing a lot about the comedy venue, [The Miller](http://www.themiller.co.uk/), we decided to head down there on Friday night. From the website it looks like it offers a lot and has quite a few nights on from comedy to gigs.
They have a fantastic choice in craft beers and ciders and their food menu was super tempting with its pulled pork burger and chilli fries. Drinks in hand we headed upstairs. Every Friday Hoopla Improv put on a night where various acts perform, at the end they open up the stage for the audience to take a turn. We were greeted with party rings and hats, we didn't realise it was one of their acts, Music Box's 5th birthday!
[![IMG_3826](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5lTEHBVz5SUwEwoiaOcyc8/77a672d06d5a98b0c13688a28bd22e89/img-3826.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5lTEHBVz5SUwEwoiaOcyc8/77a672d06d5a98b0c13688a28bd22e89/img-3826.jpg)
The nights theme was musical improv and, after we'd warmed up, the first act begun. I'd never watched improv before and it was hard to believe they were making it up in the spot, especially when they just burst into song. The act lasted the whole of the first half but was broken up into a number of sketches. The trick with improv (or so I'm told) is to know when to end the sketch.
The second act saw three girls perform and I was amazed at how simple they made it look to slip into different characters. The third act of the night was Music Box. They usually perform with a couple of them on the stage but they decided that for their big night they'd do it with all 14 of them - interesting! Improv always calls for the audience to name a situation, the first we had was _Hell in Basildon_ (!!) which ended up as a love story.
[![IMG_3850](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3PrqqwttIQiOmMO6Y8QGc8/ecad85fe13ec8ab8a7294ef57d8b203d/img-3850.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3PrqqwttIQiOmMO6Y8QGc8/ecad85fe13ec8ab8a7294ef57d8b203d/img-3850.jpg)
Each sketch lasted about 5-10 minutes which was just enough time for a plot to develop. I think my favourite part was when someone asked for a sword and a woman jumped out waving her arms stating that she was indeed a flaming sword. She then had to stand with her arms in the air for the rest of the act - the point that she looked nothing like a sword was just ridiculous funny.
[![IMG_3852](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4lKZ49NNCoIyWGEGi0Y2ka/4c3bc4eea9b9a6e417bbd249f4f807db/img-3852.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4lKZ49NNCoIyWGEGi0Y2ka/4c3bc4eea9b9a6e417bbd249f4f807db/img-3852.jpg)
After the final sketch we had another drinks break and then it was time for the audience to take a turn. Names were picked at random from a list at the back so you had no idea who you were working with. From the feel of it a lot of people in the improv scene go along to these nights for a chance to be involved and see others perform - which is why we were there. Since January Charlie had been going to a class each week and was now on his 'level two' so wanted to see what the social scene was like. With a little encouragement he signed himself up. At first he wasn't sure about the musical part as that's something he hadn't done before but if you don't try it you don't know.
[![IMG_3885](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/X7ry2YJtmwyyqgqYO2McI/93e2bc65036fdd1fee46946e30be6241/img-3885.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/X7ry2YJtmwyyqgqYO2McI/93e2bc65036fdd1fee46946e30be6241/img-3885.jpg)
Turns out he's funny! The theme for his sketch was meeting in a toilet so obviously it got a bit weird but then it turned out that Charlie was a poltergeist who was haunting the place. I thought the four of them worked really well together as they were each there to make the others better. I really enjoyed my first experience of improv and thought the Miller was a great venue for it. Everyone was really friendly and in such a good mood for a laugh. If you find yourself around London Bridge on a Friday or Saturday night make sure you pop in.
![IMG_3907](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/WStKAuxIoEcayS86mqeY8/46ee40ee9c4368f381be40deb9401f7a/img-3907.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Improv night at the Miller in London Bridge.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
We've finally moved into our new home. I was a little upset to leave behind Tufnell Park but we really aren't too far away and I'm excited to be in a new area. When we moved in we've had non stop visitors. The first night we had pizza (and champagne) but then hadn't quite moved our bed over so had to walk back to our old home!
[![IMG_4439](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/GMHZY9QQA6GgAoqGA6Ium/a71413df4e90697e290b22f7cdbd2ff2/img-4439.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/GMHZY9QQA6GgAoqGA6Ium/a71413df4e90697e290b22f7cdbd2ff2/img-4439.jpg)
Since then we've had cousins, friends, grandparents and parents round to see it. Of course they had to excuse the mess but isn't that part of moving in somewhere new? Eating takeaway on the floor and hunting around boxes to find cutlery?
 [![IMG_4697](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1Ii7xLMmuIIsAEkWGsI2Am/1fd6553cc45a54936a23db61d1040844/img-4697.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1Ii7xLMmuIIsAEkWGsI2Am/1fd6553cc45a54936a23db61d1040844/img-4697.jpg)
Charlie had to rein me in as I wanted to get stuck in painting all the walls. I've been furiously [pinning](https://uk.pinterest.com/vikiibell/future-home/) colour palettes and kitchen designs in my new home board but just can't make up my mind. We love really bright colours but want to make sure our decoration looks slightly more mature than our old place (bead curtains and photos covering walls is only a good look for students). The only thing I've been allowed to paint to far is our new garden pots and a random table we found (I may have spray painted that orange when Charlie wasn't looking).
 [![IMG_4699](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4cKjqxWVygugsi6QMuUOku/eb99402c856b7b9973d1bea689ce9766/img-4699.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1Ii7xLMmuIIsAEkWGsI2Am/1fd6553cc45a54936a23db61d1040844/img-4697.jpg)
With a tiny garden space I really want to grow some food and herbs. We got a little carried away in B&Q and ended up with strawberries, courgettes, chillies, cucumber and cabbage as well as the tomato seeds Charlie's mum got for us. My gardening experience is minimal. I think the closest I've come to gardening is picking daisies - does that even count?
For now I'm just excited about finally having a home and somewhere to decorate and look after - as you can probably tell by the copious amounts of tweets and posts.
