[![IMG_4913](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/n2OxH6ijTMAiKqe46q2ES/a8d909c4dc5d8b60dc43f25fc3960b70/img-4913.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/n2OxH6ijTMAiKqe46q2ES/a8d909c4dc5d8b60dc43f25fc3960b70/img-4913.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: We finally moved into our lovely new home.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
We recently went to [Marco Pierre White's](http://www.mpwsteakandalehouse.org/) restaurant near Liverpool Street. My brother had bought the meal for us as a Christmas present and we'd been waiting for a good night to go. I hadn't heard much about it so wasn't too sure what to expect but I was impressed. 
I had imagined that it might be a bit too 'city boy'ish, especially on a Thursday night but it seemed all the staff were happy to be around and explained the menu to us. They even had their sommelier come over and advise us of our wine choices with what we like and what goes with our food. I did feel a bit silly pulling out my DSLR to snap just about every moment of the meal!
 [![IMG_7325](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2PA3FxnfSMS6a0QwuigEIo/7eddd673a5fad86f8402302c688f941a/img-7325.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/IMG_7325.jpg)
As we looked over the menu we each had a cocktail. I had the passion Jazz which is vodka, passionfruit and apple juice. If there's something with passion fruit on the menu I'm pretty much guaranteed to order it. Charlie had a vanilla and rum cocktail which apparently made him feel like a pirate!
 [![IMG_7319](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/172WaugihGuoYo4EUUew2S/4fbee008635b0319aff6621cfb8dcda1/img-7319.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/172WaugihGuoYo4EUUew2S/4fbee008635b0319aff6621cfb8dcda1/img-7319.jpg)
For starter I had gravadlax with mustard sauce and Charlie chose kipper pate. I hadn't had the gravadlax before and was a bit disappointed it wasn't anything fancy - but then again it is just smoked salmon I ordered! Of course I had to try Charlie's too which was nice. We hadn't tried a fish pate before and it was quite tasty.
 [![IMG_7326](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5X1m0UmaGWMSkG66W4Mmk6/e92dd62e5340816af167adb5b440f119/img-7326.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5X1m0UmaGWMSkG66W4Mmk6/e92dd62e5340816af167adb5b440f119/img-7326.jpg)[![IMG_7329](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6tfxRvQtXykOkOmEkOG2i0/bd1dd6f01adda9290fba2d069f3b26b8/img-7329.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6tfxRvQtXykOkOmEkOG2i0/bd1dd6f01adda9290fba2d069f3b26b8/img-7329.jpg)
There was no question what we'd have for main course. If steaks on the menu it's always my go to dish. I'm quite often a bit disappointed by it though as we've perfected our cooking time so much that often a restaurant just doesn't compare. Here was different. I had the fillet and Charlie had fillet on the bone. They were both amazing. Perfectly cooked (and still mooing). This was paired with the red wine that was recommended by the sommelier. It wasn't a red that I would choose normally but it went really well with the meat.
 [![IMG_7336](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1QD0PmZqsAmQswSWsqMqk6/573a5a796a570cf837debcfed12e05f5/img-7336.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1QD0PmZqsAmQswSWsqMqk6/573a5a796a570cf837debcfed12e05f5/img-7336.jpg)
We're not very desserty people so decided to skip that and had after dinner drinks instead. Charlie's a whisky man whereas I love Ameretto.
 [![IMG_7342](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3wbVpAeK5OoYGcAoA4uies/1dad5c04e6e0a20c3ed3ccad62e81f33/img-7342.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3wbVpAeK5OoYGcAoA4uies/1dad5c04e6e0a20c3ed3ccad62e81f33/img-7342.jpg)
Thank you to Tom who treated us to this meal for our Christmas present. He knows how much we love experiences and going to new places and this was perfect!

seoDescription.en-GB: Our dinner in the Marco Pierre White London steak house.

title.en-GB: My Favourite Places In Tufnell Park

wordpressContent.en-GB:
As the moving date gets closer I thought it was time to write about some of my favourite places to go in Tufnell Park. We moved here two years ago not knowing the area but I've really grown to love it. There's a really now community feel around and we've recently got a really great butchers, fishmongers and soon to be a bakery.  I love popping into the local grocery shop for our Sunday lunches.
 [![IMG_0353](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1uuhOsQKaMCUcSuUMWcuqQ/4c971015b74c7b229299e6e847ef3961/img-0353.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1uuhOsQKaMCUcSuUMWcuqQ/4c971015b74c7b229299e6e847ef3961/img-0353.jpg)
One weekend when we first moved here we took ourselves on a tour of all the parks. We started with the playing fields of Tufnell Park and ventured round to Highgate cemetery and Dartmouth park. There's plenty of green spaces nearby if you just want to get out in the fresh air. Tufnell Park proves especially useful last summer when Charlie decided to teach me how to play tennis. It was perfect to book on a Saturday morning and force yourself out of bed! And of course I can't leave out Hampstead Heath. I can't count the amount of hours we've spent walking around there, playing board games or having picnics.
My two favourite places to eat in Tufnell Park are definitely Aces and Eights and the Junction. Both are very different. We're still convinced that the pizzas in [Aces and Eights](http://www.acesandeightssaloonbar.com/) are the best we've ever had. The bar changed hands a while ago and is become a little more mainstream, it's lost the dark and dingy feel it originally had with the pinup girls posters scattered around the room but it's still a great place to visit. [The Junction](http://www.junctiontavern.co.uk/) is very different. A gastro pub that we always overspend and over eat at! Their menu changes regularly but they've always got foods that are in season. We went a few nights ago and their scallops were incredible. The waiter told us they were fresh in that day and had only just come onto the menu. All the waiters there are lovely and will always advise you on what to have as well.
 [![IMG_2995](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/158lc06T5u08YqIEO6iSGm/0cdeef56e64dfec7c6d9455c5205e664/img-2995.jpg)![IMG_3664](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3pQInvi6UU6SIgIYyiGUkK/c54b0848fd261dffc0882a99cc76a266/img-3664.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/IMG_2995.jpg)
Our love of North London has grown a lot and we won't be living far at all so at least we can come back and visit! If you're new to Tufnell park make sure you follow the [TP Twitter](https://twitter.com/TufnellParkLive) account for all sorts of useful information.
Walking into the corner shop with Charlie dressed as a chicken and acting so casually still has to be one of the funniest moments. [![IMG_8938](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3AqdIWaqo8AYSyCS8kYue8/a0a4461e99174fe53a94c0237415e76f/img-8938.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/IMG_8938.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Moving out of Tufnell Park, here are all the places I'll miss!

wordpressContent.en-GB: An long weekend in Suffolk was just the excuse to have a play around with my camera. I've always had an interest in photography but have never really learn the tips and tricks of it. I took a photography module at uni but it was more the lecturer showing you his work then encouraging you to take one photo that was similar. All a bit too regimented for me. I've been playing around with my DLSR a lot more at the moment, flicking the aperture around and trying to work out all the ISO settings. I really like putting it onto manual focus and focusing on something in a strange area of the photo. I'm always amazed by what the camera can pull out and how it can completely change the scene that you're looking at. On our first day we went into Aldeburgh. The weather was insane. It was so grey and misty you could hardly see a thing. I love the beach there; it always has the fishing boats just tied up with all of their netting and stuff around. I'm not sure if they're still used or just sit there. The netting looks like cobwebs on the ground. ![Aldeburgh](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2pNl8ovm44UUu6Myw4aa4W/fe6a8dcc74bd4096aa140fe13e39e130/img-3505.jpg "Aldeburgh") As we headed home I saw the wild horses in the field so I borrowed Sarah's higher aperture lens and went for a walk down the track. I was stood for about half an hour still against a post with my hood up trying my best to channel my inner horse so they'd come closer. It worked! The lens also helped as it has such a wide aperture (?) I think the brown horse got a bit territorial of me as he came over and kept giving me a mean look. Once he decided that I was harmless he walked away and let the white horse come closer. ![Horse](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3cfoT6JKNi4Ucy6iMcquE8/fd2837af098e104afe11096370b57598/img-7137.jpg "Horse") ![Horse](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6gyaj8WWDCAYO6CE0GckYg/e7d1418aba9368badc476987c0125da4/img-7145.jpg "Horse") ![Horse](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/31H7B9vhpKGQqCEyoQMey6/81426c608f420bb54a8cba607b20a1b2/img-7129.jpg "Horse") Sarah's lens was also the reason we were able to get these next photos. I went outside after dinner and the moon was crazy bright. The difference in lighting compared with London is insane - it sounds really silly to say but when you're so used to the light pollution a completely black night is amazing. Anyway, on that night there was a fully moon and fully moons in Suffolk means light so bright it gives you shadows. With a tiny bit of help from next doors outside lighting we were able to capture these beauties! [![Charlie and I](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/313lZXJylW4SieK8goCIIo/9f3e7411833056a13638e68965f9f943/img-7305.jpg "Charlie and I")](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/313lZXJylW4SieK8goCIIo/9f3e7411833056a13638e68965f9f943/img-7305.jpg)![Us](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4khEh29z5YKQEYAKsuASUs/0eb5ac89c2cb972f1c0989a8e4c82166/img-7257.jpg "us") Kitty came to sit with me as Charlie and I were lying outside the next day. She's always so scared of everyone but every so often she will come over and say hey! ![Cat](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3p77hLr8L6WQiMisoOgsMw/ce58d3ae78200618a0d2698eee9a0329/img-3527.jpg "Cat") The final night saw us set fire to a neighbours old Christmas tree. We usually build pretty big fires in Suffolk and roast marshmallows but it was all a bit too damp so we had a vaguely burning failing attempt at a fire going on. Eventually, after countless attempts at setting different bits of it alight, it burn through the tree. I was happy enough as I love building fires. At one point I was even standing in the middle of it - that either says something about my immaturity or something about the fire. ![Tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3iMQl1tF0AAMig6iGAGWcI/2ae772e7ae5681f5973d6b88e7780e6b/img-3552.jpg "Tree")[![IMG_3573](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2ToU10mZkQyyAMooKKUEE2/d8b2fbeb6b22775373d6e6618878a111/img-3573.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/IMG_3573.jpg) On the last morning we went on a walk through the fields and came across some piggies. I have a feeling this one's a bit of a joker! ![Pigs](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4zVKU42TnqGYW0YYK22OKA/ae37a2d106adf7b8655803d9bf6cc6ae/img-3579.jpg "Pigs")

seoDescription.en-GB: A weekend in Suffolk exploring Aldeburgh and playing with my camera

title.en-GB: Weddings aren't as easy as you think

wordpressContent.en-GB: When I first got engaged everyone was telling me how quickly it would creep up on us and how much I had to do. Of course I didn't believe them and thought if anyone could do it Charlie and I could. I wasn't so far wrong but what I've found is that it would all be very simple to plan if it wasn't for everyone else. Here are my 12 tips for wedding planning: 1. Everyone will always ask you if you're looking forward to it even though it's months away. Politely nod and give them the same answer you gave them last week. 2. Everyone will give input into your ideas and have their own way of doing things. Let them have their say but remember it's your day and you and your partner are the two most important and special people there. The most important thing is that you are together and happy. 3. Tiny tasks will take the longest. I thought doing a gift list would be simple but after walking aimlessly around John Lewis for hours we gave up and decided to pull our own one together - weeks later we're still doing it! 4. Have a gift list - people generally want to buy you a special present for your day. I thought it sounded silly to ask people to buy you things but if you don't you'll end up with lots of the same thing - champagne. Okay, okay not the biggest problem in the world but storing it all in a tiny flat is! 5. No matter how excited you are about that thing you planned you don't need to tell everyone. Yes, it's your day, and yes, it will be amazing but people won't care if you've finally found the perfect centrepiece or invitation design. 6. Think outside the box. You don't have to do everything by the book, if you fancy skipping the fancy cars go for it, if you don't want a cake there's no need for one. 7. Pinterest is not your friend. You'll end up creating all these magical boards about a cool wedding but it just isn't possible unless you both quit your jobs and work full time on wedding prep. We wanted to create and make so much stuff but in between working and socialising (and moving house) we simply haven't had the time.  8. Decisions aren't life threatening - well most of them aren't. If in doubt toss a coin. 9. Delegate - people closest to you want to be involved in the prep so accept a little help. We gave Charlie's mum the task of organising transport - not the most entertaining task in the world but she knows the area best and it's one thing off our mind.  10. Be surprised. Weddings bring out strange things in people. I've heard plenty of objections to us not having a religious ceremony from people I didn't even know who were religious.  11. Have a strict plus one policy. It's all or nothing. Simple. Be prepared for people to ask or assume (don't even go there) but would you rather have their partner or one of your friends there? By the time you give everyone a plus one you've doubled your guests. Okay okay married couples are different but surely that means you should know their partner slightly if they are such a good friend right?  12. Don't panic about time. Book days in your diaries to just do wedding things. This will make sure you don't take up any last minute plans instead. For us it's all too often happened that a weekend of planning instead ends with us waking up hungover and in need of pizza and movie time. I want to thank everyone who has helped in every single tiny way to plan our wedding. From doing the big tasks to hearing us deliberate over tiny decisions to distracting a us when we need a break. Wedding planning doesn't have to be hard if you take it in manageable pieces, a bit like BBC bitesize used to tell you. **Most importantly enjoy it and make sure you have fun along the way** - just like we did with our last April fools! (Note the poor photoshopping)   [![1525309_10154165753940001_919587568_n](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5swBLb3I76Q2Gyu88ewUMq/20c03c3a067ec58309a2cea0d51af648/1525309-10154165753940001-919587568-n.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5swBLb3I76Q2Gyu88ewUMq/20c03c3a067ec58309a2cea0d51af648/1525309-10154165753940001-919587568-n.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Weddings are pretty tricky to organise whilst everyone wants to be with you celebrating. Get organised and read these 12 tips

wordpressContent.en-GB:
The past few weekends (and week nights) of wedding planning have been pretty exciting. Suddenly it's just around the corner and we have tons to do! I've got complete faith in us that we will get it all done purely because of the amount we've managed to do in just a few days so far:

*   Found and booked a hairdresser for me and bridesmaids
*   Dress fittings
*   Decoration planning
*   Music planning
*   Confirming and adding little bits to the marquee
*   Various hours on Pinterest
*   Finding readings for the ceremony
*   Planning the music for the ceremony
*   Met and planned out photos with our photographer
*   Picked music for our first dance
*   Drawing images for our menu

Oh and had an amazing stag and hen do thanks to India, Ellie and the groomsmen. Of course I can't really go into details about what went on except to say that it was really really fun, I got to see all of my good friends in one place and the weekend was full of laughter. The next big thing on the list is honeymoon! Watch this space.... ![Wedding ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/tICBeKCm52qQSYccgIiKE/08bf99b26a1b14a1f63e54b6085393ab/img-5640.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: What we have left to do for our wedding planning and what we've been doing recently.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Our wedding day was the best day ever. I know a lot of people must say that but for us it was more than true. The whole day was so totally us that we can't think of anything we'd change if we could. We hosted it in Shellpits - the cottages in Suffolk I keep going on about. Even though Charlie and I were both there the night before coordination from our bridesmaids and groomsmen meant that we didn't see each other - even if Charlie did shout messages to me at midnight and I ran out of the house with a towel over me in the morning. I'd decided that I wanted to start my pre- wedding rituals off with an early morning beach trip and so all the girls (and Tom) had a dip in the sea. I love swimming in the sea in Suffolk - it's always a bit cold but once you're in its super refreshing and gets you energised for the day. ![Beach](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5IgFmosV7GYyQqgSyMcqcu/4857a418616026ff6990569dc3e9f596/img-6051.jpg) After a speedy breakfast we popped into Aldeburgh to get our hair done. This was a last minute decision but I'm so glad we did as the girls in [The Hair Shop](http://www.thehairshopaldeburgh.co.uk/) did an amazing job. Once back at the house India was in charge of makeup. I'd chosen her to do it as I don't wear a lot of makeup so didn't fancy having someone who doesn't know me do it and coat me in the stuff. It was so nice to just be sat in the kitchen chilling as it was done rather than be under pressure of hoping a stranger can do it as you imagine. ![Anna's Hair](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3MUhvLpevY4KweWIamac44/9bf7c03354e3e5667669a3db54c72d92/448613b9615e74567eea8d09df732854.jpg) Our [photographer](http://www.dominicwhiten.co.uk/) and videographer were incredible. They both arrived as we were starting to get ready and made themselves at home. [Dominic](http://www.dominicwhiten.co.uk/) even ended up advising India about doing up the corset section of my dress! Getting ready with them there was so casual and I don't think any of us noticed them snapping away or taking a few moments on film. And I still apologise to them for bouncing around in my underwear - what can I say, I was excited! Time for the dresses .... Well pictures tell a thousand words so here we all are: ![Dresses](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2r976RmnccuESakYuiAQ0A/bcefc4c268cd0d5f8c4935d9eca2661a/img-6074.jpg) Our flowers were an easy choice - [Jane Packer](http://www.jane-packer.co.uk/). Charlie's family are really great friends with Gary who now owns the business after Jane passed away and it was her flowers I wanted to be holding on the day as they mean so much to us and Shellpits. Thank you again Gary, Louise and the rest of the JP team, they were beautiful. ![Bride flowers](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5zcBT9Sm76Akq4awWsECWw/b40cc93e12cca652ba487cbf41fba3c6/16f0ae86d0892a7b382e4265b9c91ed7.jpg) ![Bridesmaid Flowers](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5Lz1FCRcqWII0aoEckSoU0/88c8381451ce0631475f8c9be4c87b2e/bridesmaid-flowers.jpg) My car of choice to arrive at Glemham Hall for our ceremony was an Aston Martin driven by Alec, a family friend. Lucky for me he'd made us a wedding themed playlist! ![Aston Martin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6EeuJVQNz2g84G2SIwoocU/0c129ba5f16fbe8abd30d57a2bd5097f/d0eb1ea9a86ce04f816304e461b29708.jpg) The ceremony is indescribable. I've got so many flashes of moments in my head I really hope they stay there forever. We even managed to make everyone laugh as we turned around to glare at the guests during the part where they ask if anyone objects. I had also coordinated with our pianist to get a few Disney songs playing before I arrived - subtle! Our readings were fairly difficult to decide but we got there in the end and I'm really happy with our choices. We had Ellie read _A Lovely Love Story by Edward Monkton_ then my littlest cousin dan read _The Little Yellow Leaf by Carin Berger_ and finally Richard read _The Owl And The Pussycat by Edward Lear_. There may have been a few giggles when he read the line 'pussy oh pussy oh my love why a wonderful pussy you are'. We chose to write our own vows which I won't share but let's just say they were pretty special :) After signing the register we half skipped down the aisle to Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah and outside into the sunshine.  _[Read part two here.](https://vikibell.com/posts/wedding-part-ii)_ ![7f563986c9007a68ff27923d247cc71Wedding party](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3TxigGs0aQ6gA6o8QaeYIi/8a689c24768183d850ca2de1a8d580d5/7f563986c9007a68ff27923d247cc719.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Part one of our very special wedding day

wordpressContent.en-GB: Part two of my super mega awesome, best day ever, wedding. Tea and cake recommended for reading this one through....![Wedding sign](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6FRcjKBSfuCgm8suy80Wqs/30d461ecc59ab8b460727ce142520d0a/wedding-sign.jpg)A surprise method of transport from Charlie's parents had to be one thing - a blue VW campervan. Charlie dreams of being able to get one and do it up - one day Charlie, one day. We rode back to Shellpits and our reception in it which gave us a moment by ourselves to compare our mornings and talk about the ceremony. Thankfully campervans don't go too fast so we had time to chill and take a few selfies. ![Selfie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6G8UVkcQqkKMcAGWW2KKko/69b73da32af6dc28c0d776fe1f888ee5/selfie.jpg) We swapped into the land rover for the track part of this ride and I'm really glad we got to involve it somehow in our day as I love that car! The campervan driver was amazed that I just lifted up my skirts and jumped straight in the back - I'm not quite the delicate bride type. India was driving and Jub Jub was in the front too. It was hilarious rocking up in it. Especially to some of my family members who are fairly conservative when it comes to weddings. ![Land rover](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/SdiKXTMZIi8w02GaOoQAg/b710f17f0eefe84bd692b0724fe75ae7/land-rover.png) After the confetti moment we had champagne and a lovely speech from India who gave a bit of an introduction to Shellpits. It was so good to see such a mix of people floating around all talking together. This was precisely our thinking with the table plan. We split up friends and mixed them with the same kinds of age groups. Yes, I admit we did try to match make in some places - and were fairly successful as we found out the next day...! ![Confetti ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7KEBfvcMLeMaWwgQaemcMY/89d181fd6b732669f315f3e84d509f0b/confetti.jpg) Dinner passed with a blur of speeches, good food and champagne. We tried to get around all the tables but it was impossible. Our special touch to the main course was that Charlie's grandma and grandpa had made all the mint jelly. They love coming up to Shellpits to make various jams and jellies so it was an obvious choice to share the yumminess with our guests. Dessert was a little different as well. It was half a pineapple filled with fresh fruit and accompanied with rocky road. ![Mint Jelly](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3Xlm5k7oTuOSsgcQuUImAm/c16ca77d3a5e5a82e3ebe5fd332567ab/mint-jelly.jpg) I was really nervous for the first dance. Only four people knew the song and I'm not such a great dancer - especially in a giant dress. This was our biggest surprise of the day and was guaranteed tears *cue evil laugh*. It was such an obvious choice and so was who played it. We love our friend Grant's voice and music so asked if he could play for us. Suspense built? I'll cut to what the song actually was... _You've Got A Friend In Me_ from _Toy Story_. Looking back I had no need to be nervous. We were pretty good - I think! I even managed a semi pro looking spin. ![First Dance](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6uAmMd3hok6AW8aEWkMCWi/739fa923ab2668e008d349368e54171c/first-dance.jpg) Our second dance was _Love Shack_ - yes Charlie did let me choose it. Everyone came running on and jumping around. I didn't exactly stick to the standard bridal swaying and instead preferred to jump around the dance floor. There was even a few low floor dance moves and some spinning of the skirt. At one point India and I spent a good few songs simply jumping up and down - a great workout if anyone's interested! Who knows what we must have looked like to the oldies who had pulled up chairs to watch us all. We were supposed to be organising fireworks as a surprise for Sarah and David but they had planned them as a surprise for us so we ended up having an extra special display. It was a great break after the first few energetic dances. I'd really recommended it around that point in the night, if not fireworks can seem like the end of an evening when in fact they were only the beginning! I also used the opportunity to toss my bouquet. Everyone gathered around any i can remember my aunts trying to fight it out to catch it. My bridesmaid, Ellie, never one to loos a game of catch, caught it. Her boyfriend was there and looked very excited. **UPDATE:** Richard proposed in late 2015 and they are getting married in August - our next wedding!! ![Catching the bouquet](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/64df1rhWCWQmSY6y4wky4c/5d610bcf8307e1d6ca50014eab229f07/wedding-bouquet.jpg) A wedding isn't complete without a photo booth and in true Charlie and Viki style we'd decided to make our own. It seemed silly to spend money on hiring one when we have an excessively large selection of props. Instructions will be posted soon for anyone who wants to recreate it. It also means we now own one - for all your photo booth needs! I don't think I ever saw it not being used and some of the wigs even made it onto the dance floor. ![Photo booth](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2b78lCPn6ko6qmAOkmkKuk/071363f3736096975f3c8142c59c8c35/photo-booth.jpg) Dancing, champagne, smiles and laughing at a few people stumbling around was pretty much the rest of the night. I was on such a high from the day and seeing everyone celebrate with us. Everyone had told us that our wedding day would pass with a blur - for me it really didn't. I made sure to capture and savour each moment I had with everyone. It wasn't just the perfect day, it was the perfect planning for the day too. Even the few days before when we were painting and decorating it was all an incredible amount of fun. Thank you to everyone who helped to make our wedding day so special I hope it sticks with you forever. I wish we could do it every year. ![The Meare](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1FeuBV6QVuSgauSGKQ6cOy/fdd79568554648ef3625528746e3e0f2/the-meare.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Part two of our incredible wedding day - the reception, food, dancing, fireworks and the surprise of who caught the bouquet.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
We've had the first draft of our wedding video through and have finally printed off a bunch of the official photos. Everything wedding related is getting nicely wrapped up. The only big thing we need to do is sort out thank you cards - which will take bloody ages! Quite a few people have asked for tips looking back at the wedding so here some are.

1.  Record everything. The next morning Charlie and I wrote down all our stories and memories on his phone whilst they were fresh in our minds. I'm pretty sure we'll appreciate the hell out of that later on.
2.  Have a next day - we had a hog roast in the local pub where we'd got engaged. It was our way of showing our side of Suffolk and sharing a section of our day with the owners who always host us so well. It was also a great way of seeing everyone and hearing all the stories from the evening. For the people leaving that morning we also went to the beach for a dip in the sea. Although cold it was super refreshing and managed to wash away the cobwebs. Rushing off on a honeymoon means you'll miss all the excitement the next day.![Next Day](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3qziIXgGqsWY0kmEcQCKEs/6d5b9062a52a3c50e2f33ebd11934f53/next-day.jpg)
3.  Encourage everyone to stay in the same place. It builds a bit more of an atmosphere for the guests not to mention helps with any transport!
4.  Ask someone else to organise where you're staying that night. You've given so many people so many surprises during the day keep one for yourselves. India was in charge and we stayed in a cute little cottage down the road from the golf club where the majority of people stayed.
5.  Don't be too strict with your plans. We never got around to thinking about a toast master so ended up asking on of the groomsmen to do it. We didn't know what time our first dance would be and if it would be before or after fireworks - we just went with whatever time fitted in with food.[![Fireworks](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/kDGh2KJwwCEG0wyc2G4oY/3273245183a8500c549413f5ba182b38/fireworks.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/kDGh2KJwwCEG0wyc2G4oY/3273245183a8500c549413f5ba182b38/fireworks.jpg)
6.  Trust your suppliers. I really think we had awesome caterers and photographers and videographer and DJ. They were all as laid back as we were and happily sorted out things themselves. When we first met our photographer [Dominic](http://www.dominicwhiten.co.uk/) I felt as if we were all interviewing each other. He had to be right for us and us him. It worked amazingly. I can't speak highly enough of Dominic as he got stuck in and was able to help organise smaller aspects of our day which may have been overlooked. He was able to get all our guests sorted and captured the traditional shots with such speed there wasn't any hanging around. He even wrote a beautiful [post](http://www.dominicwhiten.co.uk/uncategorized/glemham-hall-thorpeness-wedding-photography-viki-charlie/) about the day. Together he and our caterer [Justin](http://www.themovablefeast.co.uk/) did incredibly. Justin even got involved in pulling up the reveal curtain for our first dance and greeted us with canapés as soon as we arrived. It small touches like that which confirm we made the correct decision with these guys.
7.  Reveal curtain - have one. I thought people would know what it was but instead they wondered where the dance floor was. This made our first dance more of a surprise as people suddenly saw a whole new area of the marquee and rushed over to watch us.![Reveal Curtain ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5wB65F5r8sOe6WCeqEigOi/91ec772ea44ac5b726cb4496711a03a3/reveal-curtain.jpg)![First Dance](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4avJKQqd9eYQ6iaOAWwqWg/ff8e8f46a124090ee96b40319e7aa15b/first-dance.jpg)
8.  Have a dress holding up contingency plan. Sounds strange and I'm not sure how to explain that but you'll appreciate it. Through vigorous jumping my bustle ended up breaking and I didn't want anyway standing on my already filthy train so I headed over to one of our more creative friends who ended up holding the whole thing up with ribbon and a tie through my bra strap. Difficult to get out of later on but a whole lot better than the whole thing tearing whilst dancing.
9.  Stay as long as you like but leave before the Dj. We were worried that people wouldn't leave until we had but that was no problem as we had told everyone that the minibus we'd organised was doing trips from 10pm. It gave the oldies and excuse to leave if they wanted although most preferred to sit at the edge of the dance floor watching. With the DJ having about twenty minutes left we decided to have our last few songs and follow a people tunnel out to our transport. This helped wind down the night, we left on a high.
10.  Don't have it in a venue. Now I imagine this make things a lot easier as to organise but they can also be strict with things like curfews etc. even if we weren't able to use the Shellpits field I would always think about renting a field or sports club land somewhere and put up a marquee. It gives you the freedom to do what you like.![Panoramic ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3bInWqO1GMuocYaAw8IqEa/aa4df0b3a480bd1b7a79b4da9051b1c7/panoramic.jpg)
11.  Have a honeymoon. Even if you just go away for a few days. We were debating having a small break after and a bigger holiday next year but decided to go all in and shot off to Bali two days after the wedding. I've appreciated the break a lot more than you can imagine and it's been so nice to spend time just Charlie and I exploring somewhere somewhere new.

![Honeymoon](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4bGvW34NlSUOAAGwYcMgqK/e390d3dfc4372525a5a95e06ca7afba6/honeymoon.jpg)

After the whole [blogger blackmail](http://www.thedrum.com/opinion/2015/08/18/bloggerblackmail-why-both-bakery-and-blogger-were-wrong) moment I thought I'd get my thoughts down around working with bloggers and being a blogger. Before I start I want to say that although I count myself as a blogger it's all quite new to me still and, as you've probably noticed, I don't manage to get weekly posts out (or more!). I also work with bloggers on a variety of campaigns as part of my job so I feel like I can comment on both sides. These are my opinions and I've made them from working with bloggers and reading a hell of a lot of tweets, blogs and Facebook chats.

# **The main issue**

The main problem in this this blogger/brand relationship is that brands are only just starting to recognise the potential of a blogger. By ignoring the roles bloggers play in brand awareness and marketing, brands are not allocating time, effort and money into their budgets to properly work with bloggers. They can't just expect to throw an "oh and ping that release over to a few bloggers to cover it to would you?" **_No. No. No_. _Not at all._** Bloggers are not journalists and can not be consistently chase for posts. More often than not bloggers are employed elsewhere and only started blogging as a hobby. They aren't getting paid to blog and any money they make from website advertising is minimal (I'm literally talking pennies a month). They've also spent years building their blog to where it is today not to mention the hours spend editing photos and posts. _In order for bloggers to work with you, your campaign needs to be something they're interested in and needs to have some benefit to them and their audience._ [![Laptop](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/uTpfXkTfzweEyM08SCu2s/e22a9812a7130c84f79fefa7e3c69f20/img-6645jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/uTpfXkTfzweEyM08SCu2s/e22a9812a7130c84f79fefa7e3c69f20/img-6645jpg.jpg)

# **Bloggers are very valuable**

As people move away from paper magazines and traditional media there is more of opportunity for bloggers to be found and heard. More and more time is spent on Twitter and Instagram with feeds filled with informative, beautiful and exciting text and images. A review of a restaurant has a lot more weight behind it than a magazine piece.  It comes straight from an everyday person not a trained journalist who has been "fed" lines to say or sold in a story around it (pun - smooth!) There is also the other side of the story. What happens if you're reading a restaurant review and see that it says sponsored content at the end? It's still going to be a positive review, from what I've read and heard, a blogger would never openly slate a restaurant. If the food or service etc. was bad then they would often contact the PR and let them know or plain refuse to cover it. What's the point in telling people places not to go? Why would you want to read something so openly negative after all the waiter may have had a bad day, the oven may have been broken, these things happen (trust my I know, my brother manages restaurants). It's not worth ruining someone's reputation over it. I would also hope that bloggers aren't fed lines of what to include in their review. Anytime I've worked with a blogger on a review or campaign I would have told them a little about it the why, how and what, then asked them to take a look and let us know what they think. _They're free to form their own opinions and that's whats so beautiful about hearing straight from a blogger - the originality. _

# **There is a darker side to bloggers**

There are those bloggers who are doing it for the freebies. Who will straight out lay their demands on the table. To be fair to them they have a point, if they have got to the stage where they're doing it for a day job then they need to make their money. They've put a lot of time and effort into their blogs so deserve rewards from it but it shouldn't be just about the money. I hate it when I'm looking for bloggers and come across a site with review after review after review. Do you just get free stuff to try out all the time? Who reads these? And isn't it hard to always review stuff over and over? I struggle enough not to call everything amazing and awesome but then again that might just me with a tiny vocabulary!

# **Follower counts**

I was disappointed to see that one of the bloggers I was working with had a lot of fake followers on Twitter. I thought something was a little off when she jumped a thousand followers since the last time I looked. Now there is sometimes a legit way that may happen but don't forget that the PR you're working with usually has monitoring and social tools which can take a deeper look into your profile and see through the eggs and spammy accounts.

# **There is no need to be rude**

There is usually some young intern or account executive on the other side of that email, likely to be the same age or younger than you and just doing as they were told. They are the ones who send the emails and they aren't the ones who make the plans as to where the budget is assigned. Please remember that and don't just ignore them or send a rude email back. The hardest thing when you're running a campaign is to not get replies. Anytime a blogger emails back, even if it's just to say "no sorry this is something I'd usually charge for" is tons better than no reply. I know some days bloggers get thousands of emails but having an out of office set maybe saying that you would love to reply but will only get in contact if it's positive or just a quick thank you but no thank you is nice to have. _All of these replies and reasons for not working on campaigns do need to be fed back up to the top so that they become more aware what works and what doesn't work with bloggers._

# **Timing**

_Both bloggers and brands need to keep in mind that timing may not be in their favour._ Once a campaign has taken place, brands often want to see the results immediately and will forget the bloggers often have content planned out already as well as having day jobs (and a social life somewhere along the lines!). The brands will forget that bloggers often have content planned out already and have day jobs (not to mention a social life). Some bloggers will be able to get your post up and out within a few days but for others you'll need to wait a few weeks. The key to this is to have an open conversation with the blogger and make sure you're both aware of timings. If you want to wrap something up quickly why not ask if they can post something a little earlier? Or at least a teaser tweet about the upcoming post which will likely please the client as they know something is coming without having to have the entire post. Bloggers also need to hold their side of the bargain - there's one particular example where I was working with a blogger and kept getting pushed back and pushed back, she openly lied to me which was just insulting seeing as I could see everything on her Instagram feed. Mistakes happen and if you can't blog you can't blog just be honest about it. It makes it embarrassing to report back to the teams to say your blogger relations hasn't exactly come through.

# **Budget and last minute tasks**

_It's important a to keep up a conversation with a PR as much as you can._ I'm at the stage with a few bloggers where I can email or tweet them and say things like "fancy trying this? Or "there's an event next week if you wanna grabbing a drink?" It cuts through all the bullshit you usually have to send about the campaigns and straight off gets a yes or no answer. When working in PR you will often get something dropped in your lap last minute with the instructions to get some blog posts out of it so having this is kind of relationship is hugely valuable and amazing. Sometimes there won't be payment in it, I think it's good for a blogger to charge but accept that sometimes they will get the minimum (although always get something out of it). At the end of the day the blogger can always say no.

# **Speaking out online**

In terms of the blogger blackmail moment I think it's bad form for anyone to pick fights through social media. If you have a problem with someone go and speak to them about it. I read about some Twitter spat with celebs the other day and thought - what's the point?! It's just attention seeking. The only time I speak out to a brand online is if I've been badly treated and it's difficult for me to connect with them via Twitter. Keep things between yourselves, people love drama but think about the reputations you're effecting by speaking out so bluntly. I always say to stick up for yourself but this doesn't have to be done via social media. And if you must then do it without naming people.

# **And finally, the term PR**

I've used the term PR throughout this mostly as it's the most recognisable description of the people I'm talking about. Yes PR is close to what I'm doing but I hate that term. Maybe it should be called social relations or digital relations or something. Anyway, I don't ring up journalists all day and I don't write press releases. In fact if you ever get a press release by me please delete it immediately as my email would have been hacked. That doesn't happen. Journalists and bloggers are in two different ball parks so keep the press releases for one and think more about tailoring how you work with the other.   That got a bit intense so here's a photo of a monkey.... [![Monkey](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1HH01qlvmY6Yo4MAU2sIAg/acb363a8c889549f7e0c06cb5e2ed714/11886165-10156157623445001-7913451976982095289-o.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1HH01qlvmY6Yo4MAU2sIAg/acb363a8c889549f7e0c06cb5e2ed714/11886165-10156157623445001-7913451976982095289-o.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: How should bloggers and brands work together and how to get the most from the relationships - in the opinion of both a blogger and a 'PR'

wordpressContent.en-GB: When we first started thinking about honeymoons I had the idea of Bali in my head. Neither of us have been over to that part of the world so we decided that was as good of a reason as any! I hate making big decisions and we managed to put off looking and ended up booking the honeymoon two weeks before our wedding. I wasn't too sure what to expect as we hadn't fully researched but I think this was a good thing as we didn't have any preconceived ideas and only had a few rough plans. I would recommend the area that we stayed - Nasa Dua as it was quite quiet and perfect for a beach break. Taxis are cheap enough that you can get into the tourists sports like Kuta and Ubud fairly easily. ![Viki & Charlie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/jzySyEQ4F222UsYiCGm8Q/776858349a906edc0f56dd2eeda0932f/viki-charlie.jpg) **Getting around** We spent quite a bit of time with various drivers exploring the island. You can book a driver for the day for £30 which is about a 9 hour day. Most of them have done a tourism degree so know a lot about the island and where to take you. I would recommend it if you're out there as it's the best way to see the island and learn more about the culture. Our driver took us around loads of local tourist and not so tourist attractions. In a day he took us to see a typical Balinese play, textile designers, coffee tasting, lunch (with amazing views over the rice terraces), silver smiths, a waterfall and finally dinner watching the sunset. ![Viki and sunset](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/bEJrMk8c0goCeG0Gsu4I4/5114036102c8a5ae583390f3c3195228/viki-and-sunset.jpg) **Kuta ** We went to Kuta twice. The first time we walked down from Legion and the second we went for a more basic dinner - we got bored of the Bali food. Kuta's full of Australian backpackers and is very busy but it's also the best place to surf if you're into that. I liked the vast amount of shops around there and the different bars and restaurants. If your looking for a slightly western touch Kuta is your place however I'd recommend venturing north slightly to Legion which is pretty much the same just quieter. ![Kuta beach](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/Z98shuFgs0GikukOccaqq/54b0de5852b81ed2bc1c50124496e2a3/kuta-beach.jpg) **Ubud ** This is another key place to visit in Bali. It was around an hour from where we were staying but cost us under £10 in a taxi to get to. We went to the monkey forest after lunch which was fun. The monkeys all live there and are generally fed by the tourists buying bananas to give them. One got a little too friendly with me ..... ![Ubud monkey](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/73PKZvAzXU0sYM6mGwGCAO/e07c477cfc0af5ccbb5cdac923475067/ubud-monkey.jpg) ![Ubud monkey](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6COj5RalQ4w8Sm26suSmGi/1fc26a5d8ef011404a445b3e99c5ca6e/ubud-monkey.jpg) **Temples** There is also quite a few temples around. In Bali there is at least one temple per house to warn off the evil spirits. There is usually another inside to welcome the good spirits and fortunes. Each day offerings are given and they will share the food they eat with the temple. We got given a lot of information about their religion whilst out there and it's really interesting to see something that a whole country believes in so strongly and how much time they spend worshiping and making offerings. ![Buddhist temple](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5F4x8hws0MKI2EMwCWsug4/826853891ce79010b9e647ac3ad59563/buddhist-temple.jpg) **Trips** One of our groomsmen booked us a three day tour whilst we were there. This made sure we got to explore the north of the island too. You can book the tour in different sections and he found it as it was listed as the [second best thing](http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g294226-d2307721-Reviews-Mayong_Village_Tracking_Experience-Bali.html) to do in Bali (after a water park ?!). We were picked up and taken across the island stopping off to see various rice terraces as well as lakes and Buddhist and Hindu temples. ![Rice terrace](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5lhaFoRzAQyIEwMW4IW6Oc/97837228e5484102c56a9786774f9084/rice-terrace.jpg) The tour can also book hotels for you too and it was really nice to see a different one. This was a lot smaller then our main hotel but the two complimented each other nicely. The manager was really friendly and all the staff even put on a show on our second night. The second day started super early as we were out on a three man traditional boat at 5.45 off to watch the sunrise and dolphin spot. It was my first sunrise and it's well worth waking up for - even if I did go back to nap before breakfast! ![Sunrise](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3TB1XmL4i4G6aUUK6QKmQg/3bdaa5d6b2d6393bb0697d01c0299469/sunrise.jpg)   After we were picked up by Artana who runs the tour and taken to his house where we met a few others and set off trekking. As we went along Artana kept stopping to explain various fruits, plants and culture for us. In all it was a three hour walk and I was glad to stop off at a farmers house near the end for some fresh coconut water and fried banana. ![Coconut tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/nJkbBh3vpucom0ISsOWwG/9e292440e3ac7fee78ab8852be9c3c43/coconut-tree.jpg) Yes that is him climbing the tree to get the coconut! The tour finished with lunch made by Artana's wife Ria. This is a really sweet little touch as it means you get to talk to a family and learn more about life in Bali as well as experience the traditional food - not just the tourist stuff! ![Viki in Bali](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/79hPwL1kZy686EC0cUq6UK/c8f40209632afab4df89fc372236e0fa/viki-in-bali.jpg)![Rice terrace](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4f81r2kBDiSy2K2C02eYaw/5385c16c94764d64342921b7e7739a83/rice-terrace.jpg) The final day of the tour took us back home whilst stopping off at a traditional food market - the food standards agencies would have a field day if they came across it!! My favourite part of the trip came next when we headed to the Sekympul waterfall. I could have stayed in that water for hours. It was amazing to be in after the car journey. Charlie wasn't much of a fan though as his contact lenses threaten to come out and he couldn't handle the chill. Luckily I was able to amuse myself and spent a fair while splashing around the rocks like a toddler.  ![Waterfalls](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/YSas1v6HQswq06GCSgsSu/b66bdafb2efe66f1586667a8f4e51268/waterfalls.jpg) We managed to see all of the island we wanted to and could then spend our final days relaxing and making the most of the pool beers. ![Beer](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6gu8O2SQkoK4Cc4qGOqoCq/7afd49127fe2a1684c7be6b52da48606/beer.jpg) I would really recommend visiting Bali as a holiday or honeymoon destination. These are my five reasons: * The weather is pretty amazing - we didn't have a dull day * The people are really kind - our hotel manager had cocktails with us before we left * It's super cheap once you're there. £60 is a million Indonesian Rupiah so you're pretty much a millionaire * There's lots of culture to explore - tons of the stuff * The scenery is beautiful - speaks for itself ![Beach photo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/54PG71Vq3Y82YwCK6euGos/ff8f6b1d5b986dc858569ba692d74ca7/beach-photo.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Read all about our honeymoon to Bali as well as some tips for if you're out there.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
One of the big questions you get asked on the run up to your wedding is _how's the diet going_. Now I know you shouldn't have to lose weight for your big day, you should be happy the way you are and plenty of people will cry out that you don't need to lose weight - so why are they asking about my diet?! I hadn't even though about it until I kept getting asked. I had this idea that I'd swim twice a week and go on a few runs - I'd be back to my teenage athletic (sort of) body in no time. That wasn't exactly how it went down. Between work, wedding planning and home hunting all I wanted to do on a spare night was chill on the sofa. So I thought I might cut back on drinking and junk food a bit but nothing too bad. Then I looked at what I was eating - that Sainsburys meal deal each day isn't the healthiest thing. Luckily my buddy [Catriona](https://kiwicakes.wordpress.com/) teamed up with me to make healthier lunches at work. Okay, well by team I mean she made me lunch and I paid her the cost of the food but that still counts right? Charlie came up with the idea after reading the [four hour body](http://fourhourbody.com/). I couldn't have done it without him - I think we were both convinced we wanted to 'win' the diet! I'm not claiming to be the healthiest person in the world, this is just what I tried out and found worked for me. Here's what you need to do:

*   Cut out all carbs - potatoes, bread etc etc
*   Replace these with legumes such as lentils and black beans
*   Cut out sugar including fruit
*   Cut out dairy - we're about the only mammal that drinks milk past childhood - why do we need it?
*   Drink only water other than the wine
*   Allow yourself one (okay maybe two) glasses of red wine a day.

Simple. With these easy rules I was able to cut out the crisps and fizzy drinks and feel a lot happy, healthier and cleaner in my diet. The biggest thing I noticed was how I felt in the mornings, I used to have cereal at work but now I'm having scrambled eggs, lentils and ham in the mornings - it takes about two minutes to make and means the energy hits me as I arrive into work. It's encouraged me to try out different foods, I hadn't thoughts about eating things like kidney beans before except in a chilli. There are plenty of delicious foods out there so why not try out different types? You're also allowed one cheat day a week which we ensured fell on a Saturday where you can eat all the junk you fancy. I've got a few great legume recipes (which I'll post up soon) but I'm still on the look out for more so if you have any let me know in the comments below. [![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6u7jxtCwCWmmAG4i8M4QcY/65decf0913b6662eb04e2cd1ff8f3828/img-6259jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6u7jxtCwCWmmAG4i8M4QcY/65decf0913b6662eb04e2cd1ff8f3828/img-6259jpg.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Why I changed the way I eat, the food groups I concentrate on and how it's lead to me feeling a lot healthier and cleaner.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Sundays aren't just for roast dinners! They're about having a big meal with either family or friends. Now don't expect the healthiest thing in the world from this recipe but it's pretty damn tasty and perfect to make if you have people round or just want to make a few freezer meals. This was one of my favourite uni meals to make purely because it comes in such big portions so lasted me weeks. My mum always thinks that spaghetti bolognese tastes better when it's been frozen - I think both are equally as good. The original recipe I based this on included white wine instead of red but I think you can use anything you have lying around. It also added a splash of milk with the mince, I found it makes it a little too fatty but feel free to experiment. Finally, I know I've only just posted about my new [low carb eating habits](http://vikibell.com/why-i-changed-the-way-i-eat/) so feel free top swap out the pasta for spiralized carrots and skip the cheese. For this recipe you'll need:

*   3 onions
*   3 cloves of garlic
*   2 carrots
*   a small pack of mushrooms
*   1 pack of mince
*   two or three tins of chopped tomatoes
*   fresh tomatoes (optional)
*   A bottle of red wine

*   First up chop the onions and a few cloves of garlic
*   Fry these in a wok in a small amount of oil (you don't want too much as the mince gives out liquid)
*   As you do this chop or peel the carrots into tiny pieces and mushrooms - mix up the varieties depending how much you like them. By the time you've cut them it'll be time to add them into the wok.

![Spag Bol](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7518.jpg)

*   Stir together well. Once the onions have softened up add in the pack of mince (500g) alongside a pinch of salt and pepper. Mix well.

![Spag Bol](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7526.jpg)

*   When the mince begins to loose its colour it's time to add the tinned tomatoes.
*   At the point you can also add in the fresh tomatoes and a good splash of wine

![Spag Bol](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7546.jpg)

*   You can either leave it to simmer on the hob or pop it in the oven at about 180 for 30 minutes and stir it occasionally

*   To make it extra healthy cover it with a layer of grated cheese for the last ten minutes to make it more into a bake

![Cheese](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7554.jpg)

*   Whilst this is melting boil some pasta to accompany it and any garlic bread you fancy
*   Take a cheap bottle of wine and decant it to make it seem fancier (it seriously tastes so much better!)

![Decant wine](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7535.jpg)

*   Spaghetti bolognese complete. You're good to go!

![Spag Bol](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7557.jpg) [![IMG_7556](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7556.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/IMG_7556.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Our not so healthy spaghetti bolognese recipe

wordpressContent.en-GB: My thoughts on creativity

I first got to know Grant back in school when we were in art class together. His final piece involved copper piping puncturing an old wooden door whilst I painted over smashed glass and twigs. The theme was discord. It means that I've been there since (almost) the beginning and I've had the chance to hear the different genres of music that he's experimented with, all the time adding his unique style. From a Grant screaming on stage at a gig in Rayleigh to a more acoustic, folk Grant playing in Leeds. He recently came to down to London to meet some producers and it was lovely to spend a week with him staying at ours. Having someone who's constantly creative and witty around is really refreshing from normal life. Of course he couldn't come down to London without playing a gig which is why we found ourselves, beer in hand of course, in the Monarch in Camden last Tuesday evening.![Grant](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4b8tt2PsO4G8qmoK88M0eO/6fd0542c49a2a60cc8b6467e82a054c4/grant.jpg) Grant was first up with the tough job of warming up the crowd which he did with ease. Soon enough you could skim the room and see his music making the crowd move and shake. ![Grant](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5pwyaElRaE8yUmmqSKCCoO/3eacbb5a6fcde6dad29f303c9b892a2c/grant.jpg) Because of the vast amount of songs he writes and the infrequent times we see him I'm always lucky enough to hear his new stuff as well as some old favourites. Grant's music is super unique to him and different to anything I've heard before. If I had to choose something similar it would have to be a kind of Van Morrison or Fleet Foxes sound. But it's almost if he's taken their style turned it inside out, added a few ingredients and baked something new out of it. ![Grant](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/NAG084pdwkoIWqaeQikWi/07db174c4c7ba38c1aace5ff754ebd39/grant.jpg) If you're in Leeds then watch out for [Cottonwoolf](http://www.cottonwoolf.com) who Grant's currently performing with. He's also releasing a new solo album under a different name and will be back in London again soon but for now have a listen to his songs over on [iTunes](https://itunes.apple.com/gb/artist/grant-k.-fennell/id450692647) or [soundcloud](https://soundcloud.com/grant-fennell). Let me know what you think!

seoDescription.en-GB: Seeing Grant K Fennell play live in London and what his music means to me.

wordpressContent.en-GB: I always get a bit excited about Autumn. I love pulling all my jumpers and boots out of the wardrobe and the feel of the chill on your face when you're wrapped up warm. The whole of Autumn has an almost magical, spooky feel to it which explains why I like Halloween so much! I think it might be my favourite season, summer being my second as you can lie out in the sunshine but it often disappoints if it just doesn't reach the high temperatures. Whereas Autumn is where the changes happen - hot turns to cold and the trees change to orange. The sun rises much later and lower as well giving you some beauty in your mornings and great photos. [![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6MxruPylu8O6IUgyY2smIs/4a206e8d63dfab7b304311e6534e7615/img-7184jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6MxruPylu8O6IUgyY2smIs/4a206e8d63dfab7b304311e6534e7615/img-7184jpg.jpg) I'm sat on the train on the way in from Southend today after seeing a Charlie's grandparents for dinner and the sunrise has me really looking forward to a change, not just in temperature but in lifestyle too. With the wedding over we've finally got time to decorate our house and concentrate more on doing things differently. I want to try and make the most out of living in London now and see different things. Maybe go to some more galleries or events or just take walks with no destination and explore. Hope you'll be seeing more of that all soon! [![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1uASpqjYzWoMuI4eAE2uAu/2f250cc396bf276ba6ec5f378f3785c2/img-7191jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1uASpqjYzWoMuI4eAE2uAu/2f250cc396bf276ba6ec5f378f3785c2/img-7191jpg.jpg)

Post wedding you're supposed to send thank you cards to all your guests right? Well our wedding was hardly a normal one so we thought we'd be a little different and give our guests one final chuckle in the form of a thank you video. I thought I'd share it with you too as it's the first proper video I've edited alone. It took us about an hour of filming and quite a few more hours of editing to create. I like to think that it was well worth the effort and fun for everyone to look back on. I'd like to experiment more with videos and editing so watch this space. The video says it all but thank you to everyone who helped to make our day so memorable. We've had such good feedback on the day and a lot of people have said it was the best wedding they've been too.  We'd planned out so much before meaning we could be laid back on the day and the run up. Nothing was too much of an effort and even though we made more work for ourselves by making our own table plan and photo booth we really didn't mind - about 5pm the day before I was casually painting the table plan in the garden! We left things a bit loose on the day too meaning we could mix around the order of things like the first dance and the bouquet toss. It wouldn't have worked if we didn't have such flexible caterers and photographer. Absolutely everyone was so happy and smiley all day! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TldyjMknmjs#action=share Aaaaannnnddddd the outtakes - because we wouldn't be completely serious! .... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m7wYEvCiWIA#action=share

seoDescription.en-GB: Our special way of saying a big thank you to everyone who made our wedding as incredibly as it was.

title.en-GB: Date Night at the Millennium Hotel

wordpressContent.en-GB: We've found that as Charlie and my weeks get booked up we hardly have a night together so we've set a Thursday evening as date night. It's the one night of the week where we know we should be seeing each other, even if it just means we both get home on time and cook together. To celebrate Charlie getting a new job I'd been thinking of places to take him for dinner, luckily we were invited to the Millennium Hotel in Gloucester Road to try out their [Italian restaurant](http://www.millenniumhotels.co.uk/millenniumbaileys/dining/olives-restaurant.html) and have a few glasses of fizz. ![Champagne](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3R4zRcdhB6G4me8Ei2Wsgw/b5baf19ca17eae2772a8f1154f5f5f88/champagne.jpg) The hotel had some refurbishment going on so we took a sneaky peek into one of the new suites. These stairs were pretty impressive but luckily they have a lift to get you up there!   [![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3udWWUrd8IGIYMIaQwYKcY/69c419553a7559200539b226058dbf58/img-7305-0jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3udWWUrd8IGIYMIaQwYKcY/69c419553a7559200539b226058dbf58/img-7305-0jpg.jpg)  The suite had anything you'd need in a mini house including this funky mirror... [![Charlie & I ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5P7pl605BCqyWWUQ88gqEA/937ea0346e4eb599f9c35a728e1b57d5/charlie-i.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5P7pl605BCqyWWUQ88gqEA/937ea0346e4eb599f9c35a728e1b57d5/charlie-i.jpg) I had to refrain from jumping on the bed and I was quite tempted to run myself a bath but thought that might be a bit much so we made our way down the giant staircase and into dinner where we sat down to a glorious three course meal. ![Bath](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3r1zmBh036gwcwgkQco04K/72e96ffeb191519d7161d6659dd541ac/bath.jpg) Over wine we were able to try out a selection of the starters although if I had to pick a favourite it would be the cold meat selection. [![Starters](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4grJaitW2A4Isy8Ym66YYy/eddd3ab10ef4e0fc2ad2417141f06a6c/starters.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4grJaitW2A4Isy8Ym66YYy/eddd3ab10ef4e0fc2ad2417141f06a6c/starters.jpg) [![Starters](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7tNTFtCazY6gMGCMwcaEQe/0152d758a0c9767cf858cf0a59d53e26/starters.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7tNTFtCazY6gMGCMwcaEQe/0152d758a0c9767cf858cf0a59d53e26/starters.jpg)I always get a little stuck picking Italian food. Choosing a pasta dish is hard as I want to taste most of them! It's also something we're pretty good at making at home so I went for salmon - something I don't usually cook, salmon. I made the right choice! It was so beautifully presented with a beetroot sauce. I like to think that your first taste is taken by your eyes so presentation for me is one of the most important aspects of a meal.     [![Salmon](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/9g5T6ToxfUAyOaosYEmiA/114129b752d4126f5069380459dd2cc3/salmon.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/9g5T6ToxfUAyOaosYEmiA/114129b752d4126f5069380459dd2cc3/salmon.jpg) Charlie went for the steak which he loved. I could also tell he was super impressed with the waiters who clearly knew a lot about the wine they were serving. Of course we had to try both red and white! [![Steak](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6KjIHTsBr2I0SykY2OqGqe/0f129ec33575134ac7ddba03b00ea527/steak.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6KjIHTsBr2I0SykY2OqGqe/0f129ec33575134ac7ddba03b00ea527/steak.jpg)[![Wine](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/20O5nLbI4Ikaycue46Q0u4/267493f5ebf948d2ad34c7bae5338e3c/wine.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/20O5nLbI4Ikaycue46Q0u4/267493f5ebf948d2ad34c7bae5338e3c/wine.jpg) As desserts were served the chef came out to tell us a little more about his menu and run through the desserts. I really enjoyed the fact that he looks for local connections in his ingredients. Although I'm not usually a dessert person the presentations were so pretty I had to try some. The apple and chestnuts strudel with calvados sauce was my favourite followed by the white chocolate and lavender crème brûlée in close second.  ![Dessert](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2szMMVvgWcuGiASUY8mQwu/ac108cc5d2c195ec1fbadd3b7761f4a1/dessert.jpg) The Millennium hotel was really cute. The restaurant doesn't really feel like you were in a hotel. It's quite small with dim lighting which takes it away from feeling like something too generic.

seoDescription.en-GB: Charlie and I celebrated date night with a three course meal at the Millennium Hotel and a cheeky look around the suites!

title.en-GB: A weekend in Florence and Pisa

wordpressContent.en-GB: I'd been planning this surprise with one of our groomsmen, Lewis, since August. As far as Charlie knew we were heading off for a weekend in Amsterdam as a wedding present- we were actually going to Florence, somewhere top on Charlie's travel list. Lewis is not the best organiser so Charlie was worried when he hadn't asked for our passports or told us any details. He had no idea! Once we got to Stansted we ring Lewis who excitedly told us the news that we were off for a weekend of culture and delicious food and wine. ![Pisa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1gGgn7T7AwoQ6mOigMkOs8/3121f24c4fef2205322bc96375e4d2e5/pisa.jpg) We found that the flights were about a third cheaper if we flew into Pisa so stayed there the first night. Everyone had warned me that there wasn't much to see and they were right. After taking a few snaps of the leaning tower, we had breakfast nearby before catching the train to Florence. It's only an hour away so if you're in either of those places make sure to visit the other. ![Viki in Pisa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1PPnbZGTb2e0yUWI6acOCw/4859b9b690db942e23ae6b8719c88bf6/viki-in-pisa.jpg)![Pisa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/hVgcAPSPLiykUwGKWwsCK/e0713d856e4314ee562eb91cf53422da/pisa.jpg) I had booked us an Airbnb for our stay - I'd never used them before but it worked out really well. I don't see why you would book a generic hotel when you can stay in such niche little places. On arrival our host presented us with a map which he went through and explained the best places to visit around town. We decided to have a wonder around on our first night and ended up on a street he had recommended enjoying pizza and a bottle or two of Chianti. [![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1FIIR0oaKo8eKGkEUEUm8M/af19fdef4039debe457efb262f8189ae/florence.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1FIIR0oaKo8eKGkEUEUm8M/af19fdef4039debe457efb262f8189ae/florence.jpg)![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1z54FBmTRGQasy6m6Q0eqE/cdd4849f19793b0d76f6853e45273dc1/florence.jpg) On Sunday we walked to a piazza and saw some of the statues there. We made a bit of a mistake having breakfast on the piazza which ended up quite expensive. It's a little harder to find breakfast down a back street in Florence so I'd recommend planning ahead slightly more than we did. You can always get a feel of the price based on an expresso which ranges from €1-4\. After breakfast we took a walk across the famous bridge and found ourselves in another square looking at a church and market. I thought it was strange that there was the odd beer bottle lying around before I realised that we were in the square where the locals hung out on a Saturday night. [![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3XFxb72RIQCQIIGIgIYUAq/3caa163a63df23e8a058f30a6b0dabea/florence.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3XFxb72RIQCQIIGIgIYUAq/3caa163a63df23e8a058f30a6b0dabea/florence.jpg) Charlie wanted a cold meats and cheese lunch so we stumbled upon this cute little shop which had room out the back for you to sit. It has to be one of our funniest meals as the waitress was a little old lady who didn't speak a word of English. After pointing at a few things and guessing what the menu meant we managed to get our meats and cheese - as well as another bottle of Chianti! The couple next to us were less than impressed though and quickly said yes to her suggestion of lasagne, wolfed down the food and were off. They might have looked at it as a bad lunch but for us it was more of an linguistical adventure. [![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2Hco4WwzGUww6eqQEeW6SE/1d7d47184255e00d8fabb9502425542b/img-7383jpg.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2Hco4WwzGUww6eqQEeW6SE/1d7d47184255e00d8fabb9502425542b/img-7383jpg.jpg) Afterwards we went up to the [Pitti Palace](https://www.polomuseale.firenze.it/en/musei/pitti.php?m=palazzopitti). We had planned to see the sunset over by the statue of David and didn't think we had time to do both the palace and the gardens so opted in for the gardens. Our step count of the day was off the scale! We climbed so many hills and stairs over the space of that garden we definitely ended up working off our lunch. ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1PAHDIEfuA8ICO06oqCsQ2/e234e6c965fbb309f5b291d904ee44d2/florence.jpg)![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6KdNgmNEaWUKaqWiKWMgsE/8bae4257b2bdbfda08403cf648e96a43/florence.jpg) We found a side exit to the gardens and it was another uphill climb to get to the statue of David. Unfortunately it was so cloudy we didn't see much of a sunset but at least we had a great view of the city. ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4cCY6H477aaWQIiG4sUKWk/fd9451a614dd5f7519caad631acaa61c/florence.jpg) We were recommended to try out [Lungarno](http://www.lungarnobistrot.it/) for dinner and it turned out to be my favourite meal in Florence. The restaurant didn't seem too busy and I get the feeling that it was fairly new but all the staff were very happy and at tentative to your meal. I loved the fact that we were greeted with a glass of prosecco - a really cute touch. We both wanted to share the Florentine steak so opted to share scallops for starters. I have no idea how Italians can go for dinner and have a starter, pasta and then a main the food is delicious but we just couldn't eat that much! ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6rpvAzK6g88agu8socC4CC/1cdd936565c5d6e364c1187d287408a4/florence.jpg) ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4xL6A8lZqgasESiiKicC2i/06a94eec32ac267f5b8b689f11bc4349/florence.jpg) Monday was an early start. We planned to get to the Duomo before the crowds and were lucky enough to get to the top around 8.30 when the mist was just beginning to rise. It's well worth a visit and a quick climb to the top. ![Duomo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3s99kaZx72yeeq0gOO4Co4/697e00328cad980c7ad6d6ace6af882d/duormo.jpg) ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6B8sL44arYKksWIEaU842A/311321e440e358dc35aa8609be60d9ee/florence.jpg)![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5FGPnIWa9aieueG4oqK8CS/5ecfebc61f87815dc8a5e8a3e570a0d9/florence.jpg) We were in and out the Duormo quicker than we thought which meant we had some time to spare. After ticking off pretty much everything on our tourist list I was more than happy to wonder the streets. We took a look at the leather markets, sat in a park, accidentally ended up in the university and of course had another long lunch! ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3slTdyHys0G4OwEASikoOI/4e67f1afb79230a8d098a8bae258c518/florence.jpg) At 2.30 we headed off to [Di Vinci Alive](http://www.davincialive.it/the-exhibition/) which was only on until 2nd November. I was taught about Di Vinci in uni but I hadn't taken too much of the details in so it was good to spend some time just learning about his life and the amount he accomplished. At the end there was a giant projection of his quotes and work across the walls of a church. We sat for around half an hour just letting it all soak in. We headed across to the food market afterwards. Downstairs is laid out like a usual street market with open fish counters and meat delis but upstairs is full of seating and people enjoying a coffee or glass of wine. It had a really cool vibe to it even though there didn't seem to be much going on. I don't think I'd go there for food but it's worth having a glass of wine and taking a look at the stalls. Charlie got into man mode with his admiration of the meats. [![Market](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5x9xwDEwNi68cqmskKaKAo/c3364e9227a075e759157efca783d96a/market.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5x9xwDEwNi68cqmskKaKAo/c3364e9227a075e759157efca783d96a/market.jpg) After a quick outfit change, we headed out to our last meal. We'd booked a really lovely restaurant but it didn't quite beat our meal the night before. For some reason I couldn't stop putting things into song as we walked there, I can't sing in the slightest so this wasn't a good move but it made the evening really funny and earned us a few strange looks. We pretty much had one full meal between us sharing breads, pasta and then a chicken dish. [![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2wWl0kxgneIIk0GMWqUUwY/38ed3d5ce58b5037ec98c433d8e38e73/florence.jpg)![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4Wk5lZAwDSS42CAU6kWa6Y/9ffd86f2106194f469fddbf2e3954429/florence.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5x9xwDEwNi68cqmskKaKAo/c3364e9227a075e759157efca783d96a/market.jpg) I made sure to book us a late flight on the Tuesday so we had a full day to enjoy. We couldn't leave Florence without a look around the Uffitzi! It took us two hours in total and I think that might be record breaking. At first I couldn't get over the beauty of the rooms as the detail in the artwork. As we went on I got a bit bored of seeing nude statue and painting after painting of Madonna and Jesus - sorry to all the art historians!! I really appreciated the artwork in there but there was just a bit too much for me to take in. I preferred some of the landscape paintings which are displayed nearer the end. Overall the gallery has inspired me to start painting again so watch this space. ![Uffitzi](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/DVQVvulQKOSiM8OMUaY4A/e4c8094b7e154812ac862d49664c384e/uffitzi.jpg) We had our last lunch near the station which of course included pasta, pizza and another bottle of Chianti! Then it was time to catch the train back to Pisa, stop off for some sunshine beers and then head back to rainy England. ![Florence](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7eYa63H8XKyWwgYESk4UoG/8c36ba25556c3d717ff8ccfa44bf73a3/florence.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Our surprise trip to Florence and Pisa to explore the Italian culture.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Last week we went to the annual [Jane Packer Foundation](http://thejanepackerfoundation.com/) Flower Ball. I'd never been to a ball before so wasn't too sure what to expect. But I can tell you that if every ball is like that you can sign me up to the next one now! ![Viki](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7A9o62aMyQWiUi2ICkgMcI/d38a9f00688b972564ddab8a34af7667/viki.jpg) It was hosted at the Hurlingham club and as we arrived the staff were smiling and handing us champagne and corsages. I had expected the room to be full of beautiful flowers and I wasn't disappointed. Each table has a different tree coming from the center. Apparently the staff had been working on the set up all day and the effort they put into it really shone through. ![IMG_0776](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1NEPA0on4cYCwwg6kScwEu/f5453b98ae767a45b35be771102ac02c/img-0776.jpg)![centrepiece](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5k4WJvdrwsGOOoMmAuMSSu/f64894e3c4a873faf48e54247fcde46f/centrepiece.jpg) Dinner passed in a glorious blur and I was too wrapped up in our conversations to actually take any photos - except of the menu of course! ![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7CBkbXNvUWkoqYoe0YMOUS/af46111134fc2f3d0b24f17d1e798b9e/img-7558jpg.jpg) Our table was nonstop laughter as we begin the silent auction and it didn't show any signs of slowing down an auctioneer from Sotheby's took the stage for the main auction. Our table ended up winning (I'm not sure if you would call it winning?!) three out of the four lots and were complained on our auctioning skills. Then it was time to hit the dance floor and try out the photo-booth. ![Photobooth](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/DCaotILOLIsS6kk2EYy0q/7dc71b3cbcda74a88bab37eff62a5e71/photobooth.jpg)   I'm so pleased that I had the opportunity to go to the ball and help raise some money for the Jane Packer foundation. There was so much energy in the room and you could tell that everyone there had a brilliant time no thanks to Gary and his team. Although I was only able to meet Jane a handful of times, Gary and his family mean a lot to me and my time in Suffolk. This is precisely the reason I chose [Jane Packer](http://www.jane-packer.co.uk/) for my wedding flowers back in [July](http://vikibell.com/wedding-day-part-i/). Congratulations to Gary and the wonderful Jane Packer team who put on a magnificent event. ![Jane Packer](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5f0EYidMbYUgWaKsIcco4w/422ef8d84fa41497866f15fc868d9ffa/jane-packer.jpg)
