seoDescription.en-GB: Jane Packer Foundation Charity Flower Ball. I'd never been to a ball before so wasn't too sure what to expect....

wordpressContent.en-GB: I love Halloween. I love that it falls on a time of year when the leaves are a crunchy autumnal mess and when the nights are getting spookier. I love planning a fancy dress outfit and getting creative with it. And I love seeing how everyone takes on their characters. We were on holiday last year which meant we skipped all that so this year I was determined to make up for it this year. On Friday night Milly, Charlie and I headed into Soho for a spooky game launch. The venue certainly had a halloween feel to it with witches offering themed canapés and suits of armour standing guard. We headed through towards what looked like a Hogwarts classroom to try out making a few potions. Of course we had to try them first! We started off with a smoking vodka concoction which I think was my favourite. ![Smoking Vodka](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6zVSJiHnLGwQkE6euEqAGY/edf26556e4665122c6385e226d1afca5/smoking-vodka.jpg) The second was a rum mix which the mixologist was very excited about as he set it alight and screamed "glitter fire" whilst pouring things over it. You can't really tell from the photo but there was a glitter fire! [![Cocktail](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/29ItJB0HlO6icck404gwsQ/392cd7693c40cd5d4b2bb95d43efe490/cocktail.jpg)](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/IMG_0858.jpg) The third was colour changing. Again the photos don't do it justice so you'll have to take my word for it - it was blue and changed to a purple pink hue. ![Cocktail](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4DGJv7gGOQkw8uUwGo66u0/9329dc2ab30692f957f3b2a634a04c8e/cocktail.jpg) We were then showed this strange mango mix which looks a bit like caviar. It solidifies in a drink and I thought all the balls looked a bit like that scene in Finding Nemo - you know before all Nemo's siblings get eaten. ![Cocktail](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2EHF4PnqsAocwaUAy6i6Q0/f7b4fcd0d28f3aa09b44932d71fd92b5/cocktail.jpg) ![Cocktail making](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2uqMHZ3v24A4QkMwKQAeoW/eeda657464168a07cf85e689fa903e94/cocktail-making.jpg) The cocktails weren't just spooky for Halloween - they were all themed around King's new Bubble Witch Saga 2 game. We had a chance to play it and Charlie and I got a bit competitive against each other - although I still don't think he knows I cheated! ![Bubble Witch](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5XfKTbGpXiOiqiAUCmUkk8/1405a58283778f22d679cbcd3628f861/bubble-witch.jpg) The game also inspired some Halloween makeovers which we tried out. These were based on some of the characters and made us look great for our dinner at Grillshack afterwards. ![Makeup](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3jJwympNL20C0AuM6uuOs0/75819c5bd81d0fe18527431e040bf575/makeup.jpg) ![Face paint](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6BWRnI5VYcCkOUgkQ0Yme8/67dcad0e073f9ca88a26f3deffb9b8b8/face-paint.jpg) On Saturday we had booked a Halloween banquet at [Pond](http://pond-dalston.com/) in Dalston but hadn't quite got around to planning our outfits. After breakfast I found myself surrounded by our fancy dress options as we decided on scary clowns. After a quick dash to the market to get Charlie a pair of lovely women's trousers, we went about creating out looks. We used spray paint, material, old clothes, pillows, hair spray, face paint and of course a fair amount of fake blood. This was the result... ![Fancy dress](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3cnREDjghG2a6KwA88SUAS/63d1764785496f067ae85c2ff134e316/fancy-dress.jpg)![Fancy Dress](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2dKZg7VD60KyiyCigeEywU/3a1324ad3e3ba4f7d4903be47db81811/fancy-dress.jpg) Heads turned as we walked in and someone even wanted her photo taken with us. Matt came as Patrick Bateman which was worryingly accurate and his brother Rob was Morty from Rick and Morty. Whenever we do fancy dress together we each slightly become our character meaning that at conversation breaks Charlie and I started doing a spooky dance staring at someone else, Matt grinned like a mad man and rob acted drunk (although I'm not too sure how much acting was involved by the end of the night) [![Patrick Bateman ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/21Sn9PUnW4SWCEkiwYGaE4/583c988c1a172581ff1c9bdfb8dc04b7/patrick-bateman.jpg)![Scary Clowns](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ncZCd06cESWwcOEISWSKk/de865882424b1ebc725f045f908f8ae1/scary-clowns.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ncZCd06cESWwcOEISWSKk/de865882424b1ebc725f045f908f8ae1/scary-clowns.jpg) On Sunday after we'd washed out all the face paint we headed to my Nan and Grandad's for a big Sunday roast. Just what we needed. ![Sunday roast ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6S9YYhD87CsA6WSCsecEyM/12707d58b12b89cb1f85c6b9149f7821/sunday-roast.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Our London Halloween adventures as we explored Soho and Dalston dressed as witches and clowns.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Hannah and I skipped out of work early on Friday and headed to City Airport. We were off to Rotterdam. I hadn't flown from City before so was excited to see a new airport. It's pretty much how you'd expect - full off city workers going home for the weekend but at least we could grab a few beers before our flight. ![Airport beer](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1HlLoyBOyksGWEgaouC8GC/ffd55ea84b5d0edeb59d2ad6247aede4/airport-beer.jpg) The flight took no time at all, before they had even finished the drinks service we were already descending. We still only got to Cat's quite late so decided to chill with a few glasses off fizz around the fire. ![Champagne](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6FRArfZh1Cs8sO0oKU8miY/9e6989a807164664f13b432fed5d65b2/champagne.jpg) After a continental breakfast on Saturday morning we jumped on some bikes and headed out for a tour of the city. We started off in the Kralingse Bos, which had a lake with a great view of Rotterdam. I can imagine how lovely it is during the summer but it was the perfect place to wipe the cobwebs away with an autumn walk through the trees. ![Park](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7YZG95nNG8mEgW26m6EsW/91aba3191e869bb61c89b28a79f737da/park.jpg) Afterwards we were in need of coffee so headed to central Rotterdam and the Saturday market. We were told by our trusty tour guide that the market had been there as long as she can remember selling everything from vegetables to bras! We stopped off to get a Stroopwafel – yes, yes it is bigger than Hannah’s head! ![Stroopwafel](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/14fh3CX14iGqiYS0CkEIsM/81ccc184c1459a55a2f195e1f246372b/stroopwafel.jpg) Then we headed into the relatively new market hall which is surrounded by flats and has a really decorative roof. Inside you can find all sorts of delicious foods and drinks. Of course I got a little excited by the tomato stall. ![Tomatoes](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2A2aGYFU0sGWouOMSsaEKw/32a27c47add90fae3441983d1a745056/tomatoes.jpg)![Market](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/TowSpGPUmy8qiqYyOuK2q/772ba55409245f1360ce3ca9d6afd6f4/market.jpg) We jumped back on the bikes and across the Erasmus Bridge to the south part of Rotterdam. I loved the old buildings over here so got a little trigger happy with my camera. Cat's dad had told us that there were very few old buildings in the city as it was so heavily bombed in the war so I wonder if these were some of them? ![Bridge](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5NCvADnpMAMUowag2GIiIu/0df0619f423c397fe7d1cd91ed2d1a2d/bridge.jpg)![Rotterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4qXUkeNzb2ou4cKc4K6oOU/b72e3166e8758a5dec2b1838ac42afb1/rotterdam.jpg)   After distracting ourselves with the buildings we went into the Fenix Food Factory which is a tiny little food market next to a small brewery in what looks like an old warehouse. We bought a cheese platter and tried out a few of the beers. ![Cheese](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4rP5klplpCAsICY2mwwcGi/90dd07cd09a3630164a7b0b3033a21b1/cheese.jpg) These beers didn't quite compare to what we tried when we got home however. Cat's dad told us a story of the best beer in the world and how on his first attempt at getting some he rung up over 300 times. Have you heard of Westvleteren? Well it's brewed by monks in a Belgian monastery and you're only allowed to buy some if you ring up at a certain time. _IF_ you manage to get through you're given a time slot to arrive for collection of two crates only and you have to give the number plate of the car you'll be driving. It's all very strict so once you finally get hold of the beer you don't really want to share it - unless it's with us! Cat's dad was really kind and opened up two bottles for us to try. These were the Westvleteren 12 (10.2%!) but there's the Westvleteren Blonde and 8 as well. The 12 is more popular but whilst we were there we found that they were selling the 8 on Tuesday - luckily Cat volunteered to ring to try and get some – it _ONLY_ took her 70 minutes to get through this time! You may need to take my word for it but they tasted amazing. ![Beer](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3SRw2BHStWAEiISWQi2YYM/5db069ce314bcdef2301f53415a5849d/beer.jpg) Best beer in the world down it was time to head to Amsterdam. Cat's brother Robert was having a leaving party for a flat mate so we used it as our excuse to visit.A few years ago the boys had been asked to move out for a month whilst converse took over their home. They didn't know too much of what went on but they were left with these incredible artworks all over the wall. I couldn't get over how great they looked. The house is in need of a bit of TLC but that brought out these paintings so much more. Words can't really explain so here's a few photos: ![Amsterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2zMXD42LeMYOYSCoqmOIYM/04ecf30611749e04ae7e0226c48ebf64/amsterdam.jpg)![Amsterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2sMX5RQkggwUOeCewgg8Ym/ddf8d6223a6b3044736a1d84e24fe89d/amsterdam.jpg)   The next day Robert took us all on a walking tour of Amsterdam. We went down the antique shopping streets, saw the Dam (the main square) and of course had a gander at the red light district, each time crossing over the famous little bridges and canals. ![Amsterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/13vZRziah0cowwG8ysOGA0/2acd656be6901ceccea574e87e83fc79/amsterdam.jpg) Then it was time to head back to Rotterdam for our last evening. After a cheeky nap on the train and a quick sauna at home, we were ready to jump back on our bikes and head into town. One of Cat's favourite restaurants in Rotterdam happens to be Moroccan so we headed there. I was a little too excited by the prospect of food and all the crazy decorations around me to take many photos but it was delicious. If you're ever in Rotterdam I highly recommend The Bazar. [![IMG_7775](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1xqNAsl0cckcIcwkG4aaUI/0358a9ba4526705e7cce4396e4cdcf38/img-7775.jpg)](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1xqNAsl0cckcIcwkG4aaUI/0358a9ba4526705e7cce4396e4cdcf38/img-7775.jpg) The next morning we headed out for our early flight to get back to work on time. The best part about flying at this time had to be that we were flying with the sunrise. ![Sunrise](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6GZLGEbafYKkAS4soy2ksM/6d1fcca123d34d807d2e44e97b177dc0/sunrise.jpg)

seoTitle.en-GB: A weekend in Rotterdam - Viki Bell

seoDescription.en-GB: A weekend with friends sightseeing in Rotterdam and Amsterdam.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
It's usually a struggle for me to decide what to cook for dinner. By the time I get back and start thinking about food I either don't have all the ingredients or it will take ages to make what I planned. I normally end up Googling a recipe and make it up from there. That's exactly what this was as I fancied some white fish but didn't have my usual ingredients. **Ingredients: **

*   Half onion
*   Handful olives
*   4 cloves of garlic
*   Splash of milk
*   White fish
*   Crushed peas
*   Half onion
*   Balsamic splash
*   Cayenne pepper
*   Asparagus and broccoli

First roughly chop half an onion and a few handfuls of olives, add four peeled cloves of garlic and season. Next put your white fish into a small dish and scatter the other ingredients on top. I used frozen Coley but any type of white fish will do. Add a dash of milk, cover with foil and pop in the oven for about 30 minutes on a medium heat - I cooked it on low as I wasn't sure when we would be eating but 30 minutes on about 170 will work just as well. Just double check the recommended time on the packaging of the fish you've chosen. ![Fish](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/iWLJmDWINMwci8WYAig2K/3d1cafcc2b7da5d9581652c3738598a6/fish.jpg) When it was almost done start on the veg. Again this all depends on your timings but you could do the peas ahead of time and pop them in the bottom of the oven to stay warm. Start by frying half a chopped onion as you microwave some frozen peas (quantity is up to you). Once both are pretty cooked add them together and roughly mash them. Then put them back in the frying pan for a few minutes with a splash of balsamic and a sprinkling of cayenne pepper for a bit of a kick. ![Peas](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2HmGD1bfe80AgSEyySgC4y/227e9cce464de22fd83a1a072d395519/peas.jpg) As you're doing this you can be steaming other vegetables. I had asparagus and broccoli in the fridge so I steamed these and then fried them off slightly to give them a bit of crispiness. Finally just lay everything out nicely on a plate (of throw it on as I did) and serve with a bottle of wine. ![White fish ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/29P9kotwRGIa8aUYkwUgW2/f1a5eccd0810e2d8641c3ae5beeb4f3a/white-fish.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A speedy post work recipe you can conjure up with the contents of your kitchen and enjoy in 30 minutes. You can adopt this for any type of white fish.

wordpressContent.en-GB: The past few weeks have been fairly hectic for me and there isn't much sign of slowing down. As I'd been away last weekend Charlie and I decided it was time for a date night and headed off to [Le Mercury](http://www.lemercury.co.uk/) in Islington. It's a little french restaurant that I'm guessing used to be an old town house. The food is relatively cheap for London with main courses around £11 and £5 for starters. I'd rung for a reservation on Friday lunchtime and luckily got one of the last tables so make sure you book. ![Le Mercury ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1qCz711K8Q4KEks6ckckcI/8d2f983db46b3de4b77618f79602717b/le-mercury.jpg) We had the Camembert for starter as Charlie hadn't had it before - I went to Tenerife earlier in the year and had it pretty much every meal time! It wasn't quite as nice as the ones in Tenerife which was a little upsetting, I think having something more in it would have been nicer. I'd try out the other starters next time as there was lots on the menu that looked good. ![Camembert ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3WdaPcsNvW0KYmAemYkSAU/7d1736a2fca63f8bb4964344d2379fa3/camembert.jpg) Our mains more than made up for our poor choice in starter. I went with the Magret de Canard - roast breast of barbary duck, garlic potato purée, savoy cabbage, red wine jus. Charlie chose Suprême de Pintade - roast breast of guinea fowl on garlic potato purée, french beans, green peppercorn sauce. Both tasted divine and were generous portions for the price. The guinea fowl was nice and light which was what Charlie was after whereas my duck was really rich and flavoursome ![Duck](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6ObX6sOqKA6umOGaUISSsg/f2dd07d8ebad0b19cf01d908dce15bcc/duck.jpg)![Guinea Fowl](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6m8FMY3sPKYy2Wwi8wIcw8/ca4439690586e46b46524f7b8fe60fb5/guinea-fowl.jpg) We just about had room for dessert - something we quite often skip but I'm so glad we didn't. I had the Banoffee Pie which always reminds me of the first time I had it with Charlie's dad in Portugal and Charlie had the cheese selection. We had our standard after dinner drinks of Port and an Amaretto. ![Dessert](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5vfoUe1xja8cYamccKcwUw/f7d977a7ce4f97c723f57e7607eec30f/dessert.jpg) ![Candle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/ylUFaIEjMk8Sm2660qAce/8c81dbb028f261850a92f7c9aad58795/candle.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Our date night visit to Le Mercury in Islington - a small french restaurant.

wordpressContent.en-GB: As a bit of a spontaneous trip a few of us decided to try out the new darts place near Mooregate, [Flight Club](http://flightclubdarts.com/). On a Monday night. With champagne. ![Champagne](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1T8YH0SmAcoSS080IqoiKY/ae5d8b1d67cb56470307f3232780679e/champagne.jpg) I've only ever played darts whilst messing around at my grandparents so I wasn't sure what to expect. I thought of it as a bit of an old mans game but Flight Club had jazzed it up a fair amount. As you arrive it looks like a normal bar except there are booths around the wall with games of darts going on. We were taken to our area and shown the controls. The board is electronic so knows where you've hit and the screen above tells you where you should be aiming. I really liked the design of the interface. We took a selfie which comes up when it's your turn. I think my favourite button on the controls was the 'more drink' button which sends a waiter to take your orders. I mean that totally makes sense and isn't just us being lazy right? ![Flight club](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/50SREQQQOkYM8aCmCSQI2K/718274681638905b164dd9fc47146d4e/flight-club.jpg) After taking advantage of the booze and food button (their pizzas were SO GOOD) we started with a game of killer. Like I said, I hadn't played darts properly before and wasn't sure of the rules but got the hang of it pretty quickly. I just struggled getting the dart to go where I wanted luckily I wasn't the only one. The fast paced nature of the game meant even with 8 of us playing you didn't have to wait long for a turn. ![Flight club](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2p3tfAJwwE2uAYAGIio8Y6/96d87bb0182a9904770d011c65d895c8/flight-club.jpg) Whether it was my inner darts champion, the champagne or beginners luck, I was winning half way through. Unfortunately I managed to loose that place pretty quickly in the second half and ended up coming last. Winning or losing it was a really fun night and somewhere I'd recommend trying with a couple of friends.

A simple and tasty dinner you can make for one, two or a whole dinner party. I'd bought some puff pastry a while back as I was planning on making a feta and roasted vegetable pie for a vegetarian friend of mine. Long story short, our plans changed and I wasn't sure what to do with the pastry. I often make chicken pie but with no chicken in the freezer that wasn't an option. Instead I threw together this tasty dinner using the contents of my kitchen. ![Salmon and spinach pie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4hmkhWZ4JOWiOSKAAgEkSU/223c8bc15af8e5282311ddb5d6fd8cdb/salmon-and-spinach-pie.jpg) Chop up one red onion and a few cloves of garlic. Fry these in a little olive oil until the onion begins to lose its colour, then add in a few handfuls of spinach. I defrosted some frozen spinach as it breaks up more easily than fresh and gives a more even flavour. Season, throw in a few handfuls of pine nuts and fry everything off for a few minutes. Meanwhile seal the outsides of your salmon fillets in a separate pan. ![Onion and spinach mix](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2w9qENwLlOE8qYQsGgYm0q/66ed9479c52c679b60f652835d3954fe/onion-and-spinach-mix.jpg)Once all this is heated you can roll out your pastry. I left mine quite thick and square but it depends how many people you're feeding/ how many salmon fillets you're using. Place the salmon in the middle and the spinach mix neatly on top. Fold everything inwards and cover with a beaten egg. Don't forget to puncture the top to let the air out before putting in the oven for about 25 minutes. ![Salmon](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6RypnNPTl6IiEWskwco8E/c8eb1d52abdc9788c801b8f9a16f2225/salmon.jpg)   Once the top is nice and crispy, take it out and serve. I made potato and sweet potato mustard mash and garlic mushrooms to go with it. There you have it, my salmon and spinach pastry. ![Salmon and spinach pie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4VllRueddm0kCGsusYMe6O/e03b08c49fe04c56551b5333c301dd45/salmon-and-spinach-pie.jpg) ![Salmon and spinach pie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2nIR3EwRAcKy42kykwsyei/c8071f948ee417de2b33dfff874bf948/salmon-and-spinach-pie.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A simple and tasty dinner you can make for one, two or a whole dinner party.

title.en-GB: How to make your Christmas gifts a little different

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Whether it's for Christmas or birthdays I always spend ages thinking about the person I'm buying a gift for and asking myself what do they want, what do they do and what can I give them that will make their life easier, better or more enjoyable. I know I covered roughly the questions you should ask yourself in last year's [post](http://vikibell.com/my-guide-to-gifts/) so this year I thought I'd share a few ideas I've come up with or have done before.![Christmas tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3yjTsJbuGkuECSecGAU6Eo/1b97198209f83b50296234a9a3876e8d/christmas-tree.jpg) **Get crafty and make something. ** Why give presents only in December? There are so many things around like BirchBox, Graze or Not Another Bill which send you deliveries each week or month. Why not sign someone up to one of these or put together your own. One idea I had (which I might still use so I'm hoping she doesn't read this!) is a hamper with a present for each month in it - meaning your festive cheer is spread through the year! On their birthday month you might have champagne, a scarf for November when it starts to get cold, a good book or some holiday spending money for the summer. You get the gist. **Make the way you give your presents a little different. ** One year instead of just giving presents like normal we decided to make it into a treasure hunt. We drew a (roughly) to scale map of my parents house and wrote clues to the various hiding places. Somehow it transformed my fifteen year old brother into a giggling kid again and my parents even had massive grins of their faces as they searched the house. I can't say what it is that I'm doing for Charlie this year but I'm planning to do a similar thing but inspired from one of the TV shows we've been watching recently - White Collar. **![Christmas tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2QvnitR3j2sAugQ6KUi4ma/9735c7a4eeec55cc5c7f4eec419b7971/christmas-tree.jpg)** **Get an experience ** Part of Christmas Day is always around the tussle of wrapping paper and the look on someone's face when you surprise them with something special. But what about afterwards? There is so much build up and so much pressure to buy material things but what about something to look forward to? There are lots of things out there to book so here's a few ideas:

*   Theatre tickets
*   A fancy dinner
*   Flights to somewhere
*   A spa break
*   A weekend in London
*   A cooking course
*   A course learning something new
*   Tickets to an exhibition
*   Tickets to an event
*   An IOU for a weekends activities

**Personalise something  ** Now I'm not just talking the normal things like key rings and photo frames. Why not try out making something a little different. Perhaps a personalised cook book with some of the families favourite recipes or custom made deck of cards? For my secret Santa one year I bought a bottle of wine but made a personalised fun label to go over the top. Suddenly it isn't such a dull present. ![Christmas tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6AkDNhxfBmKysKkK6IYQCM/fc8b1d7bcae1d8f28db84903b6575172/christmas-tree.jpg) **Make the way they use it different** In the same way as I put the label on the wine one year, Charlie gave his mum a bottle of wine but with the instructions to enjoy it with a specific friend. This could work with the cheapest presents to the most expensive to cost shouldn't be an issue here. You could give someone a Costa card and tell them to catch up with a specific old friend over coffee. You could give vouchers to a fancy restaurant or hotel stay with the idea that they will get some time away with their partner. Or you might give a present with the instructions to only open it when you think you'll need whats underneath - that way they might not get a present on Christmas day but they will get something later on in the year.   And yes these have been photos of my tree which I'm pretty proud of! ![Christmas tree](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3JGNRLIZRYKAOAaSQwcqaU/395b00892f1e42b6fcfbb3aed66939c6/christmas-tree.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My ideas of how to make your Christmas gifts a little different this year.

wordpressContent.en-GB: I've been thinking about the reasoning behind my blog a lot recently. I want to increase the amount I post but don't want it to seem like a chore. When I first came up with the idea of writing a blog it was to encourage me to get out and enjoy London (and the world) rather than going to the same pubs and places all the time. It has helped massively. There has been times when I've weighed up going home and having an early night but instead I've gone out and had an incredible time doing something different. It's the reason we're off to Germany next week to check out the Christmas markets and it's the reason I've met loads of great people at various blogger events. Writing a blog helps you open your eyes to what's around you and make the most of it all. As Charlie was getting ready to launch my new design this weekend something happened and the blog was gone. I left the room and waited, hoping he could fix it. As I waited I started thinking about it all, it's just words and pictures; I have the memories still in my head. But all that time, all that work and all those stories for people to read. Even if I scroll through my posts I'm amazed at how many I've done and how many snippets of my life I've given out. I decided that yes, I would be upset if it all disappeared and I think I would just have to start again. Blogging has opened my eyes to so many different experiences, people and ways of thinking that it's worth the time and effort. It makes me so happy when someone I'm with mentions a certain post and even if I lost all my readers tomorrow I pretty sure would continue to blog. Saying that, I don't think blogging should be about the comments or the likes or the retweets or the freebies. Blogging should be something that you do for yourself and because you want to share insights with others or reflect on what you've done. This is the reason why, with the new design, you'll no longer find a comments section on here. Blogging isn't about that stats for me, it's about the experiences and enjoyment. ![blog](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ucIWWXJOwKagQqMAIIQ2E/e551db09c5625b613bac4d846adf71ea/blog.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Thoughts on why I blog, what it means to me and what I want to achieve from it.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Shooting is something that Charlie does once a year so I've heard a lot of stories about it. This time I decided to see tag along and experience it. The shoot was organised by Charlie's dad, David and was up near Bury St Edmunds. We caught the train up on Friday evening and arrived at the pub just in time for dinner and to meet everyone. The pub served some really gamey dishes but I stuck with duck parfait (okay that is gamey!) for starter followed by steak. Charlie was a little more adventurous with his starter and opted for pigeon corn dogs. I'd been warned about having to wake up at the crack of dawn but David explained to me how the next day was going to work and luckily it didn't start as early as I'd expected! ![Gun](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3woE0N13naqIyK8okCkKsy/96d5bddf4af50c387acfc44c913a3a72/gun.jpg) We were up and having a big breakfast by 8, before putting on our kit and heading down the road to the shoot. It was held on the land of a big country house and we were all in the back of a trailer called a gun bus which took us between the drives (shoots). We started out by the pond on a duck shoot. There were so many of them but you are told how many you can shoot so once you've done your amount you stop. ![Duck shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3wjF2qmhBYamgAIkWWYK2Q/87ca0a790b0cf3630f59119623905fe4/duck-shooting.jpg) I wasn't sure how I felt about the idea of seeing something die which is one of the reasons I wanted to come along. I had a bit of a wobbly moment when I saw my first duck hit out of the air and die in the water. It seems quite harsh when they don't die straight away but there isn't too much you can do especially when they're bred to be shot. Either way I enjoyed standing on the bridge and shooting with my camera! ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2MAvvVCHyU68uU4G4u8w6e/1c93e0c764fe3bd00ce39b2980701886/shooting.jpg) Next up was pheasant and partridge. This was a lot slower as we had to wait for the beaters to walk about a mile to bring them all in towards us. In a shoot everyone pulls a number out of a hat at the beginning and that dictates where you are in the semi circle of guns. You move up numbers as the shoot goes on so that you each get a turn in each position. I got a little distracted by just looking around the views on this one. It was so nice to be out of London and in the middle of nowhere. ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6lDEYySquQAMW8Oi8kceKq/badd122480f21187837a45c89f644b9a/shooting.jpg) ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/59q3ps4arK264YECQIQUmo/d3940269c97e1908eb3e4c8595306742/shooting.jpg) The third drive was on more of an open space so I could see everyone taking their turns as the pheasants flew overhead. As the beaters walk along they literally beat the bushes and tap the trees to scare the birds and send them towards us. You could see them working their way towards us. They also help to collect all the birds at the end and put them on the back of a truck ready to be made into pâté and what not later on. ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2uZXr8Lc2wGyoKwWiIesK4/0b5bec86ced9f69a647c2cb0162d9d7d/shooting.jpg) Quite a few dogs are around which are trained to help collect the animals. In this particular drive the dogs were aching to do their own hunting and jumped forwards as soon as a pheasant landed on the ground. They were all so well trained and immediately ran back to their owners when called. We also had Charlie.... ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4r7bS2e2bKw4Ka6IWUCumU/5d2e8abb88d8249a66b3934b4edf405b/shooting.jpg) After this drive we stopped for elevensies which was sausages rolls and either a sloegasm (sloe gin and champagne) or Norfolk nog (half whisky, half baileys). Apparently this helps you stop shaking the gun if you're really cold! ![Elevensies](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6MGVxuddjqSM8G4uIUKY0c/82d74e0896bf9cf4c087ef1ce52c53ea/elevensies.jpg) On the third drive I had a go at shooting and with the help of David's directions I managed to hit a pheasant. They came out so quickly from the bushes that you hardly have time to raise the gun and take aim. I had had a go at clay shooting before but this was a lot more fun as its so quick and unpredictable. I'd got my one hit so I was satisfied and passed the gun back for the last drive. ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7K9XfisFEI2qaCMeKmW0M8/f3814d0e2b61d94a0c19bb406ff3d861/shooting.jpg) This was my favourite. We were nearby the giant landowners house (mansion?!) and there were two rather inquisitive horses keeping an eye on us. The sun was dipping lower and the trees seemed to have so much colour to them. We were behind all the other guns so could walked up and down which meant I was able to watch everyone at once and get lots of different photo angles. ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6kjVI5Z040UIsW8AqkMIAK/3862ccf104d27d5ac89c166434b3ac5d/shooting.jpg) ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7FTeugbkU8Io0Y4KSE6Ygc/d61866a5be26eb12058bf4f40954d01c/shooting.jpg) ![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5feOpGj9tuqweIkI22uuSO/824b89ae37658c52ee01fe8bc47df2e9/shooting.jpg) The sun started to dip even lower so it was back on the gun bus and time for lunch at the farmers house. Everyone gets a chance to take some of the birds they had shot. Charlie and I took back a brace of ducks which we made dinner with on the Tuesday afterwards. The extra game gets sold to restaurants or shipped to France where it's made into pâté so it all gets used up.![Shooting](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6lIVRSpnDGimWq2CuyIOm6/f1295b7917b452a0e44fa9da5a5ef83d/shooting.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Heading off to Busy St. Edmunds for a weekend of game shooting. This was my first shoot so I was intrigued to see how it all worked.

title.en-GB: A Weekend Visiting The German Christmas Markets

wordpressContent.en-GB: Another month another weekend break. This time we decided that the German Christmas markets were a must see and booked some last minute flights to Germany. Past Viki decided to play a mean trick on present Viki by booking flights leaving Gatwick at 6am. It was an early start.   We landed in Munich about 9am and after dropping our bags headed straight to Mariplatz - central Munich to look around the markets. I love all the little huts the stalls are in and it didn't seem too busy - thankfully. Charlie has been to Munich a few times before and knew exactly where to take me for lunch - Hofbrauhaus. It seemed to be a good mix of locals and tourists and the long tables give it a good atmosphere as everyone talks together. We shared a sausage platter and Pork knuckle, I think my favourite was the pork knuckle as I'm not as much of a fan of the typical hot-dog type sausage. Give me a Cumberland any day! *queue sausage joke*. Of course a stein of beer is a must. And so it begins.... ![Beer](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/TZEyypC9oGCgss06IQQWU/cb72bcebefb616f4c0e37644b81dd5e3/beer.jpg) After we had a look around the other markets in central Munich. We'd been told to visit the medieval market and have a typical drink there made up of mulled wine with a shot of rum and and sugar cube which is on fire - very warming! ![IMG_1469](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/ySMGBoAIs8Yi8UQ6kgM8w/8fc33248a3fd442d1de668bc13e20667/img-1469.jpg) Next we took a stroll around the English gardens where we saw people surfing in the river - very chilly. It was a really nice walk and very pretty as the sun was setting. I'd love to come back in the summer and chill in the sunshine. ![English Gardens](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5x84ztEZ7aYEQ2Mas8o4cm/7717a11850bf5f1973250d03f3c540b0/english-gardens.jpg) It had been a long day but we wanted to make the most of it so went off to the last market of the day, a more alternative one called Tollwood. This was my favourite market in Germany, it feels like a festival with giant tents and the lighting at night is amazing. There was a theme of recycling and waste which meant there was loads of mini exhibitions to explore as well as the usual stalls and bars. ![Tollwood](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/54OG6a1UJqOsqKyiIqQQAg/f327c5d17a9e1636c785f48a3f92d875/tollwood.jpg) ![Tollwood](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/C8Zahgt5D2mwss08SSWIw/a451153849b46bd36eb401108ce8f894/img-1524.jpg) On Saturday we had a bit of a lie in and got the train to Nuremberg to see their Christmas market. It's supposed to be one of the best and it definite lived up to expectations. We managed to get most of our presents there and were done in time for lunch -speed shopping! ![Nuremberg ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/67xeoAMsk8gG00SM8yEY6q/3d1dc3c645e85c4a870ee6b51b3b1a49/nuremberg.jpg) ![Christmas market](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6Mahw4S5Z6qcQq8GCi6as0/c939a7bf7ae5c3f434fefeaf9bca0094/img-1544.jpg) After we took a walk around the city but we didn't feel like doing anything touristy so caught the train home in order to have a more relaxed dinner back in Munich. A friend had told us that Italian was a must whilst in Munich as there are so many Italians living there. Afterwards we found ourselves at a jazz bar. If you're in Munich take a look at the Jazz scene as there seems to be bars all over the place. ![Jazz bar](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1y9KjU43ys6CmIyQUOmIsa/11d168ff54191e1f3770e8c32460abfd/jazz-bar.jpg) On Sunday we found ourselves on another train heading to Salzberg. I'd never been to Austria so was keen to tick off another country and get another shot glass (I collect them). Both Salzberg and Nuremberg were only around 1.5 hours away from Munich so worth a trip.   We hadn't really planned what to do once we got to Salzberg other than see the market so, surprise surprise, we headed there first. It was a similar kind of layout to the German ones but there seemed to be less variety of different things. Of course there's a lot of fluffy hats, Christmas decorations and wooden carvings. I thought the Christmas decorations were a lot nicer here as they were more white and silver and seemed to reflected the chill in the air. ![Salzberg](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5ur7Os6Mx2AOw6eaO48we8/1262585db7b9641e979d11f15bcd9e33/salzberg.jpg) We paused to ask a shopkeeper for a lunch recommendation and we were really happy when we found ourselves in a sort of pub made up of shared tables. We both chose chicken schnitzel which is a typical dish. For some reason I'd assumed it was a kind of sausage but it's actually just flattened, breaded meat. Paired with beer of course. ![Schnitzel](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5GLY3vcBziImSEgCcYQ2sg/aa87fffbf39098178493eff51131325f/schnitzel.jpg) We got chatting to two Americans over lunch and they were keen to take the gondola up the mountain. The only issue was time. We raced there and managed to catch the last one up meaning we didn't have too long to play in the snow. If we missed the last one down it was a long walk!! It was well worth it. The views were incredible. I only wish we'd been able to stay up there to fully watch the sunset. ![Salzberg](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2feekgN9fGeasIMciYC4Kg/41dd5766abc5e79c6ecf59dd24fcc493/salzberg.jpg)   ![Salzberg](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2ixhI3R9oE6IqMGUGugG6q/f93c7429c2cd78adac0640373d3827eb/salzberg.jpg)![Salzberg](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3eIKKxOUyI8wGmseeAo8ow/35905a7323b7f24610b94da118ddd172/salzberg.jpg)     Afterwards we headed back to Munich. Charlie fancied a Chinese (very cultured!!) and we found this tiny one with a little old lady who was really excited to see us. She gave us amazing service and the food was delicious. Exactly what we needed as we were shattered!! ![Chinese ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1Q4uyxbQwEyGeca0SsmqQC/4d738511fce647f4df37795351268bcf/chinese.jpg) Our last day. We got up early and found a cute little coffee shop for breakfast. Charlie, hater of coffee, even had a cappuccino. Then we took it slow with a walk around town, a few last beers at the Hofbrauhaus and then lunch with friends. I really wanted to go back to Tollwood which was near where we stayed so we managed to fit in a final mulled wine before heading off for our flight. ![Hofbrauhaus](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6lrki6xsKAAiYsugGQaO0K/571fb87aa06a17663a5cf2b9c605fa08/hofbrauhaus.jpg) If you get a chance next year try and take a trip over to the German markets. It really gets you in the festive mood and it a great place to some different Christmas presents. ![Munich](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5iPhk2DnMcysSK0sawI68K/06c767d35e2fdc84dc58e36bfd1b56f8/munich.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A weekend visiting the German Christmas markets and exploring Munich and Nuremberg with a quick trip to Salzberg, Austria thrown in.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I quite often watch or listen to TED talks when I'm eating or have a bit of spare time on my hands. Each is quite short which is good if you're in a bit of a breakfast rush before work or just want to distract yourself for a while. So far each one I've watched has inspired me in some way or another. I'll quite often pick out themes that interest me such as happiness or the arts but I'm going to try and push myself to watch and learn new things through them in 2016\. Anyway, the reason for this post is because as I sat eating my breakfast this morning, surrounded by all the unpacking we have to do from Christmas, I was inspired. I was inspired to ignore the unpacking (very easy!) and take some time to write this post. It's so easy to get into the swing of normal things. How many of you find yourself doing the same thing - waking up, going to work, seeing some friends and coming home again to sleep then starting again the next morning. Week in week out. But have you ever asked yourself if you are happy with that? _Do you want to learn anything new? Do you want to meet new people to? Do you want to always go to the same bar or restaurant? Are you happy in your routine? Are you happy where you live and work?_ These are all hard questions and it seems like good timing, as people around the world pick their new year resolutions, I've decided mine. It can be as big or as small as I wish and I won't approach the end of January feeling like I've failed it already. I've decided that mine is simply to be happy. That's not saying that I'm not happy right now but it's an encouragement to do more of things that make me smile deep down as well as on the surface. I've had the most ups and downs in 2015 that I've ever had in my life but overall I've had an amazing year: I got married, bought a house and travelled quite a bit - **how am I going to top it in 2016? I'm going to surround myself with happiness.** I've gone a little off topic but why not watch the Ted Talk yourself and see what you take from it? It's by Scott Dinsmore and my favourite quote is:

**"Only thing that limits possibility is now imagination" **

<iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/scott_dinsmore_how_to_find_work_you_love.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>

seoDescription.en-GB: How TED Talks inspire me and my New Year resolution.

wordpressContent.en-GB: As a kid I always used to go to the small theatre near me to see a pantomime at Christmas. As I got older this became slightly different and now I find myself seeking out a weird and wonderful show to see around Christmas/ New Year. Last year we went to the Southbank to see Timber which was all around a family of lumberjacks from Quebec juggling axes and chainsaws. This year I heard about [La Soirée](http://www.la-soiree.com/) and knew we had to go. The description was everything I loved - cabaret, burlesque and circus. As we arrived we were greeted by the familiar sounds of "roll up roll up" coming from a strangely dressed man - it was a real circus! We got inside and looked around and I got even more excited for what was to come. The atmosphere was buzzing and the lighting around the stage was exactly how I had imagined. The stage itself was a small circle platform in the centre of the seats. We were positioned near the walkway for the performers to walk through. ![La Soirée](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/65PFfZJrywge6Y4caKQYia/f2742b2f5da46496dbcb319416d0aedd/la-soiree.jpg) My favourite act of the evening was the two English gents who ended up stripping down and holding each other up by various body parts; whilst smoking a pipe of course. These guys were ripped! They each came on by themselves too, one of them explained the physics of a bubble (who knew?!) in quite a philosophical way and the other coming on to pretty much pole dance. [caption id="attachment_1008" align="aligncenter" width="310"]![La Soirée - English Gents](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/eg.jpg) Image credit: La Soirée[/caption] We could not stop laughing during the performance. From a juggling Freddie Mercury to Asher Treleaven doing 'diablo for the ladies' and reading out sections of erotic tales. There was various people swinging from hoops, dancing on a motorcycles and embarrassing the audience. Another highlight was Captain Frodo who managed to squeeze his body through two tennis racquets. As with all the artists in the show it wasn't just what they did but how they performed it and played to the audience. Frodo for example kept flicking out tiny pieces of silver in a 'ta-da' type fashion throughout his act. I don't want to spoil to much about the show but I would really recommend going along for a hilarious night out. [caption id="attachment_1007" align="aligncenter" width="310"]![La Soirée - Captain Frodo](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/Captain-Frodo-2-photo-by-perou.jpg) Image credit: La Soirée[/caption]   La Soirée is only on until Sunday 17th January so if you fancy seeing all the action for yourself, head down soon! ![La Soirée](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2xFKDgKR6YGkMoSMKMUwIo/69c16cab60ada87d8fa9a3ee2696b69d/la-soiree.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: La Soirée was everything I loved - cabaret, burlesque and circus.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Now don't be worried ‘[Reasons To Stay Alive](http://www.amazon.co.uk/Reasons-Stay-Alive-Matt-Haig/dp/1782115080)’ is a brilliant book by Matt Haig that I’ve just finished. It’s about depression and anxiety and this is why I think everyone should read it... One in five people suffer from depression at some point in their lives. You've probably already met people who have it without even realising. Even with depression, and other mental illnesses for that matter, being so widespread, they are still misunderstood and especially misrepresented in popular media and culture. One of the worst things I’ve ever heard was when an (ex) friend asked another friend who had just confided she was depressed: "but can't you just be happy?" Whether or not it was meant badly, it’s just about the most awful thing she could have responded with. Matt covers how to act around people suffering from depression as well as how to cope with it yourself. Depression is an illness; you can't just decide to be happy the same way you can't just decide to feel well again in the middle of the flu. More and more people are coming forward and asking for help with depression and knowing more about it and having more widespread acceptance, understanding and support WILL make a difference. Knowing that someone who understands is only a phone call away can give such peace of mind. Matt's book is about his personal journey through depression and what makes it so compelling is that he shares absolutely everything. From standing on the edge of a cliff, contemplating his sanity to being unable to buy milk at a corner shop because of his anxiety through to everything that picked him up again - every little up and down. His story is supplemented with medical knowledge, examples of others who have suffered and of course helpful tips. Having never really looked into mental illnesses before I hadn’t realised how much there is to learn and how many famous names have lived and still are living with depression. **Last year was the best year of my life.** I married my best friend, bought a house with him and travelled more than I ever have before. But it was also the most mentally straining year of my life. This year I'm chasing happiness and Matt's book has helped pushed me further towards this goal. One my favourite sections was where he listed every small thing that made him happy. I thought I'd do the same and share everything that puts a smile on my face (I wonder how many will match up to last year's [list](http://vikibell.com/happiness-is/)? _Sunsets, sunny days, waking up before an alarm, lie ins, good music, loud music, music to fit the mood, walks outside, Suffolk, escaping the city, exploring a new country. Photography, painting, being creative, brainstorming and coming up with crazy ideas that you will never actually do but they sound fun. Colours - bright. Seeing friends, laughter and laughing. Watching Charlie doing improv, Charlie, our wedding day, our honeymoon, painting a crazy table plan in the middle of the woods by throwing paint on it, making our day so creative and unique, hearing all the amazing feedback we had from it (best wedding ever was muttered a fair few times!)_ _The fizzy ones in pick n mix, steak, tomatoes, BBQ food cold beer, red wine, amaretto after a meal, long meals out, drinking Aspalls in the pub in Suffolk, sitting by the fire and watching a bonfire burn. The sea, swimming, waterfalls and giant lakes that you can't even see the other side of. Surprises and random acts of kindness. Kittens, Charlie's cats coming for a cuddle oh and cuddles & kisses. People reading my blog, compliments being given and received, positive thoughts and when you do something no one believed you could do. Shooting stars, a full moon casting shadows. My friends doing exciting things. Realising it's a Sunday when you thought it was a Monday. Victoria station being shut and having to walk from Green Park to work and appreciating it takes me right past Buckingham Palace. Living in London, being able to get anywhere easily, walking home instead of getting public transport. And taking time to pause and appreciate everyone and everything around me._ As I said, I think everyong should read this book, but if you're looking to learn more about it then you can pop over to [Matt's blog](http://www.matthaig.com/reasons-to-stay-alive/). But for now …. **What's on your happy list?** ![Viki](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2cGZeQhRrqyQSI84qIGES8/d71b7fbea23f76e5fb8a41eaac27327b/viki.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Reasons To Stay Alive - a new book by Matt Haig around depression and anxiety.

title.en-GB: Can you pass a UK citizenship test?

wordpressContent.en-GB: There's always articles in the news about UK citizenship tests and how such small amounts of the country can actually pass them. I tried out the test on the [Independent](http://i100.independent.co.uk/article/can-you-pass-a-uk-citizenship-test-most-young-people-cant--gJ0v-H6BQx) and guess what? I failed! I got 17/24 right but that's not enough to pass apparently. The questions I got wrong were around a statement about Richard Arkwright, knowing where textile and engineering firms recruited from after WWII, and knowing a politics quote. Of course I got questions about bonfire night and Jane Austen books correct but does all this really make me a good British citizen? Is knowing Britain's abstract history really going to help you in everyday life? Surely it's more useful to know a bit about British etiquette and how to fit in down the pub? I've come up with a few citizenship questions of my own - let me know how you score!<iframe id="quizWidget-155563" height="700" src="https://www.boombox.com/widget/quiz/fi9xdWl6emVzLzE1NTU2Mw"></iframe>

seoDescription.en-GB: The UK citizenship is pretty difficult. I've thought of a few questions your should be getting right so you can fit in down the pub.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Since I moved to London four years ago my nights out in Essex have dramatically decreased. So when a friend suggested a night out I thought, why not? I hadn’t heard the best things about nights in Basildon (who has?) but I’ll try anything once. ![Basildon](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5SYEC2fuAEOk8Km6AQ0CGs/dde4ea60d19e0f7784c89327fcd11dd0/basildon.jpg) After pizza and drinks we headed to Unit 7 in the retail park. It lived up to expectations with overly strict security, girls cat fighting and 'lads' prowling the dance floor. It wasn't our usual scene but we were there so made it into a good night ... With a lot of booze. ![Basildon](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1I4eOnGR5eKeImwqkImmIy/1b02608def3a8c2706720b332aba6a39/out-in-basildon.jpg) I love sleepovers so when I woke up the next morning Charlie and I became those annoying early risers that go around waking everyone up - fun! After a few hangover cures (pizza and a movie) we decided to take a trip to Southend for donuts and arcade games and relive our childhood. We then found out that we had last minute tickets to the Vaults that evening and their Mardi Gras party. This was my favourite part of the weekend because, well GLITTER!! Completely unprepared we jumped on the train back to London and began glittering ourselves up. ![Mardi Gras](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/53ImTrNGD6eO4SASAYISEE/05606ba0c0e69c04071e93826c575ed7/mardi-gras.jpg) I had only heard about The Vaults recently but knew it was somewhere I wanted to go. Positioned in the old tunnels by Waterloo I can only imagine the history there. To get there we turned down a back ally covered with graffiti and smelling a little funky. We watched some guys adding some fresh paint to the walls before heading inside. This was more like a party then a club or a bar. ![Mardi Gras](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6MRzQ73MY060WkeSEgKuiy/5b6b114489618db7db282c90d63a5c8b/mardi-gras.jpg) To kick off the night there was a procession of musicians and dancers through the venue (and apparently along the south bank). Then we started dancing and by dancing I mean serious dancing - people were not holding back and there were even some semi-pro looking spins going on. The energy in the room was incredible and that wasn't down to the coffee tequila shots we were drinking!![Mardi Gras](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6d9UjPlrckwGu8e0mouKEO/aaaddd7da5baffe2cf82d945badfca6a/mardi-gras.jpg) As the night wore on I got a little bit carried away with the glitter. I even managed to begin a trading session where I’d earn Mardi Gras beads for sprinkling glitter on people's faces. The pictures will explain how carried away I got... ![Mardi Gras](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2rfR9Nd5VykuMQkqOYSOUy/544f2ca05c4ad8d3ec2e95ec0ccf4567/mardi-gras.jpg) ![Mardi Gras](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4gFFXSNv8sWIouE4OAwo6w/6c1fd9f79c64c20d237e7f6e9dd242ad/mardi-gras.jpg)That was us at 3am. I like to think we're still smiling because of the amount of glitter we're wearing. I love it when a weekend that turns into something after having no plans to begin with. And of course I love it when glitter is involved, even if I’ll spend the next few months finding it all over my house.

seoDescription.en-GB: A spontaneous weekend involving a night out in Basildon, Essex and a Mardi Gras party at The Vaults in Waterloo, London with glitter!

wordpressContent.en-GB: I only starting hearing about immersive theatre in the past year or so but I was super keen to try it out. When I finally got my hands on some tickets to a [CoLab](http://www.colabtheatre.co.uk/) performance of The Crooks I was pretty excited. I wasn't too sure what to expect. We were told to _don your flat caps and join us in an episodic tumble down the sink as we go undercover into London’s VHS tinted criminal underworld. Meet the Don and his trouble and strife whilst helping his sigh associates maintain the inner mechanics of London’s Cockney Cartel. _ Charlie and I went along to London Bridge and found a huddle of people standing around outside an old rug factory. It looked dark inside and I wasn't 100% certain we'd gone to the right place until a pretty rough looking individual popped out asking who we were. We muttered a code word and were let in underneath the rusty shutters of the garage and into the middle of police undercover operation on The Don. ![Immersive theatre](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/42UUHT4JlSuqyKEUu0IaKO/bae3854671d7e58893981080ea57f746/immersive-theatre.jpg) I was a bit worried about seeming silly when I first got inside but I was soon joining in the chants and taking daring risks to infiltrate the gang. You just have to let yourself go and pretend that you're in a real life situation. It's like being in a video game or being involved in [improv](http://vikibell.com/improv-night-at-the-miller/). If I spill the beans on what happened inside I'm sure The Don will hunt me down. All you need know is that we infiltrated his mob, came close to being shot, saw fights break out and were offered countless amounts of drugs and booze from the gang members. It was really fun. I'd love to go to more immersive theatre so if you have any recommendations just give me a shout! ![Immersive theatre](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4YFhlSkn0Im0kWUQa6g4kI/36ab74796c374e375aeb53e21f982659/immersive-theatre.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: Trying out immersive theatre in a Cockney cartel - The Crooks by CoLab.

title.en-GB: Conversations You Don't Want To Overhear

wordpressContent.en-GB: I'm stood on the tube beginning this blog post after overhearing a conversation I didn't want to hear. No doubt I'll come back to it again and again before deciding whether to publish it. If you're reading this then I decided to publish it anyway. A group of men have just got off at Euston after spending the past two stops discussing whether to grab my ass (I choose the word ass because that's how they were describing it and that's how they made me feel - like I have an ass that's screaming to be grabbed, a piece of meat that you can reach out and pinch). Luckily they decided against it because they assumed I would slap them. If they hadn't, I hope that I would have been able to stand up to them but I doubt I would have slapped them, I'm not that sort of person. Either way I'm likely to have just felt embarrassed for the rest of the journey.  This isn't a rant. Okay it is a bit and I was about to say that I can't believe men still make remarks like that but I can. Men constantly need to prove themselves to each other to be the toughest, the most desired by women - the king of the pack I suppose.  A day after beginning this post I was in a pub in Angel when I heard two guys talking together. The things they were saying made me instantly judge them and their partners. Overhearing quotes like these in the pub has become so natural that I almost didn't pick up on them.  _Guy A: "How do you feel about your missus? Do you wanna fuck other women? Well of course you do but does she know?_"  A little while later...  _Guy A: "I cheated on Sandy but I couldn't look her in the face. I didn't do it again but I think about it. That isn't cheating is it?"_ _Guy B: "Course it isn't. You can feel it and look at it, have a little wank here and there."_ I felt out of place. I didn't want to be near conversations like that. I expect both men would have been full of niceties in front of their partners but I can't help but feel that they are being cheated by having them speak about them like that (not to mention that actual cheating).  Guys can be just as bitchy as girls too. When I was out the other week one of my guy friends was asked if I was his 'bird' (I hate that term) to save me getting hit on he answered yes. The guy then informed him that he was punching above his weight. What?! Why is there a need to be so hurtful and aggressive to someone you've only just met. When is that acceptable behaviour? I'm not sure of the point of this post other than to get all that off my chest. I'm just tired of hearing sexual comments being made or being stared at by creepy men on the tube.  I know not every male speaks or acts those ways towards people and I haven't mentioned all the times girls have been just as bad or times when guys have been lovely. The people I encountered recently and the conversations I've heard have just made me a little more disappointed in humans but I'm sure there will be the times when my faith is restored again soon.  That got a little negative so here's an image which makes me smile to bring you back into positive thoughts... ![Pigs](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ymb7Xu1vycas24MqigeEe/7893971134dce4fd301ed8fd36359df3/pigs.jpg)

From one peek at my Instagram you'll know that I shoot off to Suffolk at any chance I can get and I've finally listed out a few of my favourite things to do around Thorpeness. As much as I love London you can't beat a weekend in the countryside. Our house is based just outside of village down a long dirt track. It's called The Shellpits as there used to be big pits where people would gather fossil remains. The whole area was used heavily in the war and you can still see the foundations of the WWII anti aircrafts guns on the field outside. All the owners of the seven cottages get on really well and there's a big community spirit with BBQs during the summer and drinks around the fire in the winter. The whole of Thorepness is extremely welcoming and friendly. I've been told snippets of history about Thorepness over the years so I decided to research it a bit more for this post. Did you know it was named 'Weirdest Village in England' by 'Bizarre' magazine in 2003? The village used to be a fishing hamlet but was bought by a rich Scottish barrister, Glencairn Stuart Ogilvie, in 1910 who turned it into his fantasy holiday village. He built the golf course, country club, swimming pool and holiday homes so his friends and colleagues could visit during the summer. A lot of the Ogilvie family still live or visit Thorpeness too. Whenever I go up there's a few things I like to do and a few times of year I like to be there so here's my _9 Things To Do Around Thorpeness_. If you ever get a chance to visit the area you'll know where to find me and what to do! **Aldeburgh** ![Moonlight](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2GTy2KdGTK64O8UicaoYES/0089f18c2d08ddf560d58a1b064af26a/moonlight.jpg) Fish and chips is a must and you'll see how popular it is by the queues. In the summer you'll have to wait for an hour or so but it's well worth it. If the fish was any fresher it would still be swimming. Once you've got your fish and chips head over to the stone beach and enjoy it whilst overlooking the sea. Don't worry the seagulls stay back! ![Aldeburgh beach](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6FMRarG7BuoK02SCmYggaO/fa5c7970129d64c25d465954ad8b9ba8/aldeburgh-beach.jpg) While you're in Aldeburgh have a look around the shops. There isn't a lot but you're always bound to find some goodies especially from the Alde or the Adnams shop. **The Dolphin** ![The Dolphin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/227symebmskekE8WKuiAC0/e0beb94274e3ccdf86e273c0e3f7ba9f/the-dolphin.jpg) I can't remember a time that I've been to Suffolk without going to The Dolphin for at least one cheeky pint. It's pretty much in the central of Thorpeness so you can't miss it. It's the place where we went for dinner after Charlie proposed, where we sang carols at Christmas, where we've had countless summer hog roasts and it's somewhere where the staff always greet you with a smile. If we are up by ourselves in the winter we like getting a board game and spending our afternoons by the fire in there or in the summer we chill in the garden outside. For us an evening trip to the pub always ends with a walk back through the fields navigating our way by the moonlight. For someone who has always lived around light pollution I still get amazed at the moon shadows. **The Meare** ![The Meare](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1k9hszxGt4QGoycAgkU2kO/6be1000fc5bfaa5f29748c4b7dcf3e3e/the-meare.jpg) The Meare was hand dug and is a boating lake dotted with little islands each names in the theme of Peter Pan. This was Ogilvie’s homage to his friend J.M. Barrie’s now classic novel. In the summer there's the _Thorpeness Regatta_ which is where children's boat races take place. On the Friday night the punts are decorated and paraded around the Meare before a big fireworks display. **The beach** ![Thorpeness Beach](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/VWjfCQQsUui0AAC6wK68a/abc6f01bcb45ef5eabdcffc614c38bcd/thorpeness-beach.jpg) People are always heading to the beach in the summer despite the cold North Sea and the unreliable British weather. It's the perfect thing to sweep away the cob webs or banish the hangover from one too many pints of Aspalls. Of course I managed to fit in a dip in the sea on my wedding day! ![Thorpeness Beach](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5dba7grX4IQ88EmaCiMAEG/4b2a62cae46fc0a3bddff9ab4067fdc4/thorpeness-beach.jpg) **Take a walk** It's only in the recent years that I've started to really enjoy walking but in Suffolk there's so many different places you can explore. During a chilly January day we've walked to Dunwich for lunch, it took us four hours to get there and four hours back (after a few beers) but it was worth the day trip. I slowed us down quite a lot taking photos but the scenery is amazing. You can even see some of the anti-tank cubes dating back to the war. ![Minsmere](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5HM5NFclSoIcMOeSQg2YWK/97ff9bfe99b93764b543c64a45689951/minsmere.jpg) If you don't fancy such a long walk you can go across Minsmere which is a bird reserve and have a drink in the Eels Foot - yes all walks are navigated by the pubs (have you never been to the countryside?) There are loads of walk you can do from wherever you're staying so have a look at [Walking in Suffolk](http://www.walkinginsuffolk.co.uk/saxmundham.php) for some routes. ![Dunwich](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/42IjkoxyTCGwYImwMiCA0K/478c0ae71419d2f36efb191e45956dba/dunwich.jpg) **Visit Snape Maltings.** On certain Saturday's there's a farmers market with the best cheese straws alongside other goodies like local pate and cheeses. During a normal day Snape has a selection of shops selling local foods and niche home bits and bobs alongside local artwork and antiques. Of course there is also the famous music hall there too. After a nose around the shops I'd recommend taking a walk alongside the river Alde or having a cheeky pint of Adnams in The Plough & Sail pub. To see what else is on visit their [website](http://www.snapemaltings.co.uk/). ![Snape Maltings](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/32xs9onwgoUOI0Eq6uEAa2/7c4eece3928171774da5b1ecc2e2bf7b/snape-maltings.jpg) **Glemham Hall** [Glemham hall](http://www.glemhamhall.co.uk/) was where Charlie and I got married and I've been meaning to go back there for one of their events. They have loads of things on all year round from their Folk East festival to various plays and of course weddings! We drive past it on our way up and always point it out. In the summer it's easy to spot as there's a dead tree which gets decorated. Last year it had bikes hanging from it. The owners are very into art which you'll see from a walk around their sculpture garden. ![Glemham Hall](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/v21060.1208.jpg) **Aldeburgh Carnival** Each year in August there's the [Aldebugh Carnival](http://www.aldeburghcarnival.com/). This is also around the time of the Thorpeness Regatta. The Monday of carnival week is when there's a big procession through Aldeburgh with floats and plenty of fancy dress. Each year there's an overarching theme, this year's is 'circus comes to town'. We used to go up each year when we were younger and camp out in Charlie's garden. The Monday is still a big event taking us back to our childhood by drinking on the beach in front of the pub and stumbling home in the dark. It's also the weekend the [Wood Party](http://vikibell.com/the-wood-party/) falls on so we're usually doing something exciting around then. ![Aldeburgh Carnival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1QhLETS89m66Iwk6EyUs26/fa4ba55db5936b37897d76ff411bd7b7/aldeburgh-carnival.jpg) **Thorpefest** For the past few years there's been a music festival on Aldeburgh. We stumbled across it by accident when it was soul themed and last year it was music through the decades. This year it's coming to Thorpeness so it might be a little different but I'm sure it will still be great! ![Thorpefest](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/58LLYJu5X20S2aqMqqikWg/b2c4a10a27c2ca423ce2e498e08d9c28/thorpefest.jpg) There's quite a few things you can do to explore the area. You also make your own fun there whether that's taking a walk along the beach or curling up with a good book in front of the fire. It's the perfect place to escape the buzz of the city. Enjoy! ![Aspall](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5pqm5Xi0DuoWYq2YkQ4qwg/506638fe5e1b49dca3b285fc4ad7b8ff/v2img-7195.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: I love going up to Thorpeness so thought I'd share a little history about the Thorpeness and Aldeburgh area and nine things to do whilst there.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Twitter is celebrating it's 10th birthday today and I can't believe it's been around for that long but at the same time, can't imagine life without it. Twitter is constantly innovating and is always exciting you with new features. I love that they've added in GIFs - who doesn't love a GIF?   Anyway, I've been having a bit of a dig around in my Twitter history to looking back at my account and I've found a few great and 'slightly strange' tweets I've sent. Time to share! My degree was in Art and Design and as part of that we did a module around marketing ourselves so I set up my Twitter account. Since October 2010 I've sent over 6,400 tweets and learnt a lot. Judging from my first tweet I had no idea what I was doing but decided to jump straight in at the deep-end.

> Is priming a canvas, what will I do with it next?
> 
> — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [October 29, 2010](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/29109653595)

  I never did find out what I did with it and years on I'm still sending pointless tweets. 

> [#Pointlesstweet](https://twitter.com/hashtag/Pointlesstweet?src=hash) [pic.twitter.com/LyHDCCGlZR](http://t.co/LyHDCCGlZR) — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [February 20, 2015](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/568776174941409280)

But sometimes, occasionally, I tweet a real gem. Self-five!

> Every time I walk through Victoria station in the morning it's like the stampede scene in the Lion King. [pic.twitter.com/FeEzX5Seji](http://t.co/FeEzX5Seji)
> 
> — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [June 3, 2015](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/605992551737376768)

Or even some profound tips...

> No one remembers the nights they stayed home [#adventure](https://twitter.com/hashtag/adventure?src=hash) — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [October 2, 2013](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/385423310408126464)

  Twitter has seen some of my biggest announcements so far. I love the fact I can shout out to my followers and random people can just interact with what I've said.

> I'M GETTING MARRIED TODAY!!! But first for a swim in the sea [#suffolk](https://twitter.com/hashtag/suffolk?src=hash)[#wedding](https://twitter.com/hashtag/wedding?src=hash)[#summer](https://twitter.com/hashtag/summer?src=hash)[pic.twitter.com/UvieTFDRoo](http://t.co/UvieTFDRoo) — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [July 18, 2015](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/622313587156123648)

I didn't just look back at my tweets. I've gone further and looked back specifically at my last year's activity where I sent a total of 1,247 tweets and potentially reached 1.7 million people - wow! I also had a look at some of my most used words. I'd guessed that these would include blog, coffee, wedding, and wine but I was surprised to see quite a few names in there too. Shoutout to [Emma Inks](https://twitter.com/Emma_Inks) who I seem to mention a lot! ![wordcloud](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5PNDqO5Cwwma4uousEQIOk/af6cd248482978297e1112972584beca/wordcloud.png) I've been more active on Twitter in the past year or so as I've begun blogging properly and making friends through it. I love how fast paced it is and how easy it is to keep up with everything going on there - something which could be lost with the increased character limits. I've met some amazing and inspiring people through both Twitter and my blog; it's a little corner of the internet I can be myself and send silly messages if I want to.

> SO EXCITED for [#Marrakech](https://twitter.com/hashtag/Marrakech?src=hash) this weekend with [@ellielowe](https://twitter.com/ellielowe) ☀️ any recommendations let me know! [pic.twitter.com/w942CgpTTr](https://t.co/w942CgpTTr)
> 
> — Viki Bell (@Vikiibell) [February 29, 2016](https://twitter.com/Vikiibell/status/704285313456275457)

Twitter was especially wonderful around the wedding time. It was a great place to share my news and updates, read other wedding stories and find inspiration. I especially LOVE this tweet from my bridesmaid who's since got engaged and is getting married this year!

> Proud winner of the bouquet. It's not that I'm desperate to get married next, I just can't stand losing at catch. [pic.twitter.com/WI4do12tjU](http://t.co/WI4do12tjU) — Eleanor Lowe (@ellielowe) [July 19, 2015](https://twitter.com/ellielowe/status/622812022938443777)

Thanks for ten years of fun Twitter (or in my case six) and Happy Birthday!

seoDescription.en-GB: Twitter celebrates it's 10th birthday and I look back on my tweets and what Twitter means to me.

title.en-GB: Six things to do in Marrakech in four days

wordpressContent.en-GB:
The next place on my travel list was Marrakech so with a few days of holiday to use up I jumped on a place with my friend Ellie and headed there for a long weekend. Our pre-trip research had us a bit worried about our clothes and the way we might be treated there, I had read a lot of reviews saying that men will pester you and women will spit at you. Ignore that! It wasn't like that at all and we had nothing to be worried about. As a westerner you will be glanced at and a few comments might be made but as long as you don't encourage it then it's fine. Marrakech was great for a short break and we had a good balance of busy and relaxing so I thought I'd share my recommendations with you.

# **Stay in a Riad**

There are plenty of Riads around and it gives you a more traditional feel compared to the usual hotel. These are quite small so you'll get to know the staff well as they share their tips of what to do and see. We stayed in Riad Tilila which was perfect. Our room was exactly what we needed especially as we weren't planning on spending any time in there and we were given a local phone just in case we got lost! There was also the roof terrace so we could have our breakfast in the sunshine. One evening we ended up watching the sunset up there with a few beers. My only recommendation would be to request a not downstairs room as we literally opened our door and were in the lounge. It didn't bother us but might do someone looking for a bit more privacy. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3VxpdN91SEi8ICy8aeKoKo/418c5e0ad1c1926de736abe801ce2e90/marrakech.jpg)

# Jardin Majorelle

After an early flight we wanted to have a chilled first day and decided to explore the Jardin Majorelle which we'd heard lots about. Once inside the walls of the garden it was a complete contrast to the busy streets of Marrakech. When we first got there Ellie and I just wandered around in amazement, it was exactly what we needed - somewhere calm and peaceful. And blue. I LOVED the blue! ![Jardin Majorelle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7nryZPRBAIQuwyOEkKGqGu/e17265a70b972900209f6aff36561a54/jardin-majorelle.jpg)   The garden was created by the artist, Jacques Majorelle and was a side project to his painting. He would travel the world and bring back exotic and rare species of cacti, bamboo and palm trees. After Majorelle fell into money troubles and died the garden faced ruin and was due to be sold to make way for a hotel. Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé brought the garden back to life after being inspired by its beauty. They lived there for a while and you can find a memorial to Yves Saint Laurent inside the garden. I could really feel an artist touch in the garden, there was something special there that made me ignore the tourists snapping photos and enjoy atmosphere. We walked around twice making sure to take everything in. One side is bamboo but my favourite section was the cactus plants - we picked our cactus alter-egos. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4n9EKd5AgMg2uwGUc0S00Y/05c4b0b7d3e7d73c9c07d6a1784d3b25/marrakech.jpg)

# **Haggle with the souks**

You can't go to Marrakech without haggling down the souks. I loved getting lost in the market and discovering everything in there. Like most markets a lot of the stuff is similar stall to stall but if you keep walking around you'll see different areas. One area reminded me of Romford market as it was selling a load of underwear and baby clothes reminding me of my Sundays at the market with nan. We got a little lost and ended up in the leather section, there were bags everywhere! Here I found the perfect birthday present for my brother; I haggled a bit but didn't get it down quite enough so moved onto the next stall. I found a pretty much similar if not better bag and got that for a the price I was willing to pay. Simple! As long as you haggle with a smile on your face and don't get offended if they don't go down then it's fine. The price the souks go in with is always higher than they expect you to pay so don't get shocked at the first price. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7HsYaJhlKMGYCM4MOuyQmC/75b08d2c66527dd7456a3aa84a5d2a12/marrakech.jpg) You'll also see a lot of spice shops around. After buying the bag the man showed us into his friends stall where we met Ayoub who gave us a bit of a tour of his spices. He was bragging about the time Jamie Oliver came in to pick up a few bits and we ended up coming out of there with some Moroccan mint and jasmine tea. Marrakech is famous for its rugs as well. These won't be super cheap but they will be a bargain compared to what you'd spend in the UK. Make sure you check the quality as well as it differs stall to stall. I managed to find one I loved which is really good quality. Although I liked the design of my second favourite it wouldn't last nearly as long. Again you can haggle on these but don't be too cheeky; remember the amount of work that goes into making them. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/JXrUvL6yYgUQWIc0YkqAM/4d1dd9fe88b438196b159e3a7bb90da8/marrakech.jpg)

# Mojitos in nomad

When you need a break from the Souks head to the Nomad bar and have a few mojitos on the rooftops. These might just be the best mojitos I've ever had. They do great food too which I'll go into on my next post. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5zMyru95wQWQU8aWi0YMii/99f4462376ba6c14d1ed7373708d7084/marrakech.jpg)

# Ouzoud waterfall

We wanted to do one day trip during our stay and didn't fancy anything too 'touristy'. Imad at our Riad recommended going to see the Ouzoud waterfall, so we did. We headed out early, driving north, east and towards the town of Ouzoud. It was really nice to be out of the city and seeing more of Morocco. Like most group day trips it does depend on the people you're with and our trip was made by the Welsh group who turned up in tiny shorts, bikinis and flip flops - they'd been told that they were in for a day sunbathing and swimming. They saw a funny side to things when they realised we were hiking to the bottom of the waterfall and back up and we all got on well. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/51t2Oe2x8QO4yocWo62KEU/65bb286a6ccc0b610c3aa9b455c81883/marrakech.jpg) When you get to the pool of the waterfall you can go on these little rafts across the water. This was one of my favourite parts as the local rowing us decided to take us completely into the spray whilst laughing his head off.
