We all had no idea what he was doing but I couldn't stop laughing either. ![Ouzoud waterfall](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4psmRuvIS4oWoOAmikK8Qq/28158314abfd4d50d7500a3e5f0603a8/ouzoud-waterfall.jpg) ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6Djso1ws3SuW4y4wqMUgWi/95b1aca867c48824052c7e3aa8747329/marrakech.jpg) Also, there were monkeys! ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/WvQPJenAomUiO2MUGcaG8/89b22e432ecc1fd6b64e2d8870515786/marrakech.jpg)

# **Bahia palace**

There's two palaces in Marrakech and as we hadn't researched either we picked one at random; as we arrived we realised that it was the venue for the biennale so we had a nice walk around the artworks. My favourite part was this courtyard in the sunshine - it's so symmetrical! ![Bahia Palace](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4qPRM5QsAwGmiAEkMaa4QO/586ea4aa99f5d52db76b8a03b0c15692/bahia-palace.jpg) You don't need very long in Marrakech. We arrived Friday morning and left Monday evening and that was perfect. If we'd stayed for a day longer I think we would have done a camping trip in the Atlas mountains. Don't be put off by a few reviews saying it's unsafe. As long as you're confident walking down the street and you're aware then you'll be fine! Go and get lost in the streets and and explore Marrakech. ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/T3j7hFerW6GGcA8sUyso0/c18474ebb3b3a723023b3204e9fef425/marrakech.jpg)

title.en-GB: Where should you eat in Marrakech?

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I always like to know where to eat on holiday especially when it's a short break. Knowing some of the good places can really make a holiday for me. Unfortunately, I had managed to forget I'd booked our Marrakech trip until a few days before so hadn't had time to research anything - TripAdvisor to the rescue! Not only can you search by location and price, the app has a handy little feature so you can put a 'with alcohol' filter on the restaurants, something I'm not ashamed to say we used! After filtering by location, booze and price I think we found some of the top places to eat so here they are....

# Le Comptoir Du Pacha

We found this during a speedy search on our first might and chose it because the food looked good, it was near to our Riad and it was cheap- exactly what we wanted after an early start. Friendly staff, good food and good atmosphere in an typical Moroccan layout. We stuck to the set menu and had a selection of meat and vegetables rolls to start followed by steak and lemon meringue pie.  I was tired so excuse the bad lighting and iPhone photos! ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/69VCAyRDhuIoasaS4SWeEa/f8644c797f37e8b5a4e4624819f0b9cf/marrakech.jpg) ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4cZRyOFsZqaY8Y0mYsy2QM/c4e322b03a6a610d9cf12a6257b8f105/marrakech.jpg)

# Breakfast in the Riad

We took full advantage of our riad breakfasts and had them sitting on the roof in the morning sunshine. Freshly squeezed orange juice is something that you'll hear a lot about in Marrakech and I can tell you with good authority that it is A M A Z I N G! Each breakfast was a carb overload with baskets of fresh bread, pastries and yogurts. My favourite bit was our orange and chocolate pancakes. ![Riad](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1n679U5dJqm6SQmMcO6mAo/3ff1dbed34e956ac798a716a52b8ec25/riad.jpg)

# Nomad

If you go to Marrakech you'll hear about Nomad. It kind of put me off as I got the impression it was quite touristy but after being I see that it both was and wasn't. It was just quite a nice place to eat or have a drink. There is two roof terraces as well as indoor eating which all looks quite fancy. We went during the day but I get the feeling you'll need a reservation if you come at night. ![Nomad](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1V5IZqwcuAMqIOYIuG8y6S/bf727e5bd07451aeeaef6d780ad13d27/nomad.jpg) Once settled in the sunshine we ordered a few mojitos and, as I mentioned in my previous [post](http://vikibell.com/six-things-to-do-in-marrakech-in-four-days/), I swear they're some of the best mojitos I've had in my life. We ended up going for lunch on two days here as the staff were so friendly and the food so good. The first day we shared courgette fritters and bread and dips. The second time we both ordered the nomad burger. We had seen it the day before and got a bit of food envy and rightly so! It was all soooo good.![Nomad](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4cVBEqCqDYgyqKkeSuuSuy/1908aa5106e028f6492215db2592b5fa/nomad.jpg) ![Nomad](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6iPzYJUCZyAwwSQsSgyMqK/6e976b875f8d53f0cb90f9751a415ea4/nomad.jpg)

# Cafe arabe

We went here on our second night. Recommended by TripAdvisor and it was on a Marrakech [app](https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/marrakech-riad-travel-guide/id489129273?mt=8) that I'd downloaded. As we headed out the door Imad, who worked in our Riad, told us he used to work there so we knew we were in good hands. The restaurant was tiny and on the bottom floor of another Riad. The waiter was really friendly and kept joking about my food - especially funny as the menu was all on French so I had no idea what Ellie had ordered for me. We shared homous and breads and then I ended up with was a vegetarian pasta in a creamy sauce which was super tasty! ![Marrakech](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1ZNlmc0JzSaaugG8KYoGO0/660408b13317dfecd4b8bd5fe2f404e0/marrakech.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: I had managed to forget I'd booked our Marrakech trip until a few days before so hadn't had time to research anywhere to eat - TripAdvisor to the rescue!

wordpressContent.en-GB: I love jewellery. I love finding weird and wonderful rings and bracelets in various markets around the world. At some point I decided that I wanted to try out making some myself, so, after a little research, I signed myself up to Alexandra's jewellery course in Hatton Garden. If you're going to learn about jewellery you may as well learn about it in the jewellery centre of London! One of the reasons I chose this course over the others was because it wasn't just a beginners course. There were only five of us and three had been to quite a few of the courses before and were working on their pieces in their spare time. This meant we were able to see the process of more intricate pieces being made. ![IMG_7817](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1R5AFUwzNmYS4EsQQUKeYm/81f95a13cca0b2932918d83bc028268a/img-7817.jpg) The course ran for ten weeks every Wednesday and each week I learnt something new. Throughout the ten classes I made two rings and a necklace each designed (or slightly made up on the spot) by me. I learn how to solder, stone setting, resizing and reshaping pieces, polishing and even twisting the metal (which you can see on my necklace). ![IMG_7997](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2VGW9URfMsymsAek4AKSO8/0bc0358f5f75ebd0c17aad582f50f985/img-7997.jpg) The first thing I made was the ring. It was here that I learnt about stone setting and all the measurements which need to be calculated in the process. The stone is only held in by the metal which I physically forced down on top of it. The stone was bought from one of the shops in Hatton Garden and was surprisingly the same stone as the one in my necklace which I'd picked up in Florence. ![jewellery](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4tqbJcQfGMIqY4G4smUGuU/5d0cf797f30dd10b696b1165d368e3f4/jewellery.jpg) My favourite piece is the chunky silver ring I made. We were being taught about carving and given a lump of wax to experiment with. After shaving various bits off and carving into it with a few different tools, we sent it to the casters who set it in silver. When it arrived back I wasn't too sure I liked it; it just looked like a big silver lump and I was aiming for something that looked quite natural and a bit like a rock. I decided to fix it by oxidising it to create a black effect. Then I polished up random bits using two different dremel (drill) parts to give it different amounts of shine. Finally, I had a proper look at what I'd made and it's safe to say I like it - I wear it pretty much everyday now. ![jewellery](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2vxPHCYDDeSUGssmyUcY8e/55231f130fd288d6aabb785a5cbc4f0b/jewellery.jpg) [Alexandra's course](http://centralschoolofjewellery.com/) was brilliant for any beginner or even if you know a few things about jewellery making. It's structured in such a way that, unlike other courses, you can decide exactly what you want to make - if you don't want to make a ring then that's fine, make something else. She'll help you plan out your end designs, tell you the best places to get materials and help you when you inevitably mess something up.

seoDescription.en-GB: How I enjoyed taking an evening jewellery class by Alexandra Huerga in Hatton Garden and what I made.

title.en-GB: How To Survive A Zombie Apocalypse

wordpressContent.en-GB:
One of the questions I keep asking at the moment is _what would you do if there was suddenly a zombie outbreak_. Okay, I realise that sounds really really odd but everyone's answers are different and it's actually quite interesting. I thought I'd share my (untested!) tips of how to survive and I've broken it down for each place I might be when the outbreak begins.

# If you're in London / a city when all hell breaks loose.

See if you can escape and get out of the city. Take food and water in a backpack and try to get out on bike. Head to countryside. Now skip to the countryside section. If there is absolutely no way out and you're likely to get knocked down by a bicycle riding fool with a backpack, then stay put. Get chatting to your neighbours and pick the highest flat to stay in and make a den. Knock down/ block any stairs so the zombies can't get up, but ensure you have an escape route such as a low roof to jump out onto or a ladder. Ration your food and water. When running water inevitably runs out you'll need to look for more. Have a think about the toilet situation, you might need to poop out the window and stuff so get friendly with your neighbours! Teach each other new skills like fire building, hunting etc. Hopefully you'll be able to find a way into the countryside later.

# You're in a town that's about an hour out of the city.

Okay this is better. Think about getting out and heading to the countryside. Plan a few different routes or places to go and get there fast before word spreads. Take rations and spare petrol etc. If you can't leave, then work out how to secure your house and, as above, think about escape routes etc. Stock up on food, water, candles and weapons. If you have a car then think about getting more petrol so you can travel but store it somewhere separate so you'll still have petrol to use on another car if yours gets stolen. Also, if there is any kind of wild animals like deer in the parks then you might want to think about hunting them.   If you're in a town then hopefully the zombie plague won't spread as quickly as if you were in the city so you have more time to thing about these things.

# You're in the countryside.

Okay this would be the dream situation. I'm imagining that I'm in Suffolk but most countryside places would be okay/ similar. Food and water is sorted. The house is a holiday home so it's always stocked with tins of food. There are a load of old cooking books showing you how to cook things like rabbit for when it's later down the line - just thing about offering food to neighbours as you might need their help at some point! For the water, we can dig down into the old well and use that again. As a longterm goal you'll need to think about getting to a farmland for vegetables etc. and planting your own. In the countryside you have a little longer until the infection spreads so take the time to prepare. Use the last of the Internet to watch YouTube videos which will help you long term. Maybe try some around arrow making, wall building and farming. Secure the property. If zombie films are anything to go on then the nighttime is the scariest part so make sure you're prepared. Board up windows and build a wall around your property if you can. Luckily we have a big ditch that used to be shell pits outside the house so that would pretty much be our moat! You should also draw up a night watch rota to make sure no zombies break this barrier. Welcome people into your zombie safe haven but be aware of their strengths and weaknesses. Give the weak people easy and familiar tasks to do like cooking or tidying up the house whilst the stronger ones build things and hunt. Then finally **have fun and try not to die.** If the zombie plague has spread across the world then there isn't a lot of hope unless a cure has already been found so you may as well try to stay alive for as long as you can but have a bit of fun whilst doing so. Good luck! ![Zombie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/39rUNtBeTmacAUWymGgQKq/d2b31565e27dc3e8e1f4653e16b9fe6b/zombie.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My (untested!) tips of how to survive a zombie apocalypse, broken down into the best places to be when all hell breaks loose.

title.en-GB: Sunday Jazz Cruise with Bateaux London

wordpressContent.en-GB: One of our wedding presents was vouchers for a [Sunday jazz cruise](http://www.bateauxlondon.com/cruises/sunday-lunch-jazz-cruises/). We wanted to wait until it was a bit warm before booking so picked a random weekend in May to use them. It just so happened that the random weekend in May was when London hit 26 degrees. Win! ![IMG_2887](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1YfyahTn8UUUs6uOKyAaYG/e402dc84a78754d04a0aa9ae04c6b47e/img-2887.jpg) We headed to embankment pier and were shown onto the boat, Symphony, and to our table by some very happy waiters. We must have been the youngest couple on there. Other people were celebrating grandparents birthdays or were out for lunch with other 'adult aged' couples. As a cruise down the Thames it does lend itself to be a tourist trap but, luckily it wasn't. Everyone seemed really happy to be there and there was a lovely atmosphere. The waiters took our food and drink order. We chose fizz of course - this was a wedding present after all! ![Jazz boat cruise](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6FAvPD1gU8Ug02KgK2yGAE/ab722898f9a0e1e117232cdd6f48a720/jazz-boat-cruise.jpg) We started off up the Thames and went past the big MI6 building and past the bridges I cross during my walks at work. We then spun around and headed back down past the Houses of Parliament, the London Eye and as far as Canary Wharf. As we drifted along a jazz band started playing. Unfortunately, we were in the back of the boat meaning we couldn't watch them which was a shame. The sax and singer popped in twice to prove that they existed though. We started with the ham hock terrine which was really good. The pickle was super tasty; something I wouldn't have put with it myself but the flavours worked really well. ![ham hock](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6jzrd2pCDeg4cOwuCwW4ei/4c2075e3c49d6a07c1f761904241c064/ham-hock.jpg) Next I had the salmon with almond crust and green beans. ![Salmon dish](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7BJ8iaSxuE2yWIw8CwA26O/d10d70ca740e13ec3025311258275cf9/img-2841.jpg "Salmon dish") Charlie chose the stuffed chicken supreme. As it was so warm outside I thought it might have been a bit heavy but it was just right. ![Roast chicken with carrots and potato ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4JGenH01qgqoQoocEiyGqk/3c007ec8636301ddbc5c775ece7a3356/chicken-dish.jpg) We had a bit of an outside moment after that. It was so sunny and warm that I could have sat out there all day. ![Jazz boat cruise](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/71T8teSs8MUMg6GSkYAWYI/c374e9479fe08fa9467809aa4c75c534/jazz-boat-cruise.jpg) ![London Eye](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/89M07OnnUc8AkMwsAS0Qe/ac35b45624f9e5bfff3e4ce6d8f6375a/london-eye.jpg) Then it was time for dessert - red velvet brownie, vanilla ice cream and a passion fruit coulis. I'm still not convinced by the red velvet craze but this dessert was really good especially the passion fruit coulis. ![Red velvet brownie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/JUYstUBkQuoC624GeQOag/fd0a2e263d15756ffbcb0f8a9eaf90a0/red-velvet-brownie.jpg) We'd ordered a bottle of white at some point and it didn't drop the standard. I'd expected the prices to be extortionate with substandard wine but that wasn't the case. With the trip coming to a close, we headed back to the docks with our bellies full and silly grins on our faces. The jazz cruise was the perfect way to spend a Sunday afternoon!

seoDescription.en-GB: We took a cruise down the Thames with Bateaux London and enjoyed a three course meal and a live jazz band.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I'd been into the bar at [Duck and Waffle](https://duckandwaffle.com/) ages ago but never actually eaten there. That all changed on Thursday evening. After work a group of us headed across to Liverpool Street in time for our reservation- the central line at rush hour is just wonderful isn't it?! We arrived at the Heron Tower and were escorted into the lift which shot us up to the 42nd floor and showed us the amazing view over London. I spent quite a while trying to see if I could spot the Arsenal stadium and my house before realising that I was looking in the completely wrong direction. ![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2LKohLmHxS0UUgm6wGQcSw/252cf3ed3cd741f38b204f3af11333de/duck-and-waffle.jpg) We started off with a few of [Rich Woods](https://twitter.com/the_cocktailguy)' 'eat your greens' cocktails. I had Eden which was a concoction of Bombay Sapphire gin, bay leaf, IPA reduction, beetroot paint. Yes, I did choose it because it had paint in it. Everyone else went for the Pina-Kale-Ada which involved Bacardi Superior rum, pineapple sherbet, kale. We also had a few bar snacks, the bread came with violet artichoke in - I don't even like artichoke normally but it was SO good! ![Cocktail](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2BSnl8l8KsIGaI80mAuk26/d68effcb696a4688b7a11ab280c746b6/cocktail.jpg) After the drinks we headed to our table where a glass of fizz was waiting for us from Rich. Then waiter came over to explain how the menu worked. Duck and Waffle is a 'playful take on traditional British cuisine with broad European influences emphasizing local, rustic, seasonal and sustainable ingredients.' My kind of food! I usually find it difficult to pick out the one specific dish I fancy on the menu so when I found out that all the dishes are meant to be shared, I was particularly happy. We picked our favourites and ordered a big selection.
First to arrive was the spiced ox cheek donut with apricot jam and smoked paprika. I don't think I've ever had ox cheek before and it looked very peculiar to cut into but tasted so good. It was very rich so you don't need a lot of it.
 ![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/27b2IKKxM0EOcMGKuK04SG/76d8c89a002336781669519dd5da0235/duck-and-waffle.jpg)
The rest of the starters arrived as we were digging into the donut. We had picked seared octopus with fennel, asparagus with poached Arlington white hen's egg, hassleback potatoes with confit duck egg yolk, and baked haddock with lobster cream. I'm not going to describe all of it because I don't think I can come up with enough adjectives to describe YUMMY!
![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6aOAHpyCKQgoU8acQQeaGG/16bef20b813e5da7714afd31123bc24f/duck-and-waffle.jpg)
We couldn't come all this way without having the duck and waffle which of course was amazing. I don't even like waffles normally but all the flavours complimented each other so well that I really enjoyed it.
![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7cnkw6NehiWsC4ae62aGSs/9894a3f6a19e593fdcd61c35fe0ccde9/duck-and-waffle.jpg)
We had also ordered the steak which I think was my joint favourite part of the entire meal (joint with the duck and waffle of course). This wasn't just any steak, it was a 38 day aged 500G Angus bone-in rib-eye with roasted crispy cabbage, and caper and bacon brown butter. As it was to share we had ordered it medium, as opposed to my usual blue and still mooing request. It was so tasty that I really didn't care how cooked it was, there was just so much flavour. The cabbage and capers and bacon butter again paired with the tastes perfectly.
With main course complete it was onto dessert. Although we'd had a lot of food we each managed to squeeze it in, even if we did share. I went for the baked Alaska - lemon is my go to dessert seeing as I'm not a big fan of cake or chocolate. It was so pretty!! The others went for a mix of the brownie and the Torrejas with maple caramel apples and cinnamon ice cream - it was was big enough to share between all of us let along just two!
![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1aP6P566ego4GIeKeCGAU8/34c547e7af3bceee766cdbb5b1bd81d9/duck-and-waffle.jpg) ![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1UFuICMK6U4KwuOO6eAMuc/f59c1d39d45f26e731e88e36d9314757/duck-and-waffle.jpg)
We headed back into the bar to finish our drinks, where our waiter had set us up a table. The music had been turned up at the atmosphere changed as the sun had set. We'd had a wonderful evening, the food, wine and service was all perfect and I'd love to go back up there sometime. ![Duck and Waffle](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5XxUTd55oAAeUq2cCu2SMK/a7b257ee84ac8ea64b5fa5223e5a9424/duck-and-waffle.jpg)

seoTitle.en-GB: Dinner at Duck and Waffle, Heron Tower

seoDescription.en-GB: My experience of dinner at Duck and Waffle, trying out all of the amazing dishes and cocktails available on the 42nd floor of the Heron Tower.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Decorating wasn't a big priority when we moved into out flat in March last year, what with planning a wedding and a whole bunch of celebrations for the rest of the year. We'd originally planned quite a few changes to the layout but seeing as we haven't won the lottery, we decided to be happy with what we have and decorate it instead. The lady who lived there before hadn't done a lot so it all needed freshening up and become more _us_.
We've just finished our lounge, the first room in our challenge. It went from all being an off white to a mixture of white, dark grey and a light blue/ grey.
![Decorating ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4VqoIhxybSuIgQ6coQUoAm/284325ca3bdf986632064683c94fc56a/painting.jpg)
We're still planning some shelving units to go in the spaces either side of the fireplace which Charlie has designed. He's either going to build them or we'll find someone to do it for us.
We ran into a few hurdles of course. We took off the existing shelves which ripped into the walls meaning we had to re-lining paper them. The same went for the chimney breast which had this horrible chip board wallpaper on which was all the rage in the 90s?! As we peeled it off the walls were still sticky underneath meaning we had to leave them to dry out a little after scraping everything off. We also has to steam the rest of the wallpaper off which caused my beautifully painted ceiling to bubble! Luckily these went away overnight.
The second hurdle was actually lining the walls. We watched a few YouTube clips and got cracking. It's true that practice makes perfect as our first few pieces had a few more air bubbles in than the last. These air bubbles (and new ones) all came to the surface when I gave it the first coat of paint. I panicked. It looked awful! A quick call to grandpa though as we were sorted. He advised leaving the walls to dry as the air bubbles would disappear. Like magic they were gone the next day!
![Viki Painting/ Decorating ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5EJBDkI6eQmkyu6eY88oi6/02d4ef5dd6df6f404f61303695969229/viki-painting.jpg)
The third hurdle was completely self inflicted by the deign we wanted. I've always been a messy painter but this time I had to paint completely straight, neat lines against each other. It wasn't as difficult as I imagined and after watching a few YouTube videos I was fine.
For our first attempt at fully decorating a room I think it went pretty well. Now onto the kitchen! ![Decorated lounge](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5EPdFkxlXGUgEsoyYqW6io/4917cc9f5ea116b6e11b485d3f28f2fc/decorated-lounge.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: We've just finished decorating our lounge so here is my decorating story and photos.

wordpressContent.en-GB: After my [New Years resolution](http://vikibell.com/posts/ted-talks-new-year-resolutions) (yes, you can still have one six months in!) to be happy I've decided to preempt the future. I'm looking into my crystal ball to see what will make me happy this month. **Improv course ** I'm starting an improv course tomorrow which will run for eight weeks. I found out about improv at a start up night where people confessed their biggest fails. A comedian spoke about how she was on stage in front of hundreds of people and got heckled. She told them to "strap in for the ride" and kept her set going, proving to herself that she could do the show. She recommended a course which Charlie signing up for immediately afterwards. Since then we've've been to various [nights](http://admin.vikibell.com/improv-night-at-the-miller/) at The Miller and I'm always sat in the audience shouting random suggestions for [Supercoth](http://supercouth.co.uk/) (Charlie's group).  Apart from the various games we've played at dinner parties this will be my first attempt at doing improv. I'm a little worried about feeling shy and not being good at it but I've tried not to think about it too much. As always my dad was very encouraging by saying "you're not funny". We'll see. ![Supercouth](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1rN5Ib22mgkqkOQaqQSoY2/8247694a362a7ab56382207e80cd0f59/supercouth.jpg) **Royal Ascot ** I end up doing quite a few things with Ascot throughout the year because of my job. I've been to various race days but never Royal Ascot. This year I'm lucky enough to go along to Ladies Day. I think I've sorted my dress so all I need now is a hat to go with it and some shoes.  Watch this space.  **Planning a**** hen do ** [Remember](https://vikibell.com/posts/wedding-part-ii) when one of my bridesmaids caught my banquet? Well she's getting married in August and I'm helping plan her hen do in July. I love planning events so the chance to plan my best buddies hen is super exciting. I'm not revealing any details in case she reads this but trust me, it's going to be pretty awesome!  ![Catching the bouquet](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/64df1rhWCWQmSY6y4wky4c/5d610bcf8307e1d6ca50014eab229f07/wedding-bouquet.jpg) **Suffolk ** In a bit of preparation for the hen do and a bit because we haven't been up there since the start of May, we're off to my [happy place](http://vikibell.com/posts/9-things-to-do-around-thorpeness-aldeburgh) for the weekend soon. This means doing all of my favourite things and spamming my Instagram feed with shots of us walking through fields. YAY! ![Sitting in the field in Suffolkj](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/DzV6WHNs4K2QSSOE8C2OA/d299cea1a6cf61d548040e8b70790c2f/suffolk-field.jpg) **Summer Fridays ** Who decided that leaving early on a Friday was a good idea? Thank you! To keep on trend with what all the cool companies are doing, my company is letting us escape at 4pm on Fridays during the summer. This inevitably means that we'll all end up across the road at the pub for the extra hour but, team bonding right? ![Champagne](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5qunUBsl0cooeuqgGcwAKI/a3da3f478305ed1018788b5a60d485cb/champagne.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: The things I'm looking forward to in June - improv, Royal Ascot, Suffolk, hen do planning. Working towards my new years resolution of being happy!

wordpressContent.en-GB: As I mentioned in my Happy June [post](http://admin.vikibell.com/happy-june/), I was lucky enough to go to Royal Ascot this year. We went along to Ladies day and were in the Royal Enclosure which was very exciting! One of my favourite bits was getting dressed up for the day - I love any excuse to dress up. I wanted something which was summery but wasn’t full of pastel flower prints. I finally found mine from Joy which I wore with a relatively simple hat and strappy shoes. Charlie was in a top hat and tails and looked very dapper! ![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5qGnC2jPwc2M4gG0u4AiWg/c3078551a2dad22309208ea261933b02/royal-ascot.jpg) We made our way across London to Waterloo to join the crowd getting the train. The train was packed with people going to Ascot so if you go, make sure you get there early or you face standing for the hour journey. We stepped off the train and followed the sea of union jack bunting to the entrance. All the staff at Ascot were so happy and helpful, the atmosphere was super. ![Royal Ascot](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6vwqXdvHhKK2y8QYcaM6GC/0f419ae316d86eeb0e5af7bb1bebdb37/royal-ascot.jpg) After a quick coffee break we made our way to the enclosure to set up. We were in the Winning Post Gardens meaning that we were on the inside of the race track in a gazebo. Crossing the track was very fun!  ![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4417dVSi8gcI8mWwqcuwqk/df4594ce13a61d9b73acaecb30492db0/royal-ascot.jpg) We’d brought along our picnic lunch and a copious amount of champagne. After popping open the bubbles it was time to welcome the Queen - it's not Royal Ascot without the royal family is it?! I opted to stay track side and managed to get very close to her. I’m pretty sure she waved directly to me after I took this shot.![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/ZhrUWMTPQkcuQe4EqO2Yu/d7e6c1179e98e2df7b4332667a17ddff/royal-ascot.jpg) Then it was time for the first race. I’m not really into horse racing but I did enjoy cheering on the winners. The track is so big that it’s only on the final straight that you can actually see the horses, otherwise you watch on the massive screens dotted around. I was amazed at the power of them as they races by and slightly appalled at the whipping sounds as the horses were encouraged to go faster. ![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6yicBnGrKwygEIGCMOcuuQ/63c2e09b258f638c355443b0d69f4fcb/royal-ascot.jpg) The day passed with a champagne blur as we watched the races and explored the main side of the Ascot track. We put a few bets on the races but didn’t win anything upsettingly - maybe our tactic of picking the best names wasn’t a good plan! After the races we headed to the bandstand for the traditional sing-song and then back to the enclosure when crackles of thunder threatened above us. ![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3U5o3EDfgAaScw2kisgWe8/a62a40e06c086eadddde9ca5a1f5c6a7/royal-ascot.jpg)We sat there for another hour chatting and drinking in hope of avoiding the crowds before heading back on the train home. Royal Ascot was a really lovely day out at a very British event and one I’d love to repeat next year. ![Royal Ascot ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2ZCzI5c1fWwaSg0Gqcioe8/e3a306072ebbbf1ed28090d7ab904dc3/royal-ascot.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: My first time in the Royal Enclosure at Royal Ascot watching the races. We loved dressing up in all our finery and waving to the Queen!

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I wanted to try out hot yoga for a while. I like the idea of twisting my body into strange shapes in a hot room and feeling good afterwards. That sounds strange, doesn't it? Well, that's pretty much what hot yoga is as I found out when I went along for a class at [Fitness First](http://www.fitnessfirst.co.uk/inside-track/lifestyle/gonna-make-sweat-hot-yoga/).
I've never been to a gym before (unless you count classes in school) so it was an evening of firsts. I'm more of a swimmer than someone who works out but yoga seemed like somewhere I could start off. We were given a quick tour of the gym when we arrived which was interesting. I don't think you'd ever catch me on the running machines it's just so boring to run in one spot. I think the best section was the freestyle area where you can do whatever exercise you like without being restricted. Apparently, it's becoming quite a popular part of gyms so maybe that'll be my next step!
![Hot Yoga](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6eV51fwHwA2ke8cQWQoOwW/ef1e60c8328b257585a545c56f2ed9e9/hot-yoga.jpg)
Anyway, all changed and pretending to look the part, we headed down to the hot room. I loved the darkness and red lighting. That combined with the heat was really calming for me as soon as I stepped inside. It's safe to say the dark lighting and sweaty bodies didn't make for great photos so you'll just have to imagine it. Or pretend I'm this girl!
![Yoga](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/208haTTs8McgwAyCkygO6I/6053cfe7c20d3c187c3dd4d35d9eb08f/yoga.jpg "Photo credit: Shutterstock")
Our teacher took us through various poses and stretches that felt pretty easy to do. The only one I struggled with was when you have to lift one leg and the opposite arm off the floor - balance is not my strong point. The 45 minute lesson passed pretty quickly. Suddenly we were at the end and sitting with our eyes shut, almost meditating. For my first experience I really enjoyed myself. I'd love to go back and try some more hot yoga - anyone want a yoga buddy?

seoTitle.en-GB: Hot yoga class at Fitness First

seoDescription.en-GB: I tried out hot yoga with a few other bloggers for the first time at Fitness First in Angel, London. It was a really good and relaxing way to exercise.

title.en-GB: A vegetarian lunch at The Gate

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I'd heard a lot of good things about [The Gate](http://thegaterestaurants.com/) but had never got around to going until the wonderful [Katy](http://www.littlemisskaty.co.uk/2016/06/vegetarian-lunch-gate-islington.html) invited me for lunch. The Gate is a totally vegetarian restaurant and although I enjoy vegetarian food I wasn't convinced how much I'd enjoy a whole vegetarian meal. Spoiler alert - the food was amazing, I didn't miss meat at all and would love to go back again. The food was so tasty and felt super healthy.
I have a few vegetarian friends and I always struggle to cook for them; it just feels like I've forgotten the meat part of the meal. The Gate's menu was bursting with inspiration and I'll definitely be referring back to it and trying to create a few of the dishes when they next come over.
![The Gate](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/62djSA35tueUs4sYC2QwU4/2bac26409ac3729ab6d05d3009c5e0f8/the-gate.jpg)
The gate is super easy to find, just south of Angel tube. They also have another one in Hammersmith if you live west. It was the perfect place for lunch (or dinner) - light and healthy feeling. There was so much that I would choose from on the menu. I changed my mind quite a few times before finally ordering the _Asian red quinoa and miso salad_. I'm slightly obsessed with Quinoa at the moment and keep making the same chicken and chorizo quinoa mix but this was a yummy alternative. I love the asian flavours and the crunch of the fresh vegetables.
![The Gate](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2azuVtNS1yYciseIkKEIuc/6a4cadd6262eef73352e1c246ac1a653/the-gate.jpg)
Whereas my salad had a strong summer vibe, Katy's was the ultimate comfort food. She'd ordered the _root vegetable hash_ which was topped with poached egg and mushroom sauce - yummy!
![The Gate](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7gvylHwwKssSYqG8iWSU8K/cf7912e258decabbd0ecbf703216bf5d/the-gate.jpg)
One thing that striked me was that the food was all so colourful, I took a peak at some of the other dishes on the tables and it all looked good! Inspired by the table next to us we also ordered a side of Polenta chips with garlic aioli which I'd never had before. They were nice but a bit boring compared to my main which was oozing with flavours.
We were so full afterwards that, although we were tempted, we skipped dessert and headed back outside to the sunshine. I'd easily recommend The Gate for some good, healthy food without a ridiculous price tag (it's around £8 for a main). It's also super close to the Sadlers Wells theatre so the perfect place to stop in for a pre-show dinner.
**All food was complimentary but as always, I wouldn't talk about it if I didn't love it.

seoDescription.en-GB: I went along for lunch at The Gate restaurant in Angel. The Gate is one of London's most successful vegetarian restaurants.

wordpressContent.en-GB: [Alec](http://alecsrestaurant.co.uk/)'s is one of 'the' places to go for lunch or dinner if you live in Essex. There's usually someone remotely famous in there and it's full of a lot of fancy looking Essex boys and girls sipping champagne. The reputation isn't really my thing but the food, setting and staff are all wonderful. It's based in Navestock which is a tiny little village about a ten minute drive out of Brentwood. We usually go to Alec's for a special occasion, I went for dinner a few years ago to celebrate my brother's 21st and we returned again recently for my other brother's 18th. This time for Sunday lunch. This means it's the same menu as evening just with an added option of roast beef. The menu had a lot of fish options as well as steak or surf and turf. I admit that I struggled to pick this time, part to do with my hangover from the night before and part because, as usual, I wanted to try everything. ![Alec's](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3S4MHC5RCw0Eom6CscUWcs/5703ea517abf8257f86ef3d242ff40fe/alecs.jpg) I had a gin and tonic whilst I was deciding - nothing like hair of the dog! Finally settling on the jumbo tiger prawn and scallops with sweet spicy soy sauce followed by the roast cod, sweet soy & caramelised spring onion glaze. My starter was wonderful I was a little upset when it was finished as it was so good. There was a larger version available for a main which my dad picked. ![Alec's prawn and scallop](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4wg9sBL0ekwaMIwYAkSMOg/d97c1f47e7b257bf8dacc26effc8d332/alecs.jpg)   When the mains arrived I wasn't a big fan of how mine looked. I almost didn't upload the photo as it's not the most appealing. Especially compared to everyone else's. It looked very small and boring and I had no idea how it was going to fill me up. Oh I was wrong. I couldn't even finish it. The fish fell apart like butter and was coated in this very rich sauce. I think I would have been happy with half of it! ![Alec's](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3NSeJ4oGnmq04qoSGSemOs/f3d763f3193c6153f29d95291ac67d34/alecs.jpg) We were pretty full so ended up skipping dessert and instead stayed sitting around the table slowly finishing our wine. If you live in Essex I'd recommend visiting Alec's for a special occasion. Just make sure you book in advance as it's always pretty busy. ![Alec's](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6PRKaPFeRGeaWowMy2i6aK/19d9f838aa4bae549ea6ed3e6b9f5b97/alecs.jpg)

title.en-GB: How to plan a hen do

wordpressContent.en-GB: If you've been following me on snapchat recently, you'll know that I've just hosted the most incredible gender neutral hen do for my buddy Ellie. I thought I'd share a few tips on how to host an awesome hen do. ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2gbrtGIRQseMy6mkmSQ2ww/63ba4d3a8943005bd8f502c9e8671e03/glastonellie.jpg) **Ask the bride to be what she wants and respect that ** It's really important to ask the bride what she wants. You'll go to loads of hen dos in your time but you'll only get thrown one so make sure she gets what she wants. Our only instructions for Glastonellie were no sashes or learner plates and lots of prosecco and sea. We had prosecco flowing all weekend and topped it off with a swim in the sea WITH prosecco on Sunday morning. ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6wzhxbxumIOYaoCek4EKoe/3627dd4b98bd3d2889a83d19c00abeae/prosecco-in-the-sea.jpg) **Break the ice with a few games ** Keep in mind that the mix of people you throw together for the hen do might not know each other that well or worst, a couple of people won't know the 'in' jokes of the crowd of school friends. It helps to have a few games up your sleeve so that you can get everyone bonding and laughing together. The classic game we played was where the groom had given us answers to a few questions about Ellie such as her favourite foods. Ellie then had to guess his answers. If she got it right we all had to drink, if she got it wrong then she had to drink. The answers weren’t always what she would have said so she had to drink a lot! Another game we played was a competition to create a wedding dress using bin bags, tin foil and sellotape. ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3TymdTDZGwQ6Ku4YIu0qcS/bfbe99e68754930cbb7d2316f43b64c7/glastonellie.jpg) **If she says no strippers that means no strippers** You can usually tell when someone says no strippers and means it. I said no strippers on my hen do but I wasn't that surprised when one turned up and proceeded to make my next half hour hilariously awkward. I actually had two and the butler in the buff who turned out to be a friend of the host was by far more funny and fun than the actual stripper (who the company sent as a replacement for the actually okay looking guy the girls had ordered - that happens a lot!) Ellie on the other had meant no strippers. She'd been to mine and watched it all and knew that it wasn't for her so we obviously didn't get one. ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2XbrMGFLK0S4eoqUAOIEui/ed2ff3638a65285f23e291c26716309f/bonfire.jpg) **Be upfront about cost ** Cost is a big thing when it comes to hen dos. Especially if you're going abroad or staying somewhere else. Keep it as cheap as you can and work out your priority. It's great spending £20 on sashes and banners but does anyone have them leftover from another hen do? We worked out our costs and detailed what it included to everyone. This meant they all knew exactly what they were getting for the price. We also covered the cost of Ellie - I don't think it's fair for the bride to pay for the hen do and spreading her cost only worked out a few pounds extra for everyone. ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6pkLD1tLVYoI86Aeoa4AQG/b82771b7e5456b5e1b269e43c2105036/glastonellie.jpg) **Surprises bring unlimited smiles ** You can fit so many surprises into a day or weekend for a hen do and it's so lovely to watch the bride's face light up as she realised what's been planned. With months of planning on the run up to the wedding, it's also just nice for her to have a weekend off where she doesn't have to think of anything. Our biggest surprise of the weekend was mini golf. Both the bride and groom love it so when we knew there wasn't one near us we decided to make one in the woods. By rearranging a few tree trunks, making some flags and racking up the leaves we had a 3 hole course. I had thought that it wouldn't work as well as it did but we split into three teams and kept score with some specific scorecards I'd designed. We played the whole course twice and were laughing every time someone got a ball through and Ellie face. It was so much fun. ![Mini Golf](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/15tb9czrb8aUeiGGSQ2Ko4/857fd535da696ff2c5185c6f19fc405f/mini-golf.jpg) **Have fun ** Lastly, enjoy it! You're hosting and therefore need to make sure things run smoothly but as long as you've worked out the day plans and foreseen any issues (like a thunderstorm passing over us as we were about to play mini golf) you can sit back and enjoy the weekend. Don't forget to take lots of pictures! ![Glastonellie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5hre1hcLwsiYcYAAMeWE6Y/eeff3c099bedbed46c1f16f20eb65597/glastonellie.jpg)

seoTitle.en-GB: Tips to plan an incredibly memorable hen do!

seoDescription.en-GB: I've just hosted the most incredible gender neutral hen do for my buddy and these are my tips for planning and hosting one yourself.

wordpressContent.en-GB:
[Latitude festival](http://www.latitudefestival.com/) happens just around the corner from Shellpits and I went for the first time five years ago. There were various jokes last year about how we couldn't go as that was the same weekend as our wedding. So we decided to all go this year to celebrate our anniversary!
We went along for the Saturday. It was so nice to just go along for a day and skip the grime of the campsites. I only had one band that I wanted to see, Soulwax, so it was really cool to be laid back and just discover new acts. We spent most of the morning watching comedy. We started off with joe Bor as Jasper Cromwell-jones, a posh twat talking about his life as an adventure. He had various 'posh-offs' with the audience throughout the set. Next up was Boy With Tape On His Face. I'd seen him a few years ago but couldn't quite remember. Describing his set won't do it justice but it's well worth watching. ![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6i4IPIx0Hes6guGUm86Q8s/2feb9d9a53338af18ec4d8cb80bea9e6/latitude-festival.jpg)
Then we had a beer break and met up with the rest of the group who we'd managed to lose. We picked our next act randomly and ended up going to see Marcel Lecont - the French alter ago of Alexis Dubis. His set was based around interaction with the audience, sexual poetry and taking the piss out of Brits. We'd all written a few moans down for him before the show started including out worst day at work, worst sexual experience and worst experience abroad. All of our experiences got read out and the rest of the audience ended up turning and laughing at us as Marcel proceeded to make fun of what we'd said. There was a few points in the show where I was crying with laughter. He's heading to Edinburgh Fringe so check him out of you're going!
![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3dEvrcI7HGCOGMGisEU8W8/2a2a4291b1873019bc72d4e85f3032c0/latitude-festival.jpg)
After another beer break and some lunch we went across to Paul Merton. As we got near we saw that the queue to get into the tent was ridiculously long. The steward told us it wasn't worth joining so we sat in the woods to watch on a screen instead. It was still hilariously good, even with the trees slightly in the way. They played loads of the improv games I recognised and it made me so happy that I've discovered improv. It was a really chilled vibe, just sitting in the woods with a bottle of wine watching improv.
![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6Qdng8hva02o2MSoCseqSs/c5aa54542a7729a07f367a559abe04ab/latitude-festival.jpg)After meeting up with the others (who we'd lost again!) at the main stage we had a quick play in the playground with Mabel -our excuse to go down the helter skelter! Then we were back in the comedy tent to watch Josh Widdicombe who was headlining.
![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6ZyABrjbhKuEI6egWCuEM8/5f6237b523822e9e2f7f1d8adab839ce/latitude-festival.jpg)
 Straight after that we ran across to the waterfront stage where India and I had a tango lesson. We tried our best but it's safe to say that we won't be spinning each other around anytime soon! ![Tango dancing](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4JuTF2AC5OUUyOw6wiUAcW/c08bbbadebf7b03c1fbdddbbd5328f8c/tango-dancing.jpg)
It was coming up to 8pm by this point and some of the adults headed home leaving us to hit the music stages. We saw Chvrches who I'd only just started listening to a week or so before. They had a wonderful stage presence and Lauren Mayberry was jumping around with so much energy it was a wonder that she had any breath left to sing! ![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2fYz59NqIsA6cMoMqAIIQK/a8cd93ec6a668715953cf65d4a022e7d/latitude-festival.jpg)![IMG_1706](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4t2WWPZ1sQ8mMaiaMCyA4C/68ce12ac01384bda8b7a09c60044340e/img-1706.jpg)After another beer and food break we headed to the BBC Radio stage ready to see Soulwax. With the day being so chilled it was nice to have a band to jump around too. They had three drum sets on stage and everyone was so energetic it was difficult not to throw myself around to the beats. Our flailing arms and jumping about was definitely more of a work out than dancing but it was so much fun.
![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6Pvy2Py8ScMm4yIA6UyAYA/9e4538fbdd3aada5f6cab50766dfd96b/latitude-festival.jpg)
 Nearing the end of the day, we had an hour to wait until our taxi so took a stroll around the woods. Latitude at night feels truly magical. The trees are lit up with fairy lights and there are loads of little tents with strange things going on inside. My favourite was the robot tent - we saw lots of cardboard boxes which looked like robot heads so put them on and went inside this tiny gazebo  playing Robot Rock with a DJ and strobe lighting. Another part of the woods had projections on trees showing old films. The whole thing feels so surreal that is wonderful. ![Latitude Festival](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4RhNIiHw0wa8KoE42OyK8s/556c401728b585c47306777e3f8d9fa9/latitude-festival.jpg)
 Latitude has so much to offer and it was so good to spend time at a festival discovering new talents and experiences rather than just sticking by the music stages. Every time I've been to Latitude I've only known one or two people on the lineup but I've come away with so many different artists in my head. Whether you go for a weekend or just a day Latitude is the perfect festival for discovering new talents and having a really fun day.

seoTitle.en-GB: Saturday at Latitude Festival, Henham Park

seoDescription.en-GB: Spending our first anniversary at Latitude festival in Henham Park, Suffolk. Discovering comedy, improv, poetry and music.

wordpressContent.en-GB: As well as going to Latitude to celebrate our first wedding anniversary, we also planned a trip around some of Europe. A few of our friends were heading to a festival in Amsterdam so instead of jumping on a plane and going straight there we decided to stop off at a few places along the way, fitting in five different places in seven days. **Lille** On Tuesday we jumped on the Eurostar and headed to Lille. We booked the tickets about three weeks before and found that the premium class was actually cheaper than standard - one to watch out for. We arrived in Lille at about 3pm and our Airbnb host, Frank, was waiting to greet us. After a quick stop off at the flat we headed to the city centre armed with a map and a few scribbled suggestions. We'd done some last minute research about Lille on the train but Frank had mentioned that the buildings were far prettier outside than in and to simply walk around the Grand Place - the main square. ![Lille](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3VptTGp5VuGeQc8aAkS2Kg/1682e8f536c7299f8d8092f3a63d8e66/lille.jpg) We saw the Notre Dame de la Treille and wondered the back streets before settling down at a little restaurant for dinner. ![Lille food](http://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/IMG_1790.jpg) The next day we headed out for breakfast and ended up walking around the Parc Zoologique. It was a fairly small zoo but we made the most of it and even ended up catching a few Pokemon on the way! Then we picked up our bags and caught the train to the next destination on our Europe tour…. ![Lille zoo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3LnA3X8t7ice6iWmS64uCg/9eeba8f072844a7a4a8d7e39062025d3/lille-zoo.jpg) **Ghent** We arrived in Ghent around 3 and walked straight to our next Airbnb. This was one of my favourites in terms of decorations as there was so much memorabilia and music instruments having from the walls. After dropping our bags our host directed us to the city centre towards Gentse Feesten - Ghent's annual street festival. Around 2 million people attend the festival each year making it one of the biggest in Europe. The first stop on our festival tour was a the Saint Nicholas Church which had a bar inside. Who could say no to sampling a few Belgium beers in a church?! ![Gentse Feesten](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4TZ576RcmA44auY0GwgMOy/f5f809faf0ccba8aeacfaa562473d66b/gentse-feesten.jpg) Sticking to Belgium culture we next headed off for mussels and chips, with a few more beers of course. Then we took a walk around each of the stages listening to tribute bands, local pop acts and a DJ in a mardi gras tent.![Gentse Feesten](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7IycuOKDcsE6Ke2aagyAYu/11feffe38beee47bb1f67f594c2464d3/gentse-feesten.jpg)![Gentse Feesten](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/cuS6dyEdryqk2isSeA8WQ/61d5c4a7621267506ec8da04f26e65c5/gentse-feesten.jpg) We couldn’t get over how beautiful all the building were and how juxtaposed they were behind the stages that had been set up.![Gentse Feesten](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4UKs57Kd04Eqw06omykkiE/e5d3bdc57470d24d73a1c38f82bc8fa2/gentse-feesten.jpg) **Bruges** The next day we packed up and caught an early train to Bruges. Another city, another Airbnb, this one was the whole house to ourselves and it was SO CUTE! After an explore we grabbed some lunch at De Middenstand which was a recommendation by our host. After running around Lille and Ghent it was quite a contrast and felt quite fancy. They even brought us a few taster dishes which were so tasty. ![De Middenstand](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5pdQ9WGNKEW4IQOgM4c6i0/9f811f4541e9477a3a5363b65986a10c/de-middenstand.jpg) ![De Middenstand](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6FXFZ898zYusW60y0myYkc/1a4fbae5b45c910099baa73cc4649b94/de-middenstand.jpg) Then Richard arrived. For absolutely no reason he had decided to cycle to Amsterdam so we were meeting up with him for each of his stops. This was his first stop from London so we were there to cheer him on and hand him a beer as he arrived. We wanted to make the most of our afternoon so took a boat tour around the canals to see all of Bruges. It’s quite a small city so this was the best way to see everything at once and learn a little about it.![Bruges canal](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/18gpoegWoqyScmKsyewOCe/5bd3edb4a74444626e3d0d3128cf7b98/bruges-canal.jpg) ![Bruges](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4divnx2N7imKEy48aUmQSi/06406cad5dc6c776d7a5ebd6e9ed68af/bruges.jpg) We set off early again the next morning this time for Rotterdam. If you’re planning a visit to Bruges, I’d recommend 2 days so you can explore but it’s quite small so you don’t need too long.![Bruges](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3tRwo0vYA0yGi6i0oEqsy6/e3d7332cdeb7e33c41cfea567cd8529b/bruges.jpg) **Rotterdam** After a bit of a delay in Antwerp because our train got cancelled we finally arrived in [Rotterdam](http://admin.vikibell.com/a-weekend-in-rotterdam/) to see Catriona. After three nights in random homes it was really lovely to be chilling in her parents house. I went to Rotterdam last year to visit and her family are always super welcoming. ![Rotterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4WLcVnymc8gG4e0Wm26u0G/eb95d5f93d425e411ea1215b6ba349cf/rotterdam.jpg) As I’d done most of the tourist things last year we decided to take it easy and cycle around the city centre to have a few beers. We raced back home to be there for when Richard arrived after his 9 hour cycle from Bruges. He still had a smile on his face so we decided to all cycle for a tapas dinner around Kralingse Bos (the big park and lake).![Rotterdam](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3mqXhj45XO46s802eEWoSS/b059abc8701fa9cb820be15cce83a1e6/rotterdam.jpg) **Amsterdam** Our final stop of our Europe tour. We made it! Matt and Rob were waiting for us our last Airbnb just outside of the city centre. We spent two nights here so made the most of seeing the city and catching up over yet more beers on the first day before heading out to Liquidity festival on the Sunday.![Liquicity](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/43JJjpfDoIwyG66eguoK0A/f2226f4a99763eff0e2a11c4bce35cca/liquicity.jpg) The whole holiday had built up to the festival. Liquicity is an online drum and bass music community which started off as a YouTube channel. This was the second year of the festival so although it is still quite small I was excited to see what was there and how I’d handle a full day of drum and bass! ![Liquicity](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5EcmlDNjC8k8aAqk82m4Qo/97305830c06a8f7e11ae10a22e907648/liquicity.jpg) ![Liquicity ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3xp5Yohfm0c6uASoOQIUAq/6bd568c8df8977c759cb089b8362d3ba/liquicity.jpg)I had so much fun though, from quite a sleepy beginning we all found energy to jump about to the music. We weren’t the only ones making some strange movements, if you were sat on the floor you could see the ground rippling with the bass from the DJs. It looked mesmerising and also quite scary. My favourite part of the day was the Pendulum DJ set which headlined the main stage. Richard and I bounced about like crazy and covered each other in glitter.![Liquicity](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/hphvGWq1tC0gKeQMwegCE/12f23fb73d35ff322a1eab80451c1344/liquicity.jpg) A quick dash around Europe was so much fun. I’d never thought about making going to a festival so much of a holiday but it’s something I’d love to repeat again with another festival. It contrasted so much to the beginning of the holiday which was so chilled. That’s another few cities ticked off my bucket list!

seoDescription.en-GB: We took a trip around Europe stopping off in Lille, Ghent, Bruges, Rotterdam and Amsterdam where we went to Liquicity Festival.

wordpressContent.en-GB: Ever year we hold The Wood Party. It is what it says on the tin- a party in a wood. Ever year it gets bigger and better and this is the sixth time we've done it. From what started as a couple of teenagers sitting around a campfire has transformed into a night of mischief and mayhem in a wood and definitely one to remember. It doesn't happen by accident though, it takes planning to get people to the right place at the right time with the right atmosphere. Here are my tips for planning a party - whether that's in a wood or not!![13123068_10156834676545621_7013281413816248716_o](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6r3wMQTXNK0SoAGiYCowMS/ee4ff5a891df1656ebc3d1ffdc0ed513/13123068-10156834676545621-7013281413816248716-o.jpg) **(Some) people are lazy ** How often have you not planned your night out until it's time to go out the door? How far in advance do you plan how to get to a friend birthday party? Okay, saying that people are lazy is quite a generalisation but make sure you're upfront with you plans. We make the wood party as simple as possible to get to, from detailing train times to organising seats in cars. If it's far or complicated to get to people won't come; unless you make it easy for them. **(Some) people are skint ** A night out in Brixton? Sure. A night out in the middle of nowhere? Uh, how much will that set me back?! Not a lot in fact but it doesn't seem like that when you add up transport costs. It costs roughly £20 in petrol to get there (split that between 4 and that's about the cost of a pint), food costs around £5 (another pint), speaker hire costs £5 each (another pint) and booze costs however much you choose to drink. So for the price of three pints you've got yourself to a party in a wood - simple! Whereas a night out in Brixton costs a tube fare, entry fee, booze and possibly an uber home with a stop off at the chicken shop. Make sure you're upfront with your guests about any costs and if you're buying things for everyone beforehand (food) get the money in advance, that way any spare can go towards the all important booze table! **Atmosphere ** Okay, we're done on the people front but what else? Think about the kind of vibe you'll want to have and how to go about creating it. Think about decorations, music, themes and actually where you put everything. If you want the focus to be drinking then make sure the drinks are in the middle and on display whereas if you want the focus to be around dancing then make sure that's front and centre. Last year was our first with a generator and decks; it made a massive difference. Suddenly people were keen to show off their DJ skills, the music got louder and the night got crazier! ![Wood Party](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/nVvclxLdbEQcK2seG2w6i/9b2741f7f37d94e6216bd4d307d082d8/wood-party.jpg) **It gets dark ** Well duh! But when you hold an event in the middle of nowhere it gets pitch black dark. That's where solar lights come in. They're relatively cheap to buy and they last a long time. We arrive early and string them up between the trees and on the ground, marking out pathways and different areas. Come twilight the wood is light up like a mystical fairy wonderland. **Making memories ** After one hell of a party your memories are bound to be a little fuzzy. Make sure you take loads of photos and collect any that other people take afterwards. They work really well for us promoting the event next year too! It's only a couple of days until this year's Wood Party and planning is in full swing. If you're coming along, we've got a few big surprise in store too... ![P1000041](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/cvwlGHvOmcukEsSqYY2wq/009aefd3be7c45e764ba32575b93b3b0/p1000041.jpg)

Remember last year when I wrote about how much I love swimming and how it's totally going to be that hobby I pick back up? Well I may have failed myself a little there. That hobby all but lasted five sessions to the overcrowded pool in Victoria. I lacked the motivation to go by myself and whenever I did try and go swimming I got bored with repetitively swimming up and down, up and down, up and down..... So when an email landed in my inbox from [Fitness First](http://www.fitnessfirst.co.uk/inside-track/workouts/stay-cool-at-the-pool-this-summer/) for a swimming evening I thought I had no excuse. ![P1030425](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3RJiArpLvqW2YESkQwmoAM/b016977b28ce8c60f8f3b36c19197f15/p1030425.jpg)
Two weeks before I went along to meet Jono, the manager who gave me a private tour around the gym as well as a few swimming lessons. I'm not ashamed to say that it was the second time I've ever been into a gym, the first being last month when I tried out [hot yoga](https://vikibell.com/posts/hot-yoga-class). I had this idea in my head that it would be full fo gym bunnies each staring each other down as they lifted their ten ton weights, turns out that's not the case. No one else was staring at each other, no one was laughing and all the gym staff were super friendly.
Anyway, after a quick tour it was time for my lesson. We got in the pool and warned up. The last lesson I had was when I was around 5 years old so I was interested to see what Jono had to teach me. We started working through a diagram called BLABT which stands for body, legs, arms, breathing and time. For each of these Jono explained a few drill exercises, one of my favourites was where you swim front crawl but have your hands in fists. It just feels funny but improves your stroke loads when you switch back.
![Swimming Hammersmith ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6HVkGlCP7y0WuqumE2cSkM/bd0220df442c011c430a962de52b8289/swimming-hammersmith.png)
I met up with Jono four times before the swimming event, twice I managed to drag Charlie along with the promise of a steam and sauna afterwards - which by the way is awesome in the Fitness First as they have all mood lighting and you feel like you're in a spa! I managed to fit my lessons in before or after work although I definitely prefer the before work lessons as they made me feel so much more energised for the day. For someone who likes to sleep this was the perfect excuse to get me out of bed.
Anyway, the day finally came around for the #FFSwimSqaud meet and I found myself on poolside listening to Richard Stannard explain about his career as a triathlon superstar. The lesson passed pretty quickly with us all swimming lengths and trying to concentrate on different aspects of our strokes. Richard demonstrated a few techniques too and it was pretty cool to watch a pro swimming gliding through the water.
![Swimming](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/16V6MTnLKqyecCeIGs8Eu4/aa49bb3a4bb8dddaa654062f69a3b893/swimming.jpg)
What did I learn from my lessons with Jono and session with Richard? Well quite a lot actually:
* Make sure you keep your body flat in the water * Keep your head down - except when you breath of course! * Let your arms skip your hips as they they pull backwards * Kick from your hips not your feet - you can do this by twisting your hips as you swim * Make your body as long as you can in the water * Relax - if it feels natural then it's probably right
I also now know a couple of drills I can do when I go swimming, meaning I don't just swim up and down pointlessly. I can actually aim for something and I'm more aware of how it feels to slice through the water. I've also discovered how easy it is to go swimming before work, now all I need to do is find a pool near me!!
![Swimming](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5yw9nfOEaAu2ACac4acCqC/ae415b8ca89b8143d17c2839a00680ed/swimming.jpg)
*photo credit to [Abbi!](http://www.UpraisedLiving.com)

seoDescription.en-GB: Getting back into swimming with a few sessions at Fitness First with Jono and Richard Stannard. Concentrating on drills and improving my front crawl

title.en-GB: The best and worst gig: Elton John through a lens

wordpressContent.en-GB:
There is reason my photos aren't the best or the most refined. I don't take time to get the perfect shot of my food, I just enjoy it. I take a quick snap as a memory of where I've been and carry on whatever it is I'm doing. My time isn't taken up by living my life through a screen.
What I saw last week was disappointing and that disappointment hasn't vanished overnight. Apple Music gave me a wonderful gift. The gift of a lifetime - to see [Elton John in the Roundhouse](http://www.roundhouse.org.uk/blog/2016/09/elton-john-at-apple-music-festival/). The Roundhouse isn't like any venue out there, it can hold a tiny capacity of just 1,700 which is nothing when compared to the Brixton academy or O2\. As the name suggests, the stage is also round meaning the audience can get closer. Elton John isn't someone I listen to much but I know most of his songs. I'd say that other Elton fans might have deserved the tickets a little more but I'd won them and I wanted to make sure I appreciated that gift.
As the lights dropped, the crowd cheered and I felt a tightness in my chest - I was about to see a legend. I was about to see the man who'd played for the queen, the man who was legendary throughout the world. Or so I thought.
What I saw was 100s of phones being lifted in the air, friends and families dialled on FaceTime and even a woman in front of me casually checking her Twitter and Facebook feeds. I then saw heads bend in odd directions and girls going up on tiptoes just so they could peak around the screens and get a glimpse of the stage which was a couple of metres in front of them.
![Elton John](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/58cBWa5staK2ywwkE68Uuc/176e3a1e31671346e42a656bd1a4605a/img-3115.jpg)
In all transparency, I admit that at the beginning of his second song I took a very quick snap. I shot my phone up into the air and captured an image then took it back down. I wanted a memory of the moment and an image I could refer back to but at the same time I wanted to watch the gig through my own eyes, not through a screen. If I wanted to watch through a screen wouldn't it have been easier to stay home and live stream it?
All was not lost, in the moments where my view was clogged full of phone screens I shut my eyes and appreciated that at least I was there hearing the music.
Elton John and his band were incredible. Everyone on stage looked so so happy to be there, as did his special guests which he brought on to perform their own songs. I was so grateful to have been given the chance to see the legend; it's just a shame that the crowd ruined the experience.
Life isn't there to be lived through a lens. Photos are a great way of reliving memories but they shouldn't stand in the way of enjoying the moment. Go out this week, put the phone down and take some time to appreciate something special.

seoDescription.en-GB: Winning tickets to see Elton John at an intimate gig could have been the best gig ever. The music was incredible but the crowd was horrendous.

title.en-GB: Pasta making at La Cucina Caldesi

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Remember last year when we went to the [Jane Packer ball](http://admin.vikibell.com/jane-packer-foundation-flower-ball/) and we won a pasta making course in the auction? (I use won in a very loose way - do you win an auction when you've had too many lemonades and think it's funny to try and outbid your mates?) Anyway, after one ludicrous evening we found ourselves enrolled onto a pasta making course.
The six of us turned up nice and early at [La Cucina Caldesi](http://caldesi.com/) where Stefano and Marco greeted us with deliciously fresh Italian coffee. We didn't know too much about the course so they explained what we were doing and we were set to work on the pasta. First we each cracked eggs into a mixing bowl with flour and kneaded them together. Once everything had had a chance to bind together, we set them aside wrapped in cling film and got to work on the other ingredients.
Somehow Sarah and I got entrusted with a rather large box of cherry tomatoes to chop.... yummy! We ended up eating more than we chopped but luckily no one noticed. The boys prepared garlic, chillies and the filling for the ravioli whist India and David were on dessert duty.![Pasta Making](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1acNgKGXZCe4YEIw62MaAk/d310feee78f2b6bad9526cad35b88386/pasta-making.jpg)
Then it was time to roll out the pasta. Each ball was chopped into two/ three smaller balls and put through the pasta maker. We started with the ravioli which was the trickiest. The balls went through the press about six times, each time we changed the settings to make the gap smaller and the pasta sheet thinner. We did this until it went through the thinnest setting, then it was ready to use. A spoonful of ricotta and mint filling was put onto the middle of the sheet, then we folded it over itself and cupped around it. Excess pasta was chopped off making it into a rather recognisable ravioli shape. We pressed the edges in with a fork and set it aside for later. For six of us we make about 30 little raviolis.
Next up was tagliatelle. This was my favourite part. We put the pasta ball through the press, working down the settings until the penultimate one which we did twice. Then we put our thin sheet through a kind of grate which we turned and out came tagliatelle! We threw this in a little flour to stop it sticking then set that aside too.
With everything prepped it was time to cook. Salty water was boiling on the hob. Before you cook pasta you should make sure it's nice and salty and tastes like the sea in Southend - just less pollution! In went the ravioli for a couple of minutes whilst the sauces cooked. The first was a mint butter to go with the ravioli. The second was the tomorrow, garlic and chilli sauce and the final one was homemade pesto. ![Pasta Making](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4DZ5RiwGgEuOAG8y2ys8Cq/4a8d7e2a19080431e4df13db18f1af5e/pasta-making.jpg)
After all our hard work it was time to sit down and enjoy it. With a bottle or two of wine of course. I usually make quite a big and flavoursome sauce which takes the taste away from the pasta, so it was quite different to have three sauces which complimented it rather than masked it. Using fresh ingredients made such a difference to the overall taste - and it was so easy!
If you haven't given pasta making a go, [get yourself involved](http://caldesi.com/). Or at least ditch the pre-bought sauce and make your own.![Pasta making](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4bYw9HmkXmoGI2uEAMSGEk/d72786edf8f2e3191d888f408dff2c8f/pasta-making.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: A Saturday morning spent making fresh Italian pasta at La Cucina Caldesi. We made three different sauces for ravioli and tagliatelle

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Barcelona feels like one of those places everyone's been to. It certainly felt like I should have been there before  Everyone has nice things to say about it so I was very excited to see what was in store.
As I was in charge of booking our flights I ensured we had the longest time possible on holiday. We caught a flight out of London on Thursday evening and landed back again in time for work on Monday. Perfect. We stayed with our friend, Ray who had helpfully left a to do list for us to work through.
**Friday **
After a light breakfast we headed out to tick off the most touristy thing in Barcelona, [Sagrada Familia.](http://www.sagradafamilia.org/en/) As expected, it was stunning. Knowing that this was first started in 1882 and it's still being worked on is crazy. Imagine how many people have helped construct this in one way or another? What we thought was the front (we later found out it's due to be the side) was eye catching.
The back contrasted it slightly and seemed more traditional. The whole thing is due to be finished in 2026 and is set to be the highest building in Barcelona and the tallest religious building in Europe.
![Sagrada Familia](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2eJc1MdPfSUYIC2Ms4aqyg/62608542b76587588d5f8a81adbee454/sagrada-familia.jpg)
We jumped onto the metro and headed off to the port. The metro was a really convenient way to get around Barcelona with one ride working out to be a euro. After a walk around the port we stopped off at a random restaurant for tapas - when in Spain!
![Tapas Barcelona](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3fxofQCweka4ccOeI8CeYE/e45862ab8d3234044570004184434fb2/tapas-barcelona.jpg)
We spend the afternoon paddling our feet in the sea and walking along the beach. Then it was time to meet Ray for dinner. He took us to his favourite restaurant, Llamber. We had tapas again but this time it was on a whole different level. It was the best tapas I've ever had. It's not the cheapest of places but if you ever go to Barcelona you have to go. ![Llamber Barcelona](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2ttsxvuh5C0qKuG2wu8gmU/adda06f1df0295b8eccf9b87725c6c85/llamber.jpg)
Then it was time for a surprise. After a stop off to pick up some cava, we jumped in a taxi and Ray muttered something in Spanish to the driver. Next thing I knew, we were them zooming off through the city and up into the hills. We got closer and saw loads of people gathering around. After showing some tickets to the gate man, Ray ushered us in. We were at a giant open cinema setting, overlooking Barcelona. They put these on throughout the summer and this was the last. No one knew what the film would be other than it was in English. The music stated and gasps spread through the crowd. It was the Godfather 2\. Not the easiest film to pay attention to when you're a couple of bottles down but we made do by playing drinking games as we watched- much more fun than keeping up with the plot!
**Saturday **
We were up and out early, on our way to the Park Güell, another item on our list. We didn't know what to expect but we had a fair idea when we got out of the metro and started walking up hill. Park Güell overlooks the whole of Barcelona so the views were pretty insane. ![Barcelona](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7xrwtlY8ta8CkYEyWGCGsY/a370f4e67ccb471c29449d977347bcad/barcelona.jpg)
![Park Güell](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3Tz61s2Gty62K008u2wogM/61b5f889f2392b397089f259407d0576/park-guell.jpg)
Afterwards we walked down via the Passeig De Gràcia where there are a couple of Gauldi buildings including Casa Batlló. The style is so unique to anything I've seen and they're a must see.
It was approaching lunchtime so we went to the Mercado de La Boqueria to tick another thing off Ray's to do list. The market was split into different sections and had big stalls of meats, fresh (and even alive) fish and lots of smoothies and sweets. We had to get a meat cone whilst we walked around and I think it's be best cold meats I've ever had; so delicious! We picked out a little stall on the edge of the market for lunch and had a fish platter.
![Mercado de La Boqueria](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6iR983eUSWCqu2mkaCu0yc/34acba212d6878855de2dad166ecf1d9/mercado-de-la-boqueria.jpg)
Then it was time to hit the beach! We avoided the tourists on main beach and instead walked along to Nova beach. I paddled in the sea whilst Charlie guarded our belongings - that's the only annoying this about going on holiday with just two of you; you can't just leave your stuff on the beach and go in the sea together.
After getting cleaned up at home we headed to [Pax 49](http://www.pax49bcn.com/)- a cocktail bar Ray had recommended. We took prime seats at the bar and sampled a few of their cocktails. I chose an expresso martini to begin as I was tired - that's pretty much the same as having a coffee right?!
![Pax 49](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/ZP5PyWCscUM8IMy6mAA2s/0a44d125432fc07b1700b23d781cb4f2/pax-49.jpg)
We got so wrapped up in conversation we didn't realise how late it was and we hadn't eaten. On the recommendation of the bartenders, who we got to know whilst sipping numerous cocktails, we went to Napoli - a tiny pizza place just around the corner. I would much rather go somewhere on the recommendation of a local, you get a much better feel for a place which is one of the reasons Barcelona was so good - everyone kept recommending places for us!
**Sunday**
The next day was our last so we took another look at our to do list and decided to tick off nudist beach. I've never been to one before so I though it would be a bit of a errr... experience? I'd expected to see a sea of naked bodies but actually only about a third of the people were naked. The rest were at least partially wearing bikinis or shorts. The beach was a lot less busy than the tourist beaches so I can see the appeal!
We did a little sunbathing and I had a few dips in the sea before we walked back along to the more popular beach where there was food stands. It was our last day so we couldn't avoid having paella. We sat down in the sunshine overlooking the beach and the waves .... perfect!
![Paella](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6Osu5iA1Usom8qUwwOEW2g/e718eea801ed63e49f19072b34f54691/paella.jpg)
The rest of the day was pretty uneventful between sunbathing and a last catch up with Ray in the evening. We caught a stupidly early flight home from next morning in time to get back to work. I think we left a lot of things unexplored but we managed to fit in a lot for our long weekend without it being too stressful.
![Barcelona](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/32MJA0HOSs66A82AqSqmmU/c954ee053bf4f11b4b45eaf5bc79c33f/barcelona.jpg)

I love the time of year when the leaves fall from the trees and crunch beneath your feel. I love the nights turning darker and everything getting a little spookier and of course, I love Halloween. [Last year](http://admin.vikibell.com/halloween/) we ended up with quite last minute plans but everything seemed to fall into place. One of my favourite parts of Halloween is the fancy dress; not just wearing it but making it. We spent our whole Saturday thinking up what we were going to do then creating it. I think it was pretty good for a days effort!!
![](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6xOQHy7kWIg0mWiUa0SAy2/3d4f3fe16f835b162686e0dced28edac/.jpg)
Anyway, with Halloween fast approaching here's a few tips for you.
**The costume **
