Go big or go home! You can always be underdressed at Halloween but I don't think you can ever be over dressed. You're never too old for a fancy dress box and there are a couple of essential items you need to keep in there:
* A corset (if you're female!) - my corset has become part of countless fancy dress costumes. It started as the base for 17 year old me's poison ivy costume and had since been used for clowns, vampires and whores. * A black/ white t shirt (if you're a guy) - you can use this as a base for a lot of things, just rip it up and pair it with a few items and you'll be a pirate, zombie, priest .... * Spray paint - this is pretty essential. If you don't have time to dye clothes then just spray paint them. It's how we made Charlie's waistcoat and shoes for last year's costume * Liquid eyeliner - you can use this to sketch the outlines of your face paint or draw a few intricate details like this cobweb. * Black and white face paint - I buy snazaroo because it's the best I've found. It's quite expensive for a one off purchase but it lasts for ages. Failing that you can use a mixture of eye shadows and eye pencils to draw on your face too. * Black plimsoles- my ancient primary plimsoles have become part of many a Halloween outfits. They're small and don't stand out meaning the suit the purpose of a shoe without looking out of place * Fake blood - for Halloween only. Unless you're going to a Halloween party in March as I one did, but that's another story.
![Fancy Dress](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2dKZg7VD60KyiyCigeEywU/3a1324ad3e3ba4f7d4903be47db81811/fancy-dress.jpg)
**The cocktails **
This is a cocktail I made a while ago when we threw a Halloween party at our flat. The recipe below is for one but you can double or triple up to make more of a punch as I did.
_For the eyeball ice cube _
Put either a blueberry or a raspberry inside of a lychee, space them out on baking trays and freeze overnight.
_For the drink _
Mix 25ml vodka, 25ml white rum and 50ml cranberry juice. Top with lemonade and garnish with your ice cubes and serve in a jar.
![Halloween cocktail](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2l2ckp7x8IKeUICQKeq4EY/af4739eab610ac4dbcac9edcb98aab5c/halloween-cocktail.jpg)
**The plans **
I somehow always leave plans to last minute but so far haven't found a bad night. I do have to shift through a lot of boring looking options though. Most clubs will put on a Halloween night just because they can. You can go out dancing any night of the year so try and make sure there is something else on offer too. Be aware of boat trips  all these do is shove you on a boat down the Thames with some music, overpriced drinks and lots of people.
Last year we went to [The Pond](http://pond-dalston.com/) in Dalston which put on a feast for us with circus acts and live music. It was quite a small venue but everyone was dressed up and it seemed really friendly. This year I've picked a club night but it's promising circus acts, cabaret and dancing - fingers crossed it'll be good!! I still need to decide what to dress as though....

seoDescription.en-GB: My Halloween costume essentials including a cocktail for pre-drinks and where you should go out to celebrate!

wordpressContent.en-GB:
On Friday night I went along to another immersive theatre experience with [CoLab](http://www.colabtheatre.co.uk/hunted/). This one was called HUNTED and I had no idea what to expect. The only instructions we were given was to turn up at Waterloo station at a certain time with a fully charged phone, 8mb of data and headphones; at 7.30pm exactly we had to text a number. The number then sent us a link to a file which would get us to safety. Security protocol 74 had been initiated.
What happened next? Well I don't want to ruin it. Let's just say that we were hunted through the streets of London. There was running involved and a few small spaces to climb through. We suspected everyone. Anyone could be watching us and we had to get away. Fast. We had to survive. Our lives hung on the decisions we made and how fast we acted.
We had taken a few friends along who had never seen immersive theatre before and they really enjoyed it. One wasn't sure he wanted to take it seriously to begin with but I pointed out that the more you take it seriously, the more you enjoy then experience. You need to believe that you really are being hunted by baddies rather than actors and you need to throw yourself into the scene and enjoy it.
Want to try it out for yourself? HUNTED is on every Thursday, Friday and Saturday until the end of November and tickets cost just £11 each - bargain! ![HUNTED](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2fDfYoXUYgY0gKs4ia2AAO/f3abba1a6cd848e751ad3743923bc09b/hunted.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: On Friday night I went along to another immersive theatre experience with CoLab. This one was called HUNTED and I had no idea what to expect.

title.en-GB: A Tuesday night theatre trip to Dead Funny

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I can't remember the last time I went to a West End show. Booking tickets to something that's on for months always drops down my priorities list. When [Erica](http://www.imbeingerica.com/) asked if I wanted to come along to see Dead Funny with her I couldn't turn it down. And go for dinner first? Even better!! ![All Bar One](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5GEV3iLlsscke4eo4Gqq4I/029c77dd0787ccc882de4e938a3e3a60/all-bar-one.jpg)
We both met at [All Bar One](http://www.allbarone.co.uk/) which had just been refurbished. It looked pretty swanky in there with funky looking lamps hanging over the tables, not to mention possibly the best neon sign in existence! ![All Bar One](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/eKQhnMqZS8EaYiCOsYiEG/1e66104e5bdbf153ac792bc4c5b80f04/all-bar-one.jpg)
It also wasn't a tourist trap either, despite being located in Leicester Square. Fitting in a decent meal before the theatre can sometimes feel quite rushed but this didn't at all. The waiter, Juan, kept checking in on us to see if we needed anything and made sure our food came out quickly. We started with a sharing platter which had calamari (yum), chicken skewers, haloumi and chorizo skewers, home made tortillas (with just the right amount of tang) and hummus and pitta. We devoured it over a bottle of wine before tucking into steak with parmesan chips. Oh, and sweet potatoes fries because, well, you can never not order them when they're on a menu. I'd never had parmesan fries before but there were really good although quite cheesy for a whole portion. ![All Bar One](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3sift54x7qUsGQQgWi8sCY/8f6245459d594086ab590f856adc3abb/all-bar-one.jpg)
Bellies full we realised we had fifteen minutes until the show started so we scooted along to the Vaudeville theatre ready for Dead Funny to start. The play was written by Terry Johnson and was first performed in 1994\. It's set in 1992, the year Benny Hill died, followed by Frankie Howerd a few days later. The characters are part of comedy appreciation society, the Dead Funny Society, which comes together to mourn the passing of the comedians. Throughout the storyline we learn more about how Eleanor wants a child but is frustrated when her husband has no interest in touching her, the not so perfect marriage of Nick and Lisa and the overly mothered Brian, who just wants everyone to be happy. ![Dead Funny](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2PY3KofnWo8CGECUyUMeoG/77d8140acefc5e8631056adfb7de1eeb/dead-funny.jpg)
The performance was strong; the show does what the name suggestions - it was dead funny. My favourite character was easily Eleanor, played by Katherine Parkinson, who came out with some of the funniest remarks about her husband and the rest of the cast. It's also the first performance I've seen with full on nudity and boy, I was not ready for that. Cue some very immature giggles!
A Tuesday night of culture was pretty good! You can catch Dead Funny on at the Vaudeville theatre until 4th February 2017\. Thanks for the invite [London Theatre Bloggers](http://theatrebloggers.co.uk/) and [Stagedoor](http://apple.co/1sglYkH) (a handy little app for finding new shows to see).
[caption id="attachment_1615" align="aligncenter" width="1024"]![Dead Funny performed at the Vaudeville Theatre Katherine Parkinson as Eleanor, Steve Pemberton as Brian, Emily Berrington as Lisa,Rufus Jones as Richard; Ralf Little as Nick ©Alastair Muir 01.11.16](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4jmBB6f1byQ4aSWaSyu2ue/64807d558cc7408cc662fbfe1e33116f/dead-funny-play-by-terry-johnson-performed-at-the-vaudeville-theatre-london-uk.jpg) Katherine Parkinson as Eleanor, Steve Pemberton as Brian, Emily Berrington as Lisa, Rufus Jones as Richard; Ralf Little as Nick Image ©Alastair Muir 01.11.16[/caption]
 **I was a guest of both All Bar One and Dead Funny but as always, my reviews wouldn't be here if I didn't love it.

seoDescription.en-GB: A trip to see the West End play, Dead Funny by Terry Johnson and dinner at the newly refurbished All Bar One in Leicester Square.

title.en-GB: What PRs look for in bloggers

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I've heard a lot of bloggers wonder why they are chosen for campaigns over other bloggers. This was particularly so at an event I went to recently - some bloggers did something a little different before it started and others were just invited to the main event (a big no no in my opinion but let's not go into that). It got me thinking about why we chose certain bloggers for campaigns and not others. I'm putting my 'outreach' hat on and sharing my reasons for choosing a blogger to work with. These nine points may come across quite harsh but this is a behind the scenes glimpse into my choices:
**1\. They fit the brief**
Bloggers need to fit the brief 100%. There's no point working with a 20 year old beauty blogger if your client's target audience is 40 year old parents. They also have to be influential on key platforms. For example, if I'm looking to grow a client's Instagram I'll look for Instagrammers. They won't even have to have a blog (that's just an extra). **2\. They fit the client** If I'm looking for a blogger to write about a luxury brand, they'll have to have a feel of luxury themselves. The client will have to like them too which purely comes down to personal opinion so this can sometimes be tricky! **3\. They're responsive** I know that some bloggers may get hundreds of emails a day but, if you expect us to reply quickly, we expect you to as well. Campaign outreach happens quite quickly so, if you don't respond within a day or so of my email it's likely I'll have moved on to look for someone else. I've got a client waiting on results remember. **4\. They have an engaged audience** I've recently noticed a couple of top big bloggers who use follow, unfollow tactic or have bought their followers. It shows. It might get you noticed but why would I want to work on a campaign with you if your audience is a bunch of bots? The best bloggers to work with are ones with mid-high engagement on their posts. I'll be reporting back on how many likes, shares, comments or retweets their post gets so it's important for me to know that I'm likely to get good results. **5\. Their stats match the KPIs of the campaign** Sometimes a client wants something very specific and you need to work to that. One campaign I worked on had to have bloggers with a domain authority (DA) of over 25 who don't post sponsored content (that was pretty much near impossible to find). DA is an initial judge to see if a blog is good but it doesn't come down to just that. I look at both follower numbers and engagement. Social shares are going to be important in any blog post so, if a client is particularly keen to expand one channel, I'll make sure my blogger has an active and engaged presence on that channel. **6\. The blog or channel isn't packed with sponsored content** There needs to be a balance. I don't particularly like reading heavily sponsored content so why would your readers? I've come across a few parenting blogs which just contain sponsored, heavily key-worded content and giveaways. It just looks spammy. If you are writing a lot of sponsored content, think about what your audience wants to read and make the post useful for them. **7\. They're nice to work with** If I've worked with a blogger before, they have delivered their work and they were polite and friendly, then I'll put them forward for more campaigns. Working with bloggers you've previously worked with is great as you both know how each other likes to work. It's also one of the reasons I like to meet bloggers face to face too. **8\. They write good content** I'm talking about creative, well written content. Reading generic posts which don't have a point to them doesn't give me a lot of faith that I'll be proud of the work a blogger created for me. I want to see creativity and personality in posts. **9\. They care about their writing** This is similar to the last one. Unfortunately I'm very good at spotting typos in blog posts (even spotting when there are extra spaces in text) I'm increasingly noticing them in a lot of big blogs. Everyone occasionally makes makes spelling mistakes (and I'm sure you'll be able to find one or two in my posts), but if a blog is littered with them it looks like they don't care about their writing. I know that posts usually fit around a 9-5 job on top of a hectic social life but it takes ten minutes to read something through properly. If I'm paying a blogger to write something I'd expect to see the post first, not to change the content but just to check it over. Put yourself in the shoes of the client, they're not going to be too happy to read a post about their brand which is littered with typos and it reflects badly on the PR.
**10\. They want to work on the campaign** Lastly, the blogger has to actually want to work on the campaign. There's been quite a few times that the blogger is a perfect fit but they'll decline to be involved. It might just be that they are too busy or that they don't like the brand. At the end of the day it's the blogger's decision to take up the offer.  
There are a lot of factors which go into why I choose to work with a blogger. It's not always a numbers game. Sometimes I've lined up the perfect blogger and the client just doesn't like them so I have to go back to square one. Everything I've said above, can pretty much be applied to all sorts of influencers, not just bloggers.
_What's my main advice to you?_
Don't get caught up in the numbers. Don't write a blog or start an Instagram channel or whatever it is you want to do just so PRs will contact you. Start it because you want to and because you care about what you're doing. It shines through and PRs WILL notice that.

I spotted a 90s meme the other day and I wondered what things summed up the 90s for me personally. I've been scrolling back through old photos and trying to remember everything just so I could bring you my nine 90s throwbacks.
**1\. Shag bands**
Remember these? You used to cross them over on your wrists and if someone broke one they had to do certain sexual things. I googled these just now and found an article where an eight year old girl said to her mum: if a boy snaps a black band I have to make a baby with him." Why?! Because he snapped a bit of plastic?! That was a particularly strange craze.
**2\. Crash Bandicoot**
I can remember getting a Playstation when we lived in our old house and playing Crash Bandicoot and the Lemmings on it. Crash was my favourite though, I loved getting all those apples and spinning the crabs out the way! Did you hear that it's getting [remastered](https://twitter.com/PlayStation/status/805114347311611904)?! If you're looking to reminisce in the meantime then look no further as GarlandTheGreat has the game one Youtube:
**3\. Laces in the playground**
I moved schools in year four and discovered a whole new thing - break time snacks! At morning break we all used to get together and trade snacks. The best snack you could have was strawberry laces, ideally fizzy ones. I tasted them a year or so ago and they were disgusting, just a ball of sour sugar - yuck.
**4\. Word Art**
Remember when you'd spend ages picking the word art before you even started your homework then you'd sat back satisfied that you were definitely going to get 100% because your title looked so damn good?! The rainbow one was by far my favourite.
**5. Mr Motivator**
This guy was awesome! Everyone's mum owned a VHS with Mr Motivator doing his thing on it. The lycra, the bum bag and of course the motivation - it was all brilliant. We got to see him live when we went to Bestival earlier this year, we'd woken up hungover and in the pouring rain but after a session with him we felt ready for the day.
![Mr Motivator at Bestival ](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/160GmLONEGWyGyg2oo2OUg/1fdc6b98141f09232b61b8d8f7f0f292/mr-motivator-at-bestival.jpg)
**6\. Mood rings**
These little babies were the ultimate insight into a friends mood. Just take a look at their mood ring and judge away. Blue and green meant fairly normal but other colours like orange meant unsettled and black even meant depressed
**7\. Little red car**
My first car was so reliable, never ran out of petrol and always got a parking space. At the first glimpse of spring my brother and I would always rush out to the garden to wash our toys down including this little car. Everyone I knew had one and as I couldn't find a pic of mine here's Charlie looking absolutely adorable in his!
![Red and yellow car](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/NQgvh05lsGakuA6WAYCwE/2bdfe853bce6644bac5b4c74cfaa4596/red-and-yellow-car.jpg)
**8\. The Sims**
I'm not sure when we first got a computer at home but at some point I discovered The Sims. My friend and I used to spend hours planning and building our houses (after doing the money cheat of course). I think the only time we actually played the 'live' bit was when we made our crush fall in love with us. Oh, and you'd buy that vibrating heart bed so your characters could have sex and babies and stuff. Looking back now that seems super weird for ten year old me to be playing.
**9\. The Spice Girls**
Were you getting worried that I'd wouldn't mention my top 90s throwback?! Of course it's the Spice Girls. I bloody love them. I remember being super jealous that my cousins had Spice Girls T-shirts and I didn't. We all got together again a few years ago for the West End show and of course we had to dress up! We were singing along to all the songs and during the interval loads of the crowd came up to us to have their photos taken. ![Spice Girls](https://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/SAM_6114.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: There are plenty of memes around showing you top 90s trends but these are my nine top 90s throwbacks. Expect Crash Banicoot, Mr Motivator and more....

title.en-GB: Nine Things I Want To Achieve In Life

wordpressContent.en-GB:
I can remember writing a very specific life ambitions list on my Facebook when I was younger. It involved things like hug a man in a giant chicken suit (done) and own a loft apartment in New York (not done). I think that list needs a bit of an update so I've been thinking about what I actually want to achieve. 2015 saw me do two big life goals at once by getting [married](http://admin.vikibell.com/wedding-day-part-i/) and [buying a house](http://admin.vikibell.com/decorating-tips/) (well a flat but it still counts right?). Our wedding was amazing and although we're still decorating our flat, I'm really proud to have somewhere of my own. So what's next on my life agenda?
**1\. Visit South America**
I've heard loads of good things about exploring South America. I don't have anywhere specifically in mind so if you have any tips then let me know!
I'm trying to work through the continents and South America is one I've not had a chance to visit yet. At some point I'm going to plot everywhere I've been onto a map and host it on there so... watch this space.
**2\. Own a house**
I know I have a flat right now, it's wonderful and I'm incredibly lucky to live there but, eventually, I want to own somewhere with stairs and a spare room. I imagine that we'll stay where we are until we cross the big scary bridge that is having kids, then we'll look for somewhere bigger and obviously have to move out of London. Wow I sound like an adult don't I?! Anyway, that leads me on nicely to my next point.
**3\. Have children**
This is far far far off in the future (sorry Nan!) I'm having far too much fun at the moment without having to worry about smelly nappies; not to mention having to deal with a hangover and a child at once. See! The fact that I'm planning on having to look after a mini human whilst hungover just proves that I'm not ready. So at some point there will be mini-me's but not anytime soon.
**4\. Be an extra in a movie**
This one has made it on from my original list. There was something I did at school which involved something to do with 28 days later - very vague. I wasn't too sure what I signed up for or even what it was but seeing as my name isn't in the credits it doesn't count. I'd just like my five seconds of fame by walking across the background or sitting in a bar or something in a movie. I'm quite happy with whatever it is.
**5\. Sell a piece of art**
I've sold two paintings in my life which I'm pretty proud of. One was to my a level art teacher, Miss Mackie and the other was to a colour professor at the University of Leeds who just happened to stumble across it and loved it. I've always loved making art and I always say I want to do more, my biggest issue is space. I have so many canvas' around the house but no where for them to go. I don't want to paint over them but I can't keep storing them in everyone's garages. Maybe I'll make a section dedicated to them on here at some point...
**6\. Take a course in photography**
I love taking photos and playing around with my camera. I did a photography module in uni but we mainly learnt about the history of photography. I'd love to go somewhere for a week and be instructed how to take great photos as I'm using my camera. Most of what I've learnt so far has been from me experimenting.
**7\. Throw a giant party!**
I love organising things as you can probably tell by how elaborate our wedding was and from me helping to host our annual [Wood Party](http://admin.vikibell.com/planning-wood-party/). At some point I'd love to organise another massive party, perhaps a ball. I have a feeling this will need to wait a few years until I'm rich but it's going to happen. I'll be thirty in five years, any excuse ay?
**8\. Keep learning fun and strange talents**
Okay, this is more of a mantra than a set goal. It's something I started thinking about when I signed up to a [jewellery course](http://admin.vikibell.com/making-jewellery/) and continued with improv and bouldering. I like the idea that I can have loads of different hobbies and activities to do. I'd really like to try out being one of those people at the circus who wraps themselves around in the hanging ribbon but I've got absolutely no upper body strength. Oh, and at some point I'd like to do a bartender course and learn how to flip bottles and shit.
**9\. Happiness**
Happiness was my resolution for 2016 and I think I 80% achieved that. I went on some really fun holidays, had an incredible birthday and have spent time with some of my best buddies. There's been a couple of things holding me back which means that number isn't at 100% just yet. But! Big changes are about to happen so watch this space....

seoDescription.en-GB: Looking back at what I said my life ambitions were when I was younger, I think it's time to set some new ones. Here's my nine life goals.

title.en-GB: My Trip To South Africa - The Best Trip Of My Life

wordpressContent.en-GB:
The summer after my GCSEs I went on a school trip to South Africa. It was, hands down, the best trip I’ve ever taken. We spend two and a half weeks exploring four areas of South Africa; seeing countless animals and experiencing the Zulu culture.
Looking back now, I'm really not sure why I signed up, it didn't sound like my kind of thing at that age. I'd never done DofE or even camped outside before. My parents were convinced they were going to get a call home, two days in, with me crying about how I'd seen a spider. Luckily that wasn't the case. Fifteen year old me packed her bags and set off to South Africa without a care in the world. We landed in Durban and stayed overnight in a camp before we split off into groups of six and meeting our guides Douwe and Sicelo. Our first stop was the St Lucia Wetlands. **St Lucia Wetlands** We spent three days in the wetlands and all got to know each other pretty well. I went along knowing my two friends but came back bonded with our whole group - we went through everything together, experiencing a rainbow of emotions as we went along. As we trekked through the wetlands Sicelo and Douwe told us about the animals we spotted. We saw hippos, rhinos and kudu (a type of antelope).   ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/29ih6SfQGgC0Iw08wmeg8k/3e7211a5fe9cbb8a9bdde29580350b07/south-africa.jpg) We carried everything we needed on our backs, including all our food, so you can imagine I was quite happy when we got to our ‘home’ for the night and dropped everything off. Home wasn’t quite as you would expect - it was a cluster of trees. Our sleeping arrangements were simple: a sleeping bag under the stars. We stayed safe from any inquisitive animals by doing 'night watch' which was where we each took turns to stay awake for an hour to keep the fire going and shine a touch around our clearing. I thought getting up for an hour each night would be difficult but as the trip went on, I appreciated the hour to myself. I kept a diary throughout the trip and it’s been amazing to look back on every few years and recall some of the serious and not so serious memories.  ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4UEtM5NCC4I06uYWUEiIoo/69f840adb0ce692dff50516735567897/south-africa.jpg) **Imfolozi** Next stop was Imfolozi. This was a big game park where we spent four days. To get there we all piled into a safari jeep and sung countless amounts of Disney songs along the way (YAY!). On our way into the park we spotted zebras, kudus, rhinos and a few giraffes. ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5RuNN29UPK6AMs0uycKwE2/06491052974face241e6969fea72dcfd/south-africa.jpg) We made our way to home for the night and crossed a big winding river which looked like something out of the Lion King. You need to be careful when crossing the rivers there as there could be crocodiles lurking in the depths. We had to stick to the shallow sections just in case and keep an eye out. When we woke up one morning the section of the river we had crossed the evening before had a croc lounging on the banks! ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/YZqWEXWEiAGWOMOW22koO/ea34e1b27049bbfe48a9aeee3a0d4164/south-africa.jpg) Speaking of which, night watch was suddenly more dangerous. One night we were camped out by a cliff and next to the river. Seeing leopards or lions etc. on the other side of the river was fine but if we heard splashing, we were in trouble! The Imfolozi was possibly my favourite section of the trip. I loved that we fell asleep to the sound of lions and baboons and that we bathed in the river every day. We also walked for hours around the plains learning more about the history of the area and the animals. ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1sHmY9ZdVW6qGW8kEK6MyQ/44cd612eda9ccda7b3d488be2ca71949/south-africa.jpg) **Drakensberg Mountiains** After the Imfolozi it was onto the Drakensberg mountains. There weren’t as many animals there, although we saw a lot of baboons on one of the days. The views were I-N-C-R-E-D-I-B-L-E! ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5c0bGWbeLeCAgGyAyIi8AW/bfc4904e5147512e44a493f1c15b0776/south-africa.jpg) Our home whilst in the Drakensbergs was underneath a giant rock near the top of one of the mountains. On our first day we decided to walk up to what we though looked like a rock in the shape of a bear. We also climbed inside a waterfall and spotted bushmen paintings inside rocks. After missing my daily dips in the river I decided to jump into one of the pools on top of the mountains. As you’d expect, it was freezing, refreshing but freezing! ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/51c4P2w9xCgqwaYsUKuaUA/1c707fe41139823ea841f3f39da00aac/south-africa.jpg) On our last night in the mountains something happened. One of the rules of the trip was that you leave no trace. This includes setting fire to any toilet paper you use. As one of the girls burnt hers she accidentally dropped it and the dry grass immediately ignited. We all ran out to try and stop the fire. We’d seen areas of the mountains which had been set alight under controlled circumstances so as not to cause a wild fire. We knew the importance of putting that fire out, quickly. We battled it by pouring the little water we had on it and hitting it with our jumpers, finally managing to direct it towards a rock and extinguish. If we hadn’t acted so fast we would have been in a lot of trouble. One tiny accident could have been a catastrophe. We worked as a team to fight it off and I can remember sitting in our cave that evening with everyone coughing and spluttering but happy we had all worked together and beat the fire. ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ClZUSnoUUo6WksWQ46a8/a383eac8a5c357e3ace09d92a660a399/south-africa.jpg) **Zulu Village** Our final stop was a Zulu village. I don’t remember where this was exactly and I can’t seem to track it down online but it was this little community we stayed with for a few nights. During the day, we visited a nearby school where we fixed up and painted the classrooms and taught the children. I can remember on our first night a little girl taught us a song. You say “I love my teddybear” twice then “I polish your shoe” as you pretend to polish someones shoe, give them a hug and then both skip around the circle whilst everyone claps. ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4e3jhKKfc4GW0si44GS2w8/72219e263b95566068c0a1d7088c96d1/south-africa.jpg) As I’ve been writing this post, I’ve been looking back at the diary I kept and reading all the messages from my group. One of the things that everyone commented on was how much they enjoyed everyone else’s company and how much fun we were all having together. Words can’t describe what the trip meant to me. A trip like that is something you need to experience yourself to understand. Being out in the wilderness for so long has such a calming effect. I spent my days laughing, smiling and jumping about being silly. Half of my memories were so personal to our group that they would never make it into this post. It was the best trip of my life made great by my group and our amazing guides Douwe and Sicelo.  _“The wilderness on the outside is a reflection of the wilderness on the inside” Douwe Van Der Zee, 2007\. RIP._ ![South Africa](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6w3WHjVzcAaEm4wYgmo20C/dc67cbf98502d28b656eaefcf1fc26ad/south-africa.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: We spend two and a half weeks exploring four areas of South Africa, seeing countless animals and experiencing the Zulu culture.

title.en-GB: Trying Out Meal Deliveries With HelloFresh

wordpressContent.en-GB:
Ages ago I heard about [HelloFresh](https://www.hellofresh.co.uk/tasty/) and thought that it sounded like a great idea. Our usual routine means that we're only at home a few nights during the week so doing a big online order means some of the food gets wasted or shoved in the freezer. Using a service like HelloFresh gives us just the right ingredients to make some delicious, home cooked meals. I thought I'd give it a go when I got a voucher only to find they didn't deliver to my postcode. What?! I live in London, how do you not deliver to me? Anyway, a few months later an email appeared in my inbox saying the voucher was due to expire so I thought I'd just double check - GOOD NEWS! They now deliver to my postcode. With that I ordered a trial box.
The process was quite simple, just click through and pick how many people you're feeding for how many meals then check out. You get a whole bunch of reminders telling you when it's all coming and even an email saying it's just been delivered! Unpacking the box was pretty cool too, I was wondering how they'd kept everything cool but there was ice blocks and big wool insulation thing in there. ![Hello Fresh](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6PreV7isLuqeoIe4WeSmkW/1e9ce6fcf73b9ed8b79b903ef368ac2b/hello-fresh.jpg)
For some reason we'd ended up with a family box which was two meals for four (enough for leftovers for lunch!) There were two recipe cards for a pork casserole and a chicken stir fry inside. Each detailed exactly how many ingredients to use so that you can make them again later on. They gave you just enough ingredients recipe including little sachets of apple cider vinegar and a few loose star anise for the chicken dish.
We chose the pork casserole first as we don't often eat pork. I think this is the first time that I've followed a recipe step by step without substituting ingredients. It was super easy and only took about 40 mins to make. ![Hello Fresh](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1qrWUpVafScUU6a8AAECyQ/fa519341833fedcee716aeb384ece931/hello-fresh.jpg)
I was pretty tired so didn't lay out the plates as pretty as they did on the recipe card but you get the gist. The food itself was delicious. If I saw the dish on a menu I doubt I'd ever pick it but I guess that's the good thing about having your menu chosen for you; you get to try different things. ![Hello Fresh](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/fsgVhX2BSS6WMsukUQGeO/f36efae63297dde340787d1bc31f38ec/hello-fresh.jpg)
The second dish was the chicken stir fry and it was equally as delicious as the pork. I've kept both recipe cards so we can make them again. I think HelloFresh is a great idea if you don't have time to pick up ingredients or if you've run out of inspiration in the kitchen.
![Hello Fresh](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/f3E6VHRJ1CS4yUyYo4cWg/b11fc3c2b1b4d4c9a8091fb941b08262/hello-fresh.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: We're only at home a few nights during the week but using HelloFresh gives us just the right ingredients to make some delicious, home cooked meals.

title.en-GB: What Would I Do If I Won The Lottery?

wordpressContent.en-GB:
This is possibly the least likely thing to happen to me seeing as I don't play the lottery and don't like gambling. Spending £2 every week could eventually accumulate to buy flights for a holiday, rather then give me the chance that I might, one day, potentially, maybe, if I'm lucky win the lottery .... I know which one I'd rather. But, it's one of those things you think about isn't it? - what would I do if I won the lottery. Well... **The second I found out I won...** I'd cash in my ticket before I did anything, I don't think I'd quite believe it otherwise. Then I'd book somewhere swanky for dinner so I could tell Charlie. Or maybe I'd buy a massive bottle of champagne and get a lobster takeaway so we could plot and plan at home. I guess it depends what night of the week it is that I found out. If it was a weekend then it would be a pretty big night! **The day or two after...** Bit disappointing as I wouldn't do anything extravagant but, I'd spend the time planning how I'd spend the money (and read through this post to see if I still agree with myself!) **The month after...** I'd pay off our mortgage and hire a project manager to help give our flat a makeover. We've got all these plans to make it even more awesome but time and money seem to get in the way. We've decorated the [lounge](http://admin.vikibell.com/decorating-tips/) and refitted the bathroom but, we _still_ need to sort out our kitchen, bedroom and hallway. Whilst the project manager is sorting out our flat, I think Charlie and I would go travelling and tick off some of the destinations on our bucket list. We'd aim to finish up somewhere like the Caribbean and would invite our family and friends out for a holiday/ party. FUN! **The year or so after...**
Once we got back from travelling, I think I'd still be living roughly the same life as I am now just a little nicer and with more holidays. I'd still want to have a job as I like the structure in my life but, I would like more time to go on adventures, paint and create things and write this blog. I'd also make sure we did loads of the awesome events you read about in Timeout but can never afford to go to, like outrageous banquets and sky high dining.
Finally, I'd like to give some of the money to charity but I'd tie this in with doing something really fun too. I had an amazing time at the [Jane Packer](http://admin.vikibell.com/jane-packer-foundation-flower-ball/) ball a few years ago a we raised an incredible amount of money, so perhaps I'd hold an annual event. I could pay for the entire evening and give any profit or the cost of the tickets away. That way everyone wins, money goes to the right place, a whole group of people get an amazing night and I get to organise something fun - just like I said in my [ambitions list](http://admin.vikibell.com/9-things-i-want-achieve-life/).
**To sum it all up: throw crazy parties, go travelling/ on amazing holidays, keep some savings and live a fun life. Now I just need a lottery ticket.**
![Champagne](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2tJ0iuiNgAISo4gCC6u4Ew/2bfd20b39429d6dba5ea7dc07d48e641/champagne.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: I don't play the lottery so this isn't too likely to happen BUT these are my plans for if I did, one day, maybe win the big bucks!

wordpressContent.en-GB: Our most recent city break was to Berlin for four days. I’d found the flights earlier in the year and for £100 return for the both of us I couldn’t really say no. We both kind of forgot about the trip until the week before when we had the “oh yeah, we’re in Berlin next weekend’ realisation. We set off at stupid o'clock on Friday morning and flew back at an even stupider time on Tuesday morning. Despite feeling tired from the flights I think these are my ideal timings. It means you get a full day on both sides of the holiday.  **Day one** We landed in Schönefeld and jumped on the train to our Airbnb in Mitte. The trains were pretty simple to work out. You can either get a ticket for one journey, one day or a week. The week ticket was €30 which worked out best for us as a day ticket was €7 each and we needed five days. After dropping off our bags we headed to Alexandraplatz to find somewhere for lunch. A random guy overheard our conversation and pointed us in the direction of a few typical German restaurants. We ordered the Berlin sausage platter and the currywurst which we shared. As well a few beers of course!  Afterwards, we headed towards the German Christmas markets in the centre. They were nice to walk around but not great for shopping. I think we were spoilt by the markets in Munich and Nuremberg last year. We'd planned a few things to do over lunch so we jumped back on the train and headed east to Warschauer Straße. The area was like the Shoreditch of Berlin. There was a lot more street art, a lot less tourists and it felt more like true Berlin. We walked for what felt like miles (don't let Charlie be in charge of directions!) and through a pretty dodgy feeling park where I'm pretty sure you could have picked up all sorts of magical substances from the guys milling about in it. Finally, we got to where we were going.... a shopping centre. Our friend Hannah had directed us to a bar at the top which was pretty tricky to find. It's not sign posted that well and we ended up at the library on the fifth floor before we found our way through the carpark and up a ramp to Klunkerkranich. The bar was my favourite in Berlin. It had a view over the whole city (well duh, it was on top of a multi story building) and a really fun vibe to it. We grabbed a few beers and settled down in some of the seats at the back. People seemed to be having a casual evening drink or even just a cup of coffee.There was also a DJ playing some relaxing tunes too. I loved the whole atmosphere and it was exactly what I needed after a day of travelling.  ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2j013Cji4Aoc82uSKEIAKQ/c38caaccd4662b7b707219869f4bee80/berlin.jpg)Our evenings entertainment was improv. Charlie had looked up to see what the scene was like in Berlin and found a show nearby. After finishing a few drinks at Klunkerkranich, we grabbed a quick (and very cheap) dinner at a nearby pizza place called Enzos before heading to the Berlin Comedy Club. The improv was a different format to what I've seen before with loads of short form games and two teams competing against each other. The improvisers were either America, Australian or German which was fun too. I think most of the improvisers I see in London are all English so it was good to experience different senses of humour.  **Day two** We wanted to tick a few more Christmas markets off the list so headed to Gendarmenmarkt. On the way we stopped off at this little place for breakfast and I had bacon with cheese and scrambled eggs - YUM! It was just the right amount for breakfast and the coffee was delicious. ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7ffUAPoBWgMkIeCkCqOsaQ/c06dde1becf3294725994e0e9ed871cb/berlin.jpg)The market was fun to walk around. You have to pay a euro to get in but it’s worth it as there’s a whole bunch of stalls, more than the other markets and they also have a live band. It was getting closer to 1pm and we'd booked ourselves onto the alternative walking tour. I would highly recommend this if you ever visit Berlin. It’s free and takes you to some of the boroughs and explains about the street art and some of the history - without making you feel like a ridiculous tourist. We learnt about the difference between using paint or pasting printed images up - there's also a big difference in the fines you'll get if the police catch you. We also learnt a lot about gentrification throughout the tour and it was sad to see these squads or artist studios being moved on because the area was getting too expensive. ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/6P3thZJAPYKmg6Am4IMMwo/85f59171de0687e40163d22e4b200f03/berlin.jpg)Although they tour starts in Alexandraplatz, we headed East to Ostbahnhof district where there’s more street art. We saw work by the Berlin Kidz and street art that had been made by abseiling down a building. I'd always wondered how the do it! Another technique of creating the street art is to fill a fire extinguisher with paint and use that to spray the high areas of the building. ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1vd2LxMQhuWwG6Wy0WaS60/870f828384b540125486c6e3a91bcda6/berlin.jpg) We walked through the district and learnt more about the area. It covers two sides of the river and when the wall was up it was unsure who owned the bridge which connected them. Each year the citizens come out and have a massive food fight on the bridge. They throw rotten fruit and vegetables and even occasionally dirty nappies. Whoever retreats first loses the bridge for the year but the winner has to clean it all up.  I’d never looked into the reasons behind street art before, I had assumed that they were mainly due to spread a message or even because someone was just bored. There’s a lot of political messaging in the street art around Ostbahnhof but other Berlin artists create their work simply because they can. One guy paints 6 and 7's around the place for that very reason. Another, takes photos of people dancing in clubs and pastes them up on the wall surrounded by confetti in his series ‘_Time to Dance_’. There are also rules about painting over each other's street art. There's been various frauds and fights when someone has gone over the top of someone's work. Street art is only semi permanent, what I saw on the tour might not be there next week. Work disappears because it’s been either been painted over by the government or by another street artists. One of the rules of painting over someone's work is that you need to take into consideration the time and money they spent on it. The higher value it is, the less acceptable it is to paint over it.![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3IMooTpes0ak6i6MgOCWKi/059e124556a62f80f384e264128e13d9/berlin.jpg) The tour lasted three hours and I feel like I’ve only touched the surface of street art knowledge. As the tour finished up in Ostbahnhof we asked our guide where she’d recommend for dinner. Funnily enough it was near to Warschauer Straße where we’d gotten off the day before. We jumped on the train for one stop over and found a place off a road called Simon-Dach-Straße. I think we were still pretty exhausted from all the travelling and walking we did so had a fairly relaxed dinner and headed back to our Airbnb to catch up on our ZZZ’s. **Day three** We woke up to rain - yuck. Feeling refreshed after a big sleep, I was ready to hit the ground running and tour Berlin like never before. Except for the rain. We tried not to let it bring us down so grabbed breakfast and walked along to the Brandenburg gate and the Holocaust memorial. As we arrived at each place I pulled up some of the travel guides and read out the history of them. The scale of the Holocaust memorial was incredible. It was designed by Peter Eisenman and the blocks are meant to create an uneasy and confusing atmosphere - it did exactly that. ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/1juPRrMcn4IkWkO0ISOwq2/290f6a956c3a6077718d60c757437aa5/berlin.jpg)We had another walk around the Christmas markets before being defeated by the rain. Charlie’s favourite place in Munich is the Hufbrauhaus and seeing as there was one in Berlin, it seemed rude not to pop in. And by pop in I mean we were in there for about five hours. Opps. I love the atmosphere in beerhalls. It seemed like a lot of locals headed there with their families for Sunday lunch. The place was packed when we entered with elderly couples and children spinning around on the dance floor. As our Steins arrived the band started playing the Viki song which literally went “oh Viki, Viki, Viki Viki’ - errrr hello?! ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/4w3hR1MPc4me4aMSq88A8Q/a7d6e1c1186cea9798b5a3f1ebefc722/berlin.jpg)After a long time in a beerhall we thought it was a good idea to do a pub crawl. I don’t usually like pub crawls. They’re full of rowdy men looking to sink pints and move on. As well as the walking tour the alternative group offered a pub crawl which showed some of the more unique Berlin hangouts. We started off in a little bar called Yesterdays before going to a craft beer bar called the [Monterey Bar](https://twitter.com/montereybar). I picked the Berliner Berg and Charlie chose the Nogine O. both were really nice although at 10% I think I preferred the Nogine O. Feeling a little merry from the copious amounts of drinks, we went to an underground ping pong club. In true Berlin style it was through a door with no sign post and was full of graffiti. There was a game of about ten people playing ping pong, each walking around the table until it was their turn to hit it. If you were out, you were out and if you made it to the final two, things got pretty intense. The beer here was from their own micro-brewery so we grabbed a few bottles and settled down to watch the games. This was the best place we went to I think as it seemed like you were chilling in someones games room, rather than a bar. ![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/UkfJX9HY2WsYOWsEuUUu2/90214b18d5279fece626942f64ad8223/berlin.jpg)Next stop was an absinthe bar where they had a ridiculous amount of different types of it from all over the world. Our last stop was a club which was very very quiet for Berlin. It was a Sunday night though and having been drinking for hours I wasn’t in the mood for something too energetic. The pub crawl was fun to try out but I wouldn’t recommend it - you’d be able to look up similar bars and clubs yourself and save the €12\. **Day four** We were feeling extremely tired from the previous night but I wanted to make sure I didn’t miss anything out. We went out for the perfect hangover cure - pizza, then made our way across to see the East Side Gallery.![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/5lwFnqv23CKOC422Iiu0wo/d8dbfa48ce1b8ca30182b7e8c8615556/berlin.jpg) This is a big expanse of the Berlin wall which has been decorated by artists. There was various political messages as well as paintings which simply aimed to be pretty. We walked along the wall for a while before doubling back. It’s quite a nice walk and really shows the size of the wall. There were quite a few tourists around though so be prepared to dodge them taking photos. After we went to RAW-Gelände which I really wanted to see during the day. At night it’s a place with bars and clubs but there’s a really feel of artist community there. Not to mention I love abandoned and run-down buildings - I’m strange, I know.![Berlin](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2lqJvSGfvWecQKGygIseq6/937fe23b5bd12943292a3beeb215c9fe/berlin.jpg) My last Berlin activity was to go and see the Reichstag Building. I know a few people that have been up it but I wasn’t too worried about going inside. You need to get a ticket from a place across the road and when I got there the only tickets were for the next day. Not being too worried, I walked all the way around the outside instead before heading back home. I feel like we managed to fit quite a lot into our four days in Berlin. We weren’t too worried about going to the museums or the tourist hotspots and instead just wanted to experience the culture and learn more about the current city. It has an amazing feel to it whether you go for tourists reasons or to experience their insane nightlife.

title.en-GB: Abstract Expressionism at the Royal Academy of Art

wordpressContent.en-GB:
After spotting the posters on the tube a few months ago I really wanted to see the Abstract Expressionism exhibition at the Royal Academy of Art. It's a movement which heavily influenced my work at uni, not to mention that it was one of the biggest art movements of the twentieth century. This was the first time the big names such as Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and Mark Rothko had all had work displayed together.
Walking around the exhibitions rooms reignited my love for exploring artwork and visiting galleries. I used to pop along to various exhibitions whilst I was at uni but it seems to have dropped off my radar since. I always recall a school trip to the National Gallery where we were dragged around, completely uninterested in the work - I think my highlight of the trip was buying a pencil in the shop at the end. Visiting a museum or gallery is far more satisfying when you can take the time to appreciate the artwork and understand the reasons behind it. As I walked around the Royal Academy, I was intently listening to the audio guide learning more about the reasons behind the seemingly random paintings.
A lot of the artwork was created using partially planned spontaneity. The artist might have known the types of marks they wanted to make on the page but they didn't know the end result. Things were left to chance and they trusted themselves to make the work great. On first inspection the paintings look uncontrolled and unplanned but once you look closely you can see how the artists have worked back into their creations.
The principle of improvisation was central to Abstract Expressionism. This links through into the popular music at the time as well - jazz. Whilst not all the artists were interested or influenced by jazz, you can spot a lot of similarities between the art and the improvised jazz solos. This got me thinking about how one hobby can influence you in everything you do. When painting is always improvised my end result. Even when working from photographs I never want a painting to look the same - what's the point? My love improvising my paintings explains a lot about how much I enjoyed my improv comedy course last year.
This blog post has gone off on quite a bit of a tangent and I guess this bunch of ramblings is more for me than anyone else. What I'm trying to say is that you should try and visit a museum/ exhibition soon and take the time to think about and appreciate whatever it shows you. Think about it in relation to your life and see if there is anything you can learn from it.

title.en-GB: Doodling On The Tables At Inamo

wordpressContent.en-GB: A few weeks ago Charlie and I were sat in Stansted airport, waiting for our flight to Berlin and wishing the waiter would hurry up and take our order. We started thinking about how awesome it would be to have an iPad so you could order whenever you want instead of having to wait. The guys over at [Inamo](http://www.inamo-restaurant.com/) must have read my mind as an email landed in my inbox inviting me to the Camden opening. The email described a little bit about them and, well, you guessed it … they use iPads to order! Each table comes with an iPad so you can scroll through the pretty pictures of food and drinks, pick what you want and order it straight from there. ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/sjh4gYhE3IgguSMCuA2UK/7e1713f336d54c2e332b252d44fee57f/inamo.jpg) But wait…. there's more! If you don't want to use iPads you can always order using the table as they have interactive projections on there too. Pretty swanky you say? Well, they also have games you can play, a camera so you can spy on the chef, the option to change the table background and even a drawing app but I'll get to that later.  Intrigued by the tech as well as the promise of delicious Asian fusion food, I headed along to the Camden opening. The new restaurant is just opposite Mornington Crescent station and a short walk down from Camden market. I arrived to a champagne and sushi reception on the roof terrace which was surprisingly warm and didn't at all feel like London. I can't remember the last time we ate sushi out but it was delicious. ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/h77MNwIBwcQE0iaaOUSMG/4b8cbec8af29adc930ad7463c57e06c6/inamo.jpg) Then it was play time! We headed inside for a caricature drawing lesson and [David](http://grovescartoons.co.uk/) (our teacher) had already sketched out some of us. Can you spot me? ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/7dzBeYjI3eamuukCYgGAIo/321ba81434ba14c386f5cbe4c037ee04/inamo.jpg)It was then our turn to sketch out our faces. We had a quick run through of how it works and luckily I got the hang of it pretty quickly. You can pick shades of colour and different mark marking tools like spray paint, pen or some patterny thing. I’m pretty bad at drawing people so instead ended up doodling a little octopus and me under the sea. It should totally be on display at the Tate - right? ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/18X95Exj7yKA0mwIMcAwYm/4cd6f4ee4cae8ba8ba75d05d578af182/inamo.jpg) I went into my own little world whilst I was doodling, I could sit and do that for hours. Perhaps it isn’t the best place to take me for dinner if you actually want a conversation? I almost missed the food turning up but I’m so glad I didn’t; everything was A M A Z I N G! ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3mRAHD39H2gmuaigm2wIsu/dc03fdff3f201c185c78fd7d53861373/inamo.jpg) My favourite dishes were the Char Sui Buns (tiny clouds of goodness), Korean chicken wings and the crazy amount of sushi we had to begin with. ![Inamo](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3agl9ZY9xK6G2k86kWwuOS/c43fa0f4a0b855638e682fc51b1d8d32/inamo.jpg) The food and the tech in Inamo has me already planning to go back. Although, the only issue is that I’d want to order everything on the menu!! *Thanks to [Erica](http://www.imbeingerica.com/) for the pic of me. **I was a guest of Inamo but the food and drawing was so good I just had to tell you about it!

seoDescription.en-GB: Trying out the tech and drawing on the tables at the Inamo Camden restaurant opening. As well as eating ALL of the food of course!

title.en-GB: Ten years together adds up to a lot of memories

wordpressContent.en-GB: February holds a few key dates for Charlie and I. There's Valentines on the 14th, the 15th was the day he proposed to me two years ago and the 16th was the first time he asked me to be his girlfriend. Ten years ago. Because of that we tend to roll everything into one big anniversary and do something special on the 16th. Do people still celebrate their dating anniversary when they're married? Well we do. Anyway, ten years is a bloody long time and we've done a hell of a lot. It was time to crunch the numbers so I sat down with my calculator and have worked out (roughly) how many things have happened in that time. Don't worry, I've shown my workings so you can try it too! * Days we’ve been ‘an item’: 3,650 * Counting the day Charlie first asked me out until 16th February 2017 * Minutes we’ve been together: 5,256,000 * Days spent together: 2,336 * Based on us seeing each other everyday since we moved in together in September 2009, an average of a weekend spent together every three weeks at uni, the schools days together and estimates of time we spent together in the holidays * Photos taken: 47,000 * Based on the amount of photos I’ve taken in ten years, not including Charlie’s * Photos of us together: 2,300 * I have 1,500 on my laptop but there are quite a few Charlie has as well as all the ones everyone else has * Amount spent on presents for each other: £2,500 * Based on ten years of Christmas and birthday presents at around £50-100 * Smiles: 27,000  * Based on us smiling around ten times everyday we are with each other plus one smile for everyday we have been together * Hangovers: 628 * Based on one hangover for one of us per weekend for each week we’ve seen each other. This could also be higher but let’s not think about that * Cities visited: 31 * Festivals: 9 ![Viki & Charlie](https://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/DSC00459.jpg) See I told you that was a lot! Charlie and I bring out the best in each other. We're constantly messing about or planning silly ideas. In fact, my how to survive a zombie apocalypse post stems from an extremely long pub conversation we had. We've also learnt a lot about each other and been there through the tears and the tantrums (okay that's just me!). So here's a few of my tips for being happy living with someone:  * Listen to each other * Say yes more often than you say no. It makes things more fun and that thing that you didn’t really feel like doing could just turn out to be awesome! * Laughing and being silly can cure everything * Say what you’re feeling. If something is stressing you out then just say it. The other person probably hasn’t noticed that they’re doing something wrong * Cuddle * Make mundane things fun. The other day I was making fish for dinner so decided to make a fish themed playlist, turn on blue lighting (that's Hue!) and dress up like a fish for when Charlie got home. See? Fun! * Plan time to do exciting things together. Even if it’s just a walk in the park or taking board games down the pub on a Sunday afternoon A few of my favourite memories from the past ten years: It’s too hard to pick a favourite so here’s a few random memories which made me smile: 1. The time we adopted a mummified skeleton called Frankie 2. That time we had a picnic on the floor of our flat whilst listening to bird song youtube clips because the park was shut 3. That time I dressed up as a whore and Charlie had a dead bird on his head for the Movember Gala 4. That time we got super drunk on a cooking course and went gift list shopping in John Lewis 5. That time we pranked Facebook by saying we got married and Charlie’s cousin called up his sister 6. That time we actually got married 7. That time we painted our wedding table plan in the woods 8. That time we woke up drunk and bought our lounge carpet 9. That time I came home and Charlie had put on the Gandalf video in every single room of the house and hid 10. That time we went out with Charlie’s dad to celebrate our first anniversary, drunk two bottles of wine, a magnum of champagne and a bottle of prosecco and then went to an improv class 11. That time we turned up in Ghent to a massive street festival and I won a mask by doing the limbo ![Viki & Charlie](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3p1DYcMHc4EQ846oocoSqy/d7fd841e4feade191ddcd50b117e89f9/viki-charlie.jpg)

I quite often get to a stage where I have no idea what to make for dinner. It’s pretty easy to make the same few recipes every week but it gets boring quickly. To keep track of our favourite recipes and to make sure we’re mixing up our meals, Charlie and I are working on a two week mini project to make a cookbook. It’s not going to be the world's most refined, buy it in a book shop kind of thing but it’ll be something we can flick through and decide on dinner with. I’ll transfer some of the recipes into posts so I can share them with you guys too. The first one I'm sharing is my honey and JD beef. I’d been making beef burritos quite a lot but I didn’t know what else you could do with beef chunks. Apart from the obvious casserole but I’m not a massive fan of that. I had a quick Google and found a few recipes which I mixed together to create this one. Enjoy. ![Honey and JD Beef](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2jhxzz8DBiCOma4ayY6wmk/963c223e52c6ef5421ef88251ac95257/honey-and-jd-beef.jpg) **Ingredients (this makes enough for two)** * 40ml honey * 30ml brown sugar * 40ml Jack Daniels * 30ml Soy sauce * 30ml worchester sauce * 1 clove of garlic * half a fresh chilli * 400g diced beef * 1 tablespoon of oil * 1 tablespoon of butter ![Honey and JD Beef](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/2kTgseL02oSIaOU2UugqGi/b74e10346ceb0b1a143aa35b995347f6/honey-and-jd-beef.jpg) **Method** Whisk together all the honey, sugar, JD, worchester sauce, garlic, chilli and oil. Add the beef and make sure it’s well coated. Then put that all in the fridge for at least two hours. Next, melt the butter in a frying pan and add the beef mixture. You don’t want to cook this for too long else it’ll be too chewy and dry. Literally seal the edges then serve. If you have any sauce leftover you can thicken it up with a little flour and pour it over the top. It’ll end up looking like a big sticky mess but trust me, it’s delicious! I served it with green beans and a bean dish. ![Honey & JD Beef](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3ZPXWLVdteCyG6UCGC8geU/edf87dc74c3e62ee181bc6121905c952/honey-jd-beef.jpg)

seoDescription.en-GB: I didn’t know what else you could do with beef chunks apart from casserole so I came up with this delicious honey and Jack Daniels beef.

title.en-GB: Why I don’t celebrate Valentines day

wordpressContent.en-GB: Charlie and I have been together for over five million minutes. Five million, two hundred and fifty six thousand minutes to be a little more precise. We’ve build up thousands of memories in that time not to mention the 47,000 photos we’ve taken. 16th February marks our ten year ‘dating’ anniversary, (does anyone still celebrate their dating anniversaries once they get married?) so you can excuse us skipping out on the Valentine's celebrations and focussing on a more special one. Ten years is a very long time, in fact it’s forty percent of my life, a percentage which is going to keep increasing (hopefully!) until I forget what life was like without Charlie. Isn’t that weird to think that I trusted fifteen year old me to pick a life partner? Someone to share all the ups and the downs, all the funnies and all the sad bits. Trust me, there’s been a lot of funnies. Based on the amount of days we’ve physically seen each other, 2,336, the days we haven’t and an average smile per day estimate, we’ve smiled 27,000 times because of each other. Think of all those happy endorphins! Ten years has seen us get into some pretty strange situations as well. I once found myself on stage in front of a crowd of hundreds being asked who I am whilst a microphone was thrust into my face. I said the first thing which came into my head which just so happened to be “I am whore” whilst Charlie danced around me with a dead bird on his head. We were dressed up as Red and Tonto from the Lone Ranger for the annual Movember gala and were picked out to represent the ‘best couple’. ![Movember Gala](https://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Movember-Gala.jpg) Another memory I have is getting the tube at rush hour from Canary Wharf whilst carrying a life-size mummified skeleton we’ve just picked up from a transvestite in a shipping container on the docks. Whilst we were packed between passengers we decided her name would be Frankie and that she would welcome guests (and quite possibly scare off guests) in our home. ![Frankie](https://admin.vikibell.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Frankie.jpg) One finally memory that I’ll share with you was a Facebook post. I always enjoy reading about what April Fools pranks brands have pulled but I’d never done any myself, apart from when I changed the time on all the clocks win my parents house and my dad got extremely angry that he was late to work - thinking back now that wasn’t a very good prank. On 31st March 2014 we picked a flower from the garden, I put on a dress, Charlie put on a shirt, we pulled down the white projector screen and took a photo. We changed the background of the photo and uploaded it the next morning with the caption ‘Today’s the day’ and the location set to the Kensington and Chelsea Registry office. We pranked our Facebook friends into thinking we’re getting married on that day. It lead to a lot of likes, comments, phone calls and text messages. All of which we ignored for the first few hours of course. ![April Fools](//images.contentful.com/3ctegf19trkf/3fiTxEBA6IiEgqGoKEAuG/ff788b2dc8d4a31acef0c46d016e4f75/valentines.jpg) Together Charlie and I bring out the best of each other. We like doing silly things and straying away from the norm. We don’t want to celebrate ‘us’ by being sat in a restaurant packed with other couples squinting at each other in the candlelight whilst tucking into a overpriced Valentine’s special sharing dessert. That’s why we’ll skip out on the Valentine's celebrations and save it for two days later when our anniversary hits and we can be 'us'.
